hits._id: Government nominates members to Parliamentary select committee to solve the national problem; UNP puts conditions on participation.

_source.content:
The Speaker informed parliament today the names of the government members appointed to the Parliamentary Select Committee to address the National issue.
 
Accordingly, the government has nominated 19 members including Leader of the House Minister Nimal Siripala de Silva as its chairman.
 
The mandate of the PSC is to make political and constitutional recommendations to enable all Sri Lankans to live as one nation.
 
G.L. Peries, Maithreepala Sirisena, W.D.J. Senevirathna, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Dinesh Gunawardana, Douglas Devananda, Susil Premajayantha, A.L.M. Athaulla, D.E.W Gunasekera, Patali Champika Ranawaka, Rishard Badi Udin, Basil Rajapaksa, Wimal Weerawansa, Lakshaman Senevirathna,  and Wasudeva Nanayakkara are the other ministers appointed to the Committee.
 
Deputy Minister Mutthu Sivalingam, parliamentarians Sudarshani Fernandopulle and Janaka Bandara are also included in the Committee membership.
 
During a vote of condolence in parliament today, Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed his views on the Parliamentary Select Committee appointed by the President.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
The government attempted to form this Committee in the past as well but it failed consequently as the UNP, TNA and JVP did not nominate their members.
 
Our news team asked Chief Opposition Whip MP John Amaratunga whether his party would nominate members to the Committee this time.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
In a letter addressed to the President dated June 13th, the Opposition Leader forwarded the government 4 proposals and asked to implement them before holding elections in the North.
 
First among them are to appoint a civilian Governor to the Northern Provincial Council and invite Commonwealth observers to monitor the proposed North Provincial Council election.
 
Although the Opposition Leader requested a meeting to discuss the implementation of the 17th Amendment and other proposals, the government has not reserved a date for a meeting.
 
Meanwhile our news team asked JVP MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake whether his party is going to participate in the Parliamentary Select Committee.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Our news team also contacted TNA representative and, asked him his party’s decision with regard to their participation in the Committee.
 
The TNA representative told our news team that the majority of the Committee members are from the government, so the previous stance of the party would remain unchanged.

hits._id: UPFA contested the Election - How does SLFP support a national government? : Patriotic movement are baffled

till the 20th.

hits._id: President to address Commonwealth Business Forum

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena, who is in London to attend Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 2018, is scheduled to address the Commonwealth Business Forum today (Apr. 18).
 
The President has been invited to deliver the keynote address at the forum under the title, “Achieving Sustainable Development Goals”.
 
The Commonwealth Business Forum is an integral part of CHOGM and it brings together the businesses critical to trade and investment leadership with the government to debate the issues facing their countries.
 
President Sirisena is also scheduled to meet British Prime Minister Theresa May and hold discussions with several key officials who will be participating in CHOGM.
 
The theme this year’s CHOGM is “Towards a Common Future”.
 
Special attention is being given to areas such as prosperity, security, fairness and sustainability to achieve the goals of the Commonwealth countries.
 
During his stay, the President will also attend the 92nd birthday celebration of Queen Elizabeth II.

hits._id: Number of local councillors likely to be reduced by 4,000

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says as a responsible Head of State he would not allow the government to be weakened for any reason.
The President said this while addressing the heads of media institutions at the President’s House in Colombo this morning (Apr. 06).
He also said that a complete Cabinet reshuffle including changing the institutions coming under the Ministries will be made soon.
President Sirisena said that a committee would be appointed with the members of both parties to come up with suggestions before the Cabinet reshuffle.
He also said that the Local government election Act should be amended as soon as possible.
He pointed out that having over 8,000 councillors is not a proper situation for a country like Sri Lanka and added that the number needed to be reduced by half.
The President also rejected certain reports on the tax amendments came into effect earlier this week.

hits._id: UN High Commissioner of Human Rights commences his official tour

_source.content:
UN High Commissioner of Human Rights, Zeid Ra’ad Al Hussein, arrives in Sri Lanka for his four day official tour.
Our correspondent said his flight arrived in Katunayake at 8.25pm. Zeid Ra’ad and six others who accompanied him was greeted by officials of the External Affairs Ministry.
During his visit Zeid Ra’ad will have discussions with President Maithripala Sirisena, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, Minister of External Affairs and other heads of the state.
"Substantive discussions during the visit will include measures to strengthen, promote and protect human rights, as well as steps being taken to implement the provisions of Resolution 30/1 titled 'Promoting reconciliation, accountability and human rights in Sri Lanka' which was adopted by the Human Rights Council on October 1 with the co-sponsorship of Sri Lanka,” stated a press release by the Ministry of External Affairs.
The High Commissioner will also visit Jaffna, Trincomalee and Kandy during his stay here.

hits._id: Mahinda Deshapriya writes to President and PM on PC elections

_source.content:
The Chairman of the Elections Commission Mahinda Deshapriya has written to President Maithripala Sirisena, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and Speaker Karu Jayasuriya requesting them to take steps to conduct the Provincial Council elections as early as possible.
 
Deshapriya has also sent those letter to party leaders as well.
 
Already the tenures of Sabaragamuwa, North Central, and Eastern Provincial Councils have elapsed and the elections are yet to be held.
 
The tenure of North Western, Central, Northern and Southern PCs will end this year and the term of the Uva, and Western PCs will end next year.
 
A spokesperson from the Elections Commission said that the Provincial Council election system is being changed and it would force to postpone the PC elections further.

hits._id: Make the UNP win to take the government’s money to UVA; A request from opposition leader.

_source.content: Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe requests that the UNP be made victorious if it is necessary to have Government funds set apart for Uuva Paranagama development.  Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe toured Haputale yesterday in view of the election.Expressing his views while participating in a people’s meeting held at Damba-thaenna in Haputale, Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe said further that it was possible to obtain funds from the Central Government for the Uuva Provincial Council if the UNP was voted.

hits._id: Video : We must Make SL the knowledge hub : President

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that commitment should be made to take the country towards the knowledge hub making use of education’s past heritage and the progress Government has made in the education sector.The President said so while participating at a convocation held at BMICH in Colombo yesterday.On this occasion the President pointed out further that during the recent past the Government had taken several vital policy decisions   for the betterment of the education sector.Meanwhile the new Sports Ministry building constructed at a cost of Rs. 400 million at the Colombo Race Course was also declared open last afternoon under the patronage of President Mahinda Rajapaksa.A decision has been taken  for all family health officers to refrain from field duties from today.

hits._id: Premier addresses Japanese Parliament today.

_source.content:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe, who is on an official visit to Japan, will address the Japanese Parliament today. 
Only two state leaders have been given an opportunity to address the Japanese Parliament in its history.
The two leaders are Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and US President Barak Obama.
Meanwhile, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has proposed to establish an active group comprising high ranking Ministers and Officials to further strengthen the relationship with Sri Lanka. 
The Japanese Prime Minister had echoed these sentiments when he met with visiting Sri Lankan Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe on the sidelines of the Science and Technology Summit in Kyoto yesterday.
The two leaders have decided to appoint a working committee to upgrade bilateral relations between Japan and Sri Lanka.
The committee will comprise top level ministers and officials from both countries.
The Prime Minister will hold discussions with Sri Lanka Business Cooperation Committee and Japanese Trade Organizations.
He is also expected to hold another round of discussions with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe tomorrow and call upon Emperor Akihito.Prime Minister Wickremasinghe will sign several bilateral agreements with Japan.

hits._id: President Sirisena visits Pakistan

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena will undertake a 3-day visit to Pakistan beginning from today (Mar. 22), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
 
He has been invited by the President of Pakistan Mamnoon Hussain to attend the National Day of Pakistan.
 
President Sirisena will hold discussions with his Pakistani counterpart President Hussain, Prime Minister Shahid Khaqan Abbasi during his stay in Pakistan.
Several agreements will also be signed during this visit. 
During his visit, President Sirisena will declare open the re-furbished International Buddhist Centre in the diplomatic enclave in Islamabad.

hits._id: New Ministers for 9 Cabinet and state Ministries; Mangala appointed Minister of Finance and media; Ravi to oversee Foreign Ministry; New Minister for Ports; And Maarapana returns to the cabinet

_source.content:
Nine Cabinet Ministers and one State minister took oaths before the President in their new portfolios this morning under the first Cabinet reshuffle of the Unity Government.
Accordingly, former Foreign Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera was sworn in as the new Finance Minister while former Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake was sworn in as the new Foreign affairs Minister at the Presidential Secretariat.
Former minister of Skills Development and Vocation Training Mahinda Samarasinghe has been appointed as the new minister of Ports and Shipping replacing minister Arjuna Ranatunga who has been appointed minister of Petroleum Resources Development.
Former minister of  Petroleum Resources Development chandima weerakody will now oversee the ministry of Skills Development and Vocation Training.
Thilak Maarapana who resigned from the ministry of Law and Order and Prison Reforms following the controversial Avant Garde incident in 2015 has been appointed as the minister of Development Affairs.
At the same time, former Minister of Mass Meida  Gayantha Karunathilaka was sworn in as the minister of Land and Parliamentary Affairs.
Meanwhile, Mahinda Amaraweera has been appointed the state minister of Mahaweli Development in addition to his current Fisheries Ministry portfolio.President Sirisena functions as the Cabinet Minister of Mahaweli Development.
In addition to overseeing the Social Empowerment Ministry, S.B. Dissanayake has been appointed as the Up country Development Affairs Minister.
W.D.J. Senevirathna has been appointed minister of Sabaragamu Development in addition to his current portfolio as minister of Labour and Trade Union Relations.

hits._id: Government to Prioritize Resettlement of IDP's - President

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena said the government gives priority to the resettlement process for the displaced persons in the North and the East and stressed the need to provide solutions to the matters regarding resettlement.At a special discussion held yesterday at the Presidential Secretariat, the president spoke on the Northern and Eastern resettlement program.He instructed that the relevant officials give priority to practical issues pertaining to the process.Meeting with the relevant ministers and government officials, the president gave instructions to schedule a meeting with the Resettlement Committee.This committee would comprise of the Governors of Northern and Eastern provinces.The meeting will take place within the next two weeks and will focus on matters pertaining to each area.

hits._id: President Maithripala Meets German Chancellor

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena met German Chancellor Angela Merkel a short while ago.
President Sirisena left for Germany on February 15 for a two-day state visit.
The aim of the visit is to further strengthen the economic and trade cooperation with Germany; the economically powerful member state of the European Union.
During the two-day visit the President was scheduled to have discussions with the German Chancellor Angela Merkel,German Minister of Foreign Affairs, German Minister of Economic Affairs and some representatives of the German Parliament.

_source.content: Chief Government Whip Minister Dinesh Gunawardena stated that a report will be prepared including details of the MPs who voted for and against the gazette notifications issued under the Strategic Development Act during the vote taking.This report will be presented to President Mahinda Rajapaksa and the General Secretary of the UPFA.Ministers Dilan Perera, Wimal Weerawansa, Rauf Hakeem, A L M Athaulla, Rishad Badiudeen, Rajitha Senarathna and Gamini Lokuge, as well as Deputy Ministers Muththu Shivalingam, Weerakumara Dissanayake were absent at the time of voting.A spokesperson at the government party office at parliament stated that 46 Ministers and MP’s of the government were absent at the time of voting on the 1st gazette paper.Update : Saturday, 26 April 2014 - 13:09------------------------------------------------Several Ministers including Dilan, Wimal, Hakeem, Rishad and Rajitha absent at the time of voting for 2nd and 3rd gazette papersSeveral government Ministers were absent from the chambers at the time the 2nd and 3rd gazette papers under the strategic development act were taken up for voting yesterday.Ministers Dilan Perera, Wimal Weerawansa, Rauf Hakeem, A L M Athaulla, Rishad Badiudeen, Rajitha Senarathna and Gamini Lokuge, as well as Deputy Ministers Muththu Shivalingam, Weerakumara Dissanayake were absent at the time of voting.Meanwhile, Minister Patali Champika Ranawaka voted against the 2nd and 3rd gazette papers along with UPFA MP Ven Athuraliye Rathana Thera.A spokesperson at the government party office at parliament stated that 46 Ministers and MP’s of the government were absent at the time of voting.

hits._id: Defence Secretary voices about the reports on granting military protection to former President

_source.content: Defence Secretary Karunasena Hettiarachchi says that he is not aware of the reports spreading with regard to granting military protection to former President Mahinda Rajapaksa under the instructions of President Maithripala Sirisena. hits._id: Lotus Tower becomes the next Hot Topic

_source.content: The Lotus Tower or Nelum Kuluna will turn out to become the next burning topic with regard to projects started by the previous regime with Ports, Shipping and Aviation Minister Arjuna Ranatunga promising to discuss the project with the President Maithripala Sirisena and the Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe.  While on a visit to the Port City Project, the Minister stated the tower was being built on land owned by the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) and that there were no legal documents to verify that land had been taken for the project.   “The former SLPA chairman and the then subject minister should be responsible for this discrepancy. This is not just anybody’s land. It is SLPA land and there is a procedure that must be followed,” the minister said.He said the land belonging to the Sri Lanka Ports Authority (SLPA) had been provided under the guise of carrying out a development project but there were no development projects being built on this land.“We will ensure that lands belonging to the SLPA will remain with the Authority and the income generated through projects on these lands or by the SLPA will be for the Authority,” he emphasized.

The National Election Commission's chief believes that the Commission would receive the new Act from the Speaker by 15th of September and they would need at least 75 days to finalize the election related work.

hits._id: President leaves for India

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has left for India this morning(Mar. 10) and later scheduled to visit Japan from 12th of March to 17th of March.
At the joint invitation of Indian Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi  and  French President Emanuel Macron,  President Sirisena will undertake an official visit to India  from 10-11 March 2018  to participate at  the First Conference of the International  Solar Alliance Founding Members, which will be convened on 11th of March, in New Delhi, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
 
Over thirty-two Heads of Government and high-level delegates are scheduled to attend the ISA Conference. Sri Lanka became a founding member of the International Solar Alliance on 12th of February 2018.
 
The major objective of the International Solar Alliance is to enable better harnessing of solar energy as an alternative energy source and to address the specific solar technology deployment needs, of solar resource-rich countries, located between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn. 
 
The ISA, by this initiative, further aims to address the gaps in the solar energy manufacturing eco-system and to ensure universal energy access, energy equity, and affordability that are common issues facing most of the solar resource-rich countries.
 
The Government of Sri Lanka joined the ISA in keeping with its policy declaration to prepare the groundwork for the country to fulfil the basic energy requirements of the people through renewable energy sources. 
Meanwhile, after the conclusion of the visit to India, at the invitation of the Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, President Maithripala Sirisena will undertake a State visit to Japan from 12 to 17 March 2018.
During his stay in Japan, President Sirisena is scheduled to have an Imperial Audience with His Majesty, Emperor Akihito on 13th of March, and on the next day, he will meet Prime Minister Abe for summit talks. 
 
Following talks, the Japanese Premier will host the Sri Lankan President to a State dinner. 
 
The two leaders will discuss matters of mutual interest to deepen cooperation between Sri Lanka and Japan.
 
A Yen Loan Agreement between the Government of Sri Lanka and the Japan International Cooperation Agency is to be signed during the visit for implementing the Health and Medical Service Improvement Project.
 
President Sirisena will attend a business meeting organized by the Japan External Trade Organization, which will be co-hosted by the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Tokyo Chamber of Commerce and Industry. During the State visit, the President will also meet with the Sri Lankan community in Japan.

hits._id: His holiness the POPE blesses those serving the people in Sri lanka.

_source.content: His Holiness Pope Francis called on President Maithripala Sirisena at the Presidential Secretariat last evening, where bilateral discussions were held between them with the sharing of good wishes.Later, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe joined the discussion with Pope Francis and President Sirisena.After this discussion, His Holiness and the President came to the hall which had a gathering of special invitees for the occasion, where the exchange of gifts between the Pope and the President took place.President Sirisena gifted the Pope with a “Ran Kendiya” a gilded ornamental jug with handle and spout, richly engraved in traditional designs, typical of such vessels used in the royal courts of ancient Sri Lanka.Pope Francis gifted President Maithripala Sirisena a copy of the Nautical Atlas attributed to Bartolome Oliva, drawn in 1562, which has 14 Nautical Maps in colour of Asia and Europe, including a very clear map of Sri Lanka at that time.

hits._id: Don’t blame government for scarcity of water – President makes a request from the farmers

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena made a request from the farmers in Polonnaruwa today, not to blame the government when they face a scarcity of water for cultivation. The President stated this while addressing the national ceremony of Aluth Sahal Mangalya held at Gal Vihara premises in Polonnaruwa today. The President also revealed that previously there were plans to supply water for the new season by 1st of April. However, as the farmers disagreed, the water will be supplied following the New Year festival.

hits._id: No Bridge To Connect India And Sri Lanka – Prime Minister

_source.content:
Building a bridge between India and Sri Lanka was shot down yesterday at Parliament. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremasinghe rejecting any bilateral discussion held during his recent visit to India rejected the possibilities for a bridge under the current Government.
PM responding to a question for oral answer raised by opposition MP Udaya Gammanpila said: “Lok Sabha publishes its Hansard in Hindi. I have not received a copy of it published in English. If any of the members knows Hindi, we could get this translated. Until such translation is done I am unable to comment on the matter. However, Minister Nitin Gadkari is very much building a bridge connecting the two nations. In the absence of any discussion at Government level I am unable to provide further information on the matter.”
However, MP Gammanpila bringing out Indian media challenged Prime Minister to show because why he should not take action against foreign media through diplomatic channels in Colombo. “I have reports published immediately after 16th December 2015 where Minister of Transport and Highways of India Nitin Gadkari addressed the Lok Sabha. In the even Indian Media misquoted the Sri Lankan Prime Minister, you should have taken action through the diplomats. Let us know your action taken. It is your fault for not having a single officer stationed in our High commission in Delhi with adequate knowledge on Hindi,” said MP Gammanpila.
In response, Prime Minister said: “We can only read out in this House what is published in English. Please translate it if you know Hindi. You are doing nothing but fuelling racism. During the Rajapaksha regime people who knew mandarin were assigned to UK and those who knew Islandic were found at our Embassy in Beijing. Foreign Service was destroyed during the last Government. If we follow your advice we may have to put language specialists in our embassies and High Commissions to cover Malayalam, Tamil, and other languages in India. I am sure that you only know to follow Malayalam Voodoo.”

hits._id: MC, UC, and PS amendments ratified by Speaker

hits._id: Foreign Minister Ravi resigns

_source.content:
Former Minister of Finance and current Minister of Foreign Affairs Ravi Karunanayake stated a few minutes before that he is officially resigning from his post.He made this announcement delivering a special statement in the parliament.Minister Ravi attended a special meeting with the President and the Prime Minister at the Presidents Secretariat Office yesterday.
In addition to our news team receiving confirmation of this meeting taking palace from State minister Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena, our correspondents personally witnessed minister Ravi Karunanayake, Rajitha Senaratne and Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe enter the premises of the Presidents secretariats office yesterday.
It was noted however that minister Karunanayake was not present at the cabinet meeting that was held at the president’s secretariats office yesterday morning.
Government ministers of the SLFP had met with the President and Premier earlier in the day, and had requested that Minister Ravi Karunanayake be asked to resign or have him removed from the post.
Meanwhile, with regard to the no confidence motion filed against minister Karunanayake, the date that the debate will take place, is to be decided at the party leaders meeting today.
Meanwhile, making a statement regarding the resignation of Minister Ravi Karunanayake, Opposition Leader R.Sambandhan stated that what minister Ravi did is a very good example of good governance to be followed by others.Moreover, Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe remarked that Minister Ravi had informed him regarding his decision before, yet officially discussed the matter with the president yesterday.

hits._id: Mahinda Rajapakse followers who accepted state and deputy ministry portfolios express their views.

It is significant that several SLFP MPs who worked closely with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa also received State and Deputy Ministry portfolios in the National Government yesterday.

Similarly T. B. Ekanayake who stood strongly for former President Mahinda Rajapaksa and even played a leading role in bringing him to Kurunegala too accepted a state minister post.
 In addition several MPs who had shown strong support towards the former president such as Dilan Perera, Sumedhaa Jayasena, Lakshman Wasantha Perera, Nishantha Mutuhettigama and Nimal Lansa also took their oaths as state and deputy ministers.
MP Nishantha Mutuhettigama who was sworn in as Harbour and Naval Affairs Deputy Minister also expressing his views after accepting his post of Deputy Minister stated that he will be partial to the former President in the future as well. He also mentioned that he will cooperate with the current party leader and work for its progress.

hits._id: Priyasad Depp takes oaths as new Chief Justice

_source.content: The most senior Supreme Court Judge Priyasad Depp was sworn-in as the 45th Chief Justice of Sri Lanka this morning. The oath taking was held before President Maithripala Sirisena at the presidents official residence this morning. The new Chief Justice functioned as the Government Solicitor General between 2007 and 2011. He served as a Supreme Court Judge until he was recommended for the new position by the Constitutional Council. Chief Justice Priyasad Depp is an old boy of St. Joseph College, Colombo.

hits._id: Mega irrigation project to provide water to North Western Province declared open by President

_source.content:
A mega irrigation project to provide water to North Western Province was declared open by President Maithripala Sirisena short while ago.
The government has initiated the d North Western Province Canal NWPC Project to provide water to the people in the Province who were suffering for a long time due to lack of water resources.
The project implemented in two stages will meet the irrigation and drinking water demands benefitting 80,000 families in 393 Grama Niladhari Divisions located in 5 Divisional Secretary Divisions.

hits._id: Fair development throughout the country

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena says that development is carried out in all districts in a fair manner.  He was speaking at a ceremony to recruit 1,000 graduates for teaching positions in schools of the North Central Provincial Council this morning. In addition, the president participated in another ceremony, ‘women in agriculture’ held in Anuradhapura this morning. Speaking further at the ceremony, the president said the prime duty of the government is to focus its economic building effort on innovative export development.

hits._id: Dullas Alahapperuma resigns from SLFP leadership position

_source.content:
Matara district SLFP leader Parliamentarian Dullas Alahapperuma said that he has decided to step down from the position.
Addressing a media conference held in Colombo this morning, Alahapperuma said he expects to tender his resignation to President Maithripala Sirisena in the course of time.
He further said that he took the decision in protest of removing party stalwarts from organizing positions.
He also expressed his views about the first year anniversary of the national government to be held in Matara today.

hits._id: South must work to gain national reconciliation- Prez

_source.content:
People in the South must have a better understanding about national reconciliation than those in the North, President Maithripala Sirisena said yesterday.
The president was visiting Thelippalei and Kopay in Jaffna, to hand over 701 acres of land to their original owners who lost the property during the war.
Addressing the gathering at the event the president added that several extremist groups are attacking the government with accuses and added that representatives of reconciliation must visit people in the South to educate them.

hits._id: 151st Birth Anniversary of Sir Anagarika Dharmapala

_source.content: The 151st Birth Anniversary of Sir Anagarika Dharmapala is celebrated today. The government has decided to hold the Anniversary celebration island-wide under the theme ‘Desa-Basa-Resa Surakina Sisu Parapurak’(A Student Generation Protective of the Country, its Language and the Nation). Also a week from today until the 20th has been named Sir Anagarika Dharmapala Week. The Presidential Media Division stated that President Maithripala Sirisena will preside in the main celebration held today at the Dharmapala College, Pannipitiya.

hits._id: Build a country which would ascertain the Sri Lankan identity despite race or creed: Says PM

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says that everybody born in this country, despite their race or creed, should be able to claim a country in which their Sri Lankan identity is attested.He stated this during a speech at a public rally held in Batticaloa yesterday.Meanwhile, former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says although the current government makes various allegations of robbery against him, none of them explained what he had stolen. He sated this at a public rally held in Wellawaya yesterday.

hits._id: US President Obama says Sri Lanka created a symbol of hope for world democracy

_source.content: US President Barack Obama praised Sri Lanka's successful and peaceful presidential elections and congratulated the outgoing administration on a swift and orderly transfer of power.President Obama said that beyond the significance of this election to Sri Lanka, it is also a symbol of hope for those who support democracy all around the world.Obama congratulated the incoming President Maithripala Sirisena on his victory.The US leader said that at this moment of hope, the United States looks forward to deepening its partnership with the people and government of Sri Lanka and to working with President Sirisena to advance peace, democracy, and prosperity for all Sri Lankans.

hits._id: National Anthem sung in Tamil

_source.content:
The National Anthem was sung in Tamil to mark the end of 68th Independence Day celebrations held at the Galle Face Green.  Meanwhile, former Minister Dilan Perera told the parliament last week that SLFP has no objection if the Anthem was sung in Tamil.
Main reason for Mahinda Rajapaksa government to collapse was racial actions, he said adding if a party member is against this move it is solely a personal opinion.

hits._id: UN Chief satisfied with progress made by the Gvt.- Prez

_source.content:
United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon expressed his appreciation over the progress made by the government and assured fullest cooperation and assistance to the government for carrying out these tasks, President Maithripala Sirisena said.
Addressing heads of media stations at his official house he said he had explained the steps taken to strengthen democracy through the 19th Amendment to the Constitution and the establishment of Constitutional Council and Commissions to the UN chief.
Speaking about the 65th Anniversary of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP), he said that all the party members are invited to attend the rally in Kurunegala on Sunday.
He added that any issues within the party can be sorted out through discussions.

hits._id: President urges trade unions to focus on National Goals

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena said the government will provide required financial provisions immediately to establish the Nursing Faculty to award Nursing Degrees, which has been a long term demand.
President held a meeting with the Government Nursing Officers Association yesterday at the Presidential Secretariat.
International Nurses Day is celebrated around the world on 12 May each year.  The meeting was held to coincide with the celebration, where nurses are acknowledged for the contribution they make to society.
The President also drew his attention into the matter that when the unions make demands they focus only on career needs.
He pointed out the importance for them to present new ideas and proposals through their unions to achieve national goals.

hits._id: America waters down resolution while signs portend of an agreement prior to Geneva resolution

_source.content:
While commending the Sri Lankan Government for the ‘physical’ reconciliation work in the North and resettlement of IDPs, UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillai said today that she remained concerned about the lack of ‘meaningful progress on accountability and reconciliation.’


			   
			   		
	
			   

The US State Department has said that the new resolution to be submitted by the United States during the ongoing UN Human Rights Council session in Geneva would be built on the 2012 resolution,

Patrick Ventrell, Acting Deputy Spokesperson of the US State Department said that the resolution will request of the Government of Sri Lanka to follow through on its own commitments to its people.


			   
			   		
	
			   

Moreover the Sri Lankan government has objected to the clearance given to hold an anti-government meeting at the British parliament premises last week.

An External Affairs Ministry spokesman said that the government had also raised objections with the British Foreign office after officials of the British government also attended the meeting.

Deputy British Prime Minister and Leader of the Liberal Democrats Nick Clegg, Senior Minister of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and former Conservative Party Chairman Baroness Warsi were among those attended the meeting organized by the Global Tamil Forum.

Meanwhile latest reports have revealed that the Government of Sri Lanka has taken a u-turn to adopt a non-confrontation stance against the West on the proposed US procedural resolution.

Also, the US is expected to water-down its resolution to encourage the countries domestic reconciliation and accountability.

When contacted a senior spokesperson for the Ministry of External Affairs Confirmed that that talks on several levels are currently underway with US officials on the sidelines of the United Nations Human Rights Council Sessions.

In related developments the Presidents Special Envoy on Human Rights Minister Mahinda Samarasinghe is said to have arrived in the island today.

On the 15th of next month Minister Samarasinghe is due to present the islands Universal Periodic Review before the UN Human Rights council while UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navaneethan Pillai is also expected to submit her report on the island to the council.

However the UN Human Rights Council has not yet officially confirmed that a American sponsored resolution would be moved against the island.

hits._id: Elections Commissioner issues circular to prevent transfers during Presidential election season

hits._id: Civil members of Constitutional Council to Parliament today

_source.content:
The first parliamentary meeting after the appointment of the national government’s cabinet takes place today.
Although the maiden meeting of the 8th Parliament after the General Election was held on the 1st of this month, and the Parliament met afterwards on 3rd this month, the national government’s cabinet had not been appointed by that time.
Today after parliament meets at 1.00 p.m. obtaining of approval for civil activists nominated for the Constitutional Council will take place first.
Dr. A. T. Ariyaratne, Dr. Radhika Kumaraswamy and former Attorney General Presidential Counsel Sibili Azees are the civil members nominated for the Constitution Council.
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe is scheduled to make a special statement in parliament today about the steps being taken at the UNHRC these days.
Meanwhile the JVP is due to present an adjournment proposal to the effect that political intervention in the recruitment of government officials must be prevented.

hits._id: President leaves for New York

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena left for New York today to attend the 70th United Nations General Assembly.
The President is scheduled to deliver his address at the Assembly on 30th September morning.
He is expected to enlighten the General Assembly on Sri Lanka’s stand on the reports released on alleged human rights violations.
The President will also attend the Economic Conference held on 27th September in New York. 
During his stay in the United States the President is scheduled to hold bilateral discussions with the American President Barack Obama and the Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull.
External Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera, Minister of Rehabilitation, Resettlement and Hindu Affairs D.M. Swaminathan, Minister of Justice and Buddha Sasana Wijeyadasa Rajapaksha and Minister of Skills Development and Vocational Training Mahinda Samarasinghe will be accompanying the President in this visit.
 
Update : Wednesday, 23 September 2015 - 11:24---------------------------------------------------------President departs to US today President Maitripala Sirisena is scheduled to depart for the US this forenoon for addressing the 70th UN General Assembly.
The President will address the conference on 30th of this month at 9. 45 a.m. New York time.
The President who will join in addressing the Economic Conference held on 27th of this month in New York and also scheduled to meet and hold discussions with several State Leaders including US President Barrack Obama.
Minister Mangala Samarasinghe, Dr. Wijedasa Rajapaksa, D. N. Swaminathan and Mahinda Samarasinghe too will join the President in this tour. Meanwhile state leaders of many countries in the world are heading for New York by now to participate in the 70th UN General Assembly. His Holiness, Pope Francis has already arrived in New York.

hits._id: "J.Packer was involved in local politics" - PM

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has defended the government’s decision to withdraw licence approval and millions of dollars in tax breaks for James Packer’s now-scrapped 450 million dollar Colombo Crown ­casino project, saying there was “nothing in it” for the country.Prime Minister Wickremesinghe, who began his third term in office last month after former president ­Mahinda Rajapaksa lost the election, also hinted that Packer’s cancelled casino licence was the subject of political favour.President Maithripala Sirisena, promised to scrap three controversial casino ­licences, including Packer’s Lake Leisure joint venture, during the election campaign in which it highlighted widespread corruption and crony capitalism within the former regime.Prime Minister said Packer decided to go ahead despite wide opposition because he felt his friendship with the Rajapaksa regime was sufficient and the Rajapaksa regime would be there forever.

Athaullah’s National Congress.

H. Mahmood Ali said that Bangladesh will not hesitate to provide all possible assistance to help to Sri Lanka, as the two countries have “ an extremely cordial relationship,"The Foreign Minister further expressing his views said that President Sirisena's visit to Bangladesh is an important milestone in the long-standing friendship between the two countries.The President expressed gratitude to the Government of Bangladesh for the warm welcome extended by him to the Sri Lankan delegation.He also said that Bangladesh has always a true friend to Sri Lanka and with gratitude recalled the assistance given by the Government of Bangladesh during the recent flood disaster,  as well as during the conflict in the past.

hits._id: Indian Fishermen Will Not Be Allowed To Enter Into Sri Lankan Sea

_source.content:
Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says government will never give permission to Indian fishermen to engage in fishing activities in the Sri Lankan waters.
He totally rejects some allegations that the government would allow Indian fishermen to enter into Sri Lanka seas.
Although various parties from time to time have expressed multiple views regarding this matter the ministry of fisheries has not conducted a single discussion in this connection. The minister therefore requests the public not to be panicked by false information spread by various elements.
The ministry will consider the views of the fisher societies before taking any decision pertaining to fishing industry in Sri Lanka.
The Minister further said that Sri Lanka Navy and the Coastal Guards are ready to arrest the Indian fishermen who violate the Sri Lankan sea territory.

hits._id: President arrives in Malaysia

President Maithripala Sirisena landed in Malaysia just a short while ago for a 3 day official visit.
Over the next 3 days President Sirisena will sign several Memorandums of Understanding with Malaysia on cooperation in tourism, in the field of training, research, public administration, culture, arts and heritage and in the field of youth development.

hits._id: Update : 19th - A is in line with Constitution

_source.content: Supreme Court (SC) informs that the 19th Amendment is in line with the constitution and certain sections require a referendum.Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe stated that, he is ready to remove those sections. Update : Thursday, 09 April 2015 - 13:49---------------------------------------------------Political party leader meeting begins to discuss about 19th amendment debateA special political party leaders’ meeting is currently being held to decide whether the debate with regard to the 19th Constitutional Amendment is held today in parliament.The discussion commenced under the patronage of Speaker Chamal Rajapaksa at 10 o’clock this morning.Today and tomorrow have been already reserved for the debate on the 19th Amendment in the parliament order book.The proposed 19th Amendment Draft Bill was presented to parliament by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe on March 24th.Later 19 petitions, 5 for the new Amendment and 14 against it were filed with the Supreme Court.A panel of 3 Supreme Court Judges including Chief Justice K. Sri Pavan, Supreme Court Judge Chandra Ekanayake and Supreme Court Judge Priyasad Depp considered the petitions last Wednesday.However MEP leader and former minister Dinesh Gunawardana said in parliament yesterday the Supreme Court has not informed its opinion to the Speaker as yet.Update : Thursday, 09 April 2015 - 13:46----------------------------------------------Party leaders convened to discuss on 19th amendmentA special party leaders’ meeting has been called for this morning to decide whether  the 19th amendment  would be debated in parliament today.  A senior parliamentary spokesman told our news team that arrangements have been made to hold this party leaders’ meeting at about 10 this morning.The senior spokesman said further that a final decision with regard to this would be taken at this meeting.The hearing of petitions submitted to the Supreme Court with regard to the draft 19th constitutional amendment act was concluded on 5th this month.Accordingly the three-member bench of Supreme Court Judges including Chief Justice K. Sripavan had announced that relevant decision would be communicated to the President and the Speaker.Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe presented the proposed draft 19th constitutional amendment act on 24th last March.Nineteen petitions had been filed before the Supreme Court with regard to the draft act.Out of these five had been filed in favour of the draft act while 14 were against it.Hearing of these petitions before Supreme Court Judges Chief Justice K. Sripavan, Chandraa Ekanayake and Priyasaad Dep had begun last Wednesday.Meanwhile holding the debate on the draft 19th constitutional amendment act today and tomorrow has been entered on parliamentary agenda book.However MEP leader and former Minister Dinesh Gunawardhana said in parliament yesterday the Supreme Court view with regard to the 19th constitutional amendment had so far not been conveyed to the Speaker.

hits._id: Thai Pongal celebrated today

_source.content:
The Tamil community across the world is celebrating Thai Pongal today(Jan.14).
It is the harvest festival dedicated to the Sun God.
President Maithripala Sirisena, issuing a message in view of the Thai Pongal festival said that he would like to consider the Thai Pongal festival, which has bestowed the supreme status upon agriculture, as an occasion to make the efforts taken by the government to take the country towards self-sufficiency in food and providing strength to the efforts.
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe in his Thai Pongal message said that the agrarian society possesses a deep reverence for the Sun God that goes back to centuries.
The Premier also said that all Tamils celebrating around the world join hands with all Sri Lankans in a poignant message of goodwill among all.
Meanwhile, Opposition Leader R. Sampanthan said that his prayer was at this year's special occasion that we would find a reasonable, lasting political solution to the unresolved national question through the new constitution.

hits._id: "No Conflict Within The Unity Government": Says UNP & SLFP

_source.content:
General Secretaries of the United National Party (UNP) and the Sri Lanka Freedom Party (SLFP) say there is no conflict within the Unity government.
Speaking at a media briefing held at the Parliamentary Complex a short while ago, General Secretary of the UNP Minister Kabir Hashim said the party has a close relationship with President Maithripala Sirisena who is the Chairman of the SLFP and General Secretary Duminda Dissanayake.
Minister Hashim said the understanding and trust between the two parties is more important than the Memorandum of Understanding signed by the UNP and the SLFP.
Minister Kabir Hashim said the government was able to work in unity due to the trust established at the beginning. The UNP General Secretary said successful discussions were held to resolve certain issues as there were disagreements between the two parties on certain matters.
The Minister said although certain parties attempt to create problems within the UNP, the party does not resort to such actions.
General Secretary of the SLFP Duminda Dissanayake meanwhile said the individual responsible for creating a new force accepted responsibility on national television over Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s defeat at the 2015 Presidential election.

hits._id: Bandula Gunawardena says 'will support' President's anti-corruption moves

_source.content: Joint Opposition has requested President Maithripala Sirisena to immediately take legal action against those who were involved in the bond scam, regardless of their status.They are urging the President not to worry about the threats. Speaking at a press briefing held at the Parliament Complex today (25), MP Gunawardena said that the Joint Opposition is willing to extend its fullest cooperation to the president in this regard.

hits._id: Minister Sagala makes a statement on bus explosion

_source.content: The explosion which took place on a bus in Kahagolla in Diyathalawa was discussed in Parliament today (Feb. 21).The group leader of Joint Opposition Dinesh Gunawardena said that the government should reveal the factual information with regard to this incident.Then Minister Sagala Ratnayake and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe responded.The PM said that the initial investigations have been completed and according to that the explosion was caused by a hand grenade.He said it has been placed inside a bag of a commuter who was travelling from Bandarawela.Minister Sagala Ratnayake meanwhile said that the Government Analyst is conducting an investigation into the incident.He said the fire was caused by a grenade explosion and more details could be disclosed after the probe is complete.

hits._id: Ministerial subcommittee to initiate WHO recommendations regarding kidney disease

_source.content:
An inter ministry sub committee has been appointed to initiate the recommendations of the World Health Organization regarding the unidentified kidney disease that has been reported in several areas of the Island.

The sub committee appointed by the ministerial panel includes representatives from the health, agriculture, water supply and drainage, environment, local government and provincial council ministries.

However, minister of health Maithreepala Sirisena stated that the government has decided to initiate the recommendations stated in the final report issued by the WHO.

The minister made this statement while taking part in the national function held in Kegalle in lieu of the Tuberculosis prevention day scheduled to be commemorated day after tomorrow.

hits._id: UPFA controlled Imbulpe PS budget defeated for the 2nd time - Govt member runs away with the Chairman's documents

_source.content: The UPFA controlled Imbulpe Pradeshiya Sabha budget for next year was defeated for the second time with 4 majority votes today.Deputy Chairman and another 5 UPFA members joined their UNP counterparts to vote against the budget while Chairman Indu Gunatilaka and one UPFA member voted for the budget.UPFA member Indika Rohana Jayamanne who voted for the budget on the previous occasion has grabbed a file document from the Chairman’s table and run away in protest of not taking one of his proposals for discussion.Opposition Leader Anton Coorey abstained from participating in the vote taking this time.The next year’s budget of Mawanella Pradeshiya Sabha was passed unanimously today.There are 13 UPFA councilors and 9 UNP councilors at the pradeshiya sabha controlled by UPFA.The budgets of about 16 UPFA controlled local government institutes have been defeated by now.

hits._id: SL and India to release arrested fishermen

Sri Lanka and India have decided to release 123 fishermen who are in each other’s custody.
Accordingly, 85 Indian fishermen in Sri Lanka and 19 Sri Lankan fishermen in India will be released Fisheries Ministry stated.
A discussion regarding this was held between Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and Fisheries Minister Mahinda Amaraweera today.

hits._id: Special security for Sri Lankan President participating at Modi's swearing in ceremony

_source.content: Indian Media reported that President Mahinda Rajapaksa will hold bilateral talks with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi after participating at the latter’s swearing in ceremony.The meeting is scheduled to take place at 6PM at Rashtrapathi Bhavan.External Affairs Minister Professor G L Peiris, President’s Secretary Lalith Weerathunga, Minister Arumugam Thondaman, Monitoring MP of the External Affairs Ministry Sajin Vass Gunawardana and Secretary to the Ministry Kshenuka Senevirathna will accompany the President.Meanwhile, the government has decided to release all Indian fishermen in Sri Lankan custody as a sign of goodwill in view of the swearing in of Indian Prime Minister elect Narendra Modi.The Ministry of External Affairs stated that instructions were received from President Mahinda Rajapaksa.President Mahinda Rajapaksa is also expected to meet with Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sheriff and Maldivian President Abdulla Yameen.6,000 security personnel will cover a two-km periphery around the Indian presidential palace.Indian Police will throw in a higher weight on the security of Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, Sri Lankan President Mahinda Rajapaksa and Afghan President Hamid Karzai.

hits._id: Bond report brings tension to Parliament, Kavinda faints

_source.content:
A tense situation was prevailed in Parliament this afternoon (Jan. 10) when Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe rose to make a special statement.
 
The Joint Opposition MP’s converged into the Well of the House and started to protest.
 
The JO members Mahindananda Aluthgamage, Ranjith Zoysa, Gamini Lokuge, Sisira Jayakody, Pavithra Wanniarachchi and government MP's Kavinda Jayawardena, Nalin Bandara, Hector Appuhami and Chaminda Wijesiri were among them.
 
Then the Speaker, Karu Jayasuriya adjourned the sessions for 10 minutes for a party leaders’ meeting.
 
Thereafter, Deputy Minister Lasantha Alagiyawanna said that the Bond report will be tabled on 17th of this month.
 
Thereafter, the Prime Minister made his special statement in which he explained the steps taken by the government to probe the Central Bank bond controversy after details emerged.
 
However, the Speaker adjourned the Parliament until 23rd of this month.
 
Meanwhile, it was reported that MP Kavinda Jayawardena fainted and collapsed inside the chamber.
 
He was taken to the medical center of the Parliament and doctors have told he may have fainted as he had not taken his breakfast.
 
Meanwhile, his staff said that there is no truth in the rumour that the MP was hospitalized.

hits._id: Special circular on Uva elections from elections commissioner to government officials

_source.content: A special circular has been issued by the elections commissioner Mahinda Deshapriya regarding the Uva provincial council elections.The circular has been issued to all ministry secretaries, district secretaries, department heads, and chairmen of government corporations as well as chairmen of constitutional councils.The circular which has been issued on the 16th of this month requests not to use government property including vehicles for election propaganda activities, during the Uva provincial council elections.It further notes not to promote or transfer government officials during this time period.Through the circular the elections commissioner has also notified to suspend ordinary transfers of all government officials including teachers and principals who will be on election duty, in the provincial council areas where elections will be held.The suspension is in effect from the 16th of this month to 2 weeks following the conclusion of the polls.The elections commissioner has further informed government officials to postpone any special projects due to be launched during the election time period.

hits._id: President to intervene in VAT changes

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has called a discussion regarding the recently introduced VAT concessions.
Officials at the Finance Ministry and businessmen are taking part in this meeting.
The VAT that remained at 11 per cent before was increased to 15 per cent on May 02.
The hike affected local businesses, and tradesmen in several areas protested against the government’s move.

hits._id: Petition to SC against excessive number of cabinet Ministers

_source.content:
A fundamental rights petition was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday challenging President Maithripala Sirisena’s decision to increase the number of cabinet ministers from 30 to 48.
The petition was filed by Attorney-at-Law Aruna Laksiri and he has cited President Sirisena and the Attorney General as respondents.
The petitioners stated that the national government must consist of the party who earned the maximum number of seats and other parties including independent groups according to the 19th amendment of the Constitution.
The petitioner points out that the current government which has been formed through the agreement of a mere few parties cannot be considered a national government.
Accordingly the petitioner claims that it is against the law to increase of number of cabinet Ministers above 30. On this ground the petitioner requested the Supreme Court to impose an interim ban to prevent the appointment of more than 30 ministers.

hits._id: President to India today

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena will leave for India today to participate in the BRICS Outreach Summit to be held in Goa, India.
The President Sirisena, as well as heads of State of the member countries of the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation also known as BIMSTEC will attend the BRICS Outreach Summit as an observer.
President Sirisena is also expected to hold bilateral discussions with several Heads of State on the sidelines of the BIMSTEC summit.
The President is expected to hold discussions with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Chinese President Xi Jinping and a host of other leaders.
BRICS is an international relations conference attended by the heads of state or heads of government of the five member states Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.

hits._id: EU Parliament team says reforms are slower than expected

_source.content: A delegation of the European Parliament is currently visiting Sri Lanka to review the progress on national reconciliation and its implementation of the international conventions applicable to GSP+ has expressed concern that the progress achieved has been slower than expected. The visit provides Members of the European Parliament (MEP) with an opportunity to witness the developments since their last official visit in 2016 and to discuss issues of common interest with the Sri Lankan authorities. The delegation visited the Northern Province on 1st November and met with the Governor and civil society representatives. They also visited an EU funded resettlement site and held discussions with some of those who have resettled. In Colombo, MEPs had the opportunity of meeting the Minister of Finance, the Minister of Development and International Trade and the Leader of the Opposition. They also met senior officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Environment, the Ministry of Labor and the Ministry for National Integration and Reconciliation. The delegation of the European Parliament welcomes a number of positive developments that have taken place since their last official visit, such as the decision to readmit Sri Lanka to its preferential trade program GSP+ and the lifting of the ban on Sri Lanka’s fisheries exports to the EU market. However, MEPs have underlined during their discussions that GSP+ was granted as an incentive for the reform process that the Government of Sri Lanka has embarked on. MEPs expressed concern that the progress achieved has been slower than originally hoped, but that the foundations for that progress were now mostly in place. The Chair encouraged the Government of Sri Lankan to pursue their deliberations on constitutional reform with a view to further strengthening the protection of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, and, of course, the process of national reconciliation.

hits._id: Agri Insurance free from Yala Season onwards

_source.content:
The government has decided to provide insurance schemes for paddy, potato, Bombay onions, corn, maize, soybean and green chilli crops, from the next Yala season.
Chairman of the Agriculture and Agrarian Insurance Board, Sydney Gajanayake said that 2.5 million farmers cultivating such crops will receive an insurance coverage amounting to Rs.40,000  per acre.  
The government has allocated Rs. 100 billion for this matter.
The insurance scheme was previously provided to farmers under the 2018 budget proposals and Rs. 642 was charged from each farmer for this scheme.
The government previously paid 82 percent of the insurance premium and has now decided to bear the total cost of the insurance premium.

hits._id: Ministers Who Assumed Duty Today

_source.content:
Few of the newly appointed government ministers assumed duties at their relevant ministries today.
Minister of Justice and Buddhist Affairs Wijedasa Rajapaksa assumed duty this morning at the Ministry of Justice. Speaking to the media he stated that he expects to establish a new constitution in the national government within the next two years.
W.D.J. Seneviratne, Minister of Labor and Trade Union Relations, assumed duty today at his ministry in Narahenpita.
Chandima Weerakkodi, Minister of Fuel and Petroleum Gases assumed duty today at his ministry in Colombo 7. Expressing his views to the media the minister said that he will take measures to build a new system for storage of crude oil.
Minister of Fisheries and Water Resources Mahinda Amaraweera said that he will take necessary steps to develop the technology used for fishing.   In addition to these, Minister of Megapolis and Western Development Patali Champika Ranawaka, Minister of Agriculture Duminda Dissanayake and Minister of National Dialogue Mano Ganeshan assumed duty today at their respective ministries.

_source.content: It was stated in a document tabled in parliament yesterday that security sources have identified that there is threat from extremists and radicals to the life of current president Maithripala Sirisena  and the lives of the two former presidents.This is mentioned in a document Public Peace and Christian Affairs Minister tabled in response to a query an MP raised for an oral reply.  It was stated in the document that 138 police personnel had been deployed for the security of former President Chandrika Kumaratunga at the time of her retirement and that this number had been currently reduced to 66.The document said that 102 police personnel had been deployed for the security of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa at the time of retirement and that today this number had been increased to 105.

hits._id: Scores of state leaders including Chinese President congratulate new President Maithreepala.

_source.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping extended his wishes to new President Maithreepala Sirisena.In his message of congratulations, he stated that Sri Lanka is a trusted ally and partner of China, and that he is looking forward to strengthen the bilateral strategic cooperation.Scores of state leaders including United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon extended their wishes today.Elaborating further, UN Secretary General wished the Sri Lankans for the successful conclusion of the country’s presidential election, and welcomed the constitutional transfer of power.Moreover, US President Barack Obama, British Prime Minister David Cameron, Singapore President Tony Tan and their Prime Minister Lee Hsieng Loong, Indian Congress party leader Sonia Gandhi as well as the European Union, and the Japanese government congratulated the new President.Meanwhile, Indian news paper The Hindu stated in their Editorial that they expect India – Sri Lanka ties to be further strengthened under Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe’s purview.The Hindu referred to the new Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe as a politician with close ties to India.The new Prime Minister too received messages of congratulations from several countries including India.

hits._id: An election should be held after fulfilling the given promises - says cabinet spokesman Minister Rajitha

_source.content: The Cabinet Spokesman Minister Rajitha Senaratna said that the government should face an election only after fulfilling the promises given to the people.Addressing a media conference to inform Cabinet decisions held at the Department of Information today, Minister Senarathna said that the draft bill to amend the constitution including the change of electoral system would be presented to that parliament next March.Minister Rajitha Senaratne stated that he’ll be at a disadvantage if the electoral system was changed, since the seat is more favourable to the UNP.He added that what’s important to the people is not the election, but fulfilling the pledges made by the government.The parliament can remain for 2 years following an election.He also said that people will not complain for exceeding the 100 days, if the government can change the presidential system, the parliament system and appoint relevant independent commissions.Meanwhile, journalists questioned the Cabinet Spokesman about the allegations made by former Minister Wimal Weerawansa, stating that his wife was arrested on political vengeance.In response, Minister Rajitha stated that the passport is similar to the identity card and that they have made changes to the ages entered in the birth certificates of their first two children.Minister further said that she has presented 2 passports and 2 identity cards to obtain loans among other benefits.Meanwhile, the Cabinet has approved the recent Interim Budget proposal to increase the Samurdhi allowance by 200%.At the same time, Cabinet approval has been given to appoint a special committee to inquire into the complaints regarding post election violence.The committee comprised of experts in the field of law, administration, finance and investigation will present their report to the Cabinet within 60 days.In addition, the Cabinet approval was given for printing text books for the next year to state institutions including Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Limited, State Printing Corporation and the Government Printer’s Department.

hits._id: Progress review meeting of Mahaweli Ministry held

_source.content:
Progress review meeting of the Ministry of Mahaweli Development and Environment was held under the patronage of the President Maithripala Sirisena today (Feb. 21).
 
A detailed discussion was held on special development plans conducted under Ministry of Mahaweli Development.
 
President Sirisena stressed the importance of improving the efficiency and regularizing the projects to provide benefits to the Mahaweli farmer community.
 
The President also emphasized the importance of conducting proper studies on possible dry weather conditions in the future and plan management of water levels of reservoirs accordingly and inform the farmers to manage their cultivations in the future on the basis of such forecasts.
 
He instructed the officials to launch such awareness campaigns through farmer organizations.
