hits._id: 56 technical errors noted in delimitation report- Min. Faizer Mustapha

_source.content:
Minister of Provincial Councils and Local Government Faizer Mustapha says that there are 56 technical errors in the delimitations report.
A special discussion was held regarding the local government elections yesterday in parliament under the patronage of the prime minister.
Representatives of the main political parties, UNP, SLFP, UPFA, TNA, JVP, Sri Lanka Muslim Congress and National People’s Congress participated in the discussion.
The lengthy discussion had been held with regard to issues regarding the local government elections.
Following the handover of the delimitations committee report, the report will be published in the gazette in accordance with the local government elections act.
Accordingly, a party leaders meeting will be held on the 23rd of January.

hits._id: Homagama budget defeated for the 2nd time - Tense situation in Uhana Pradeshiya Sabha

_source.content: A tense situation reigned in several local government institutions during the vote taking in the last several days.The Uhana Pradeshiya Sabha was also tensed this morning after its chairman postponed the meeting and left the chambers.Uhana Pradeshiya Sabha budget was defeated with 5 majority votes during its first vote taking a few days ago.Accordingly, the second vote taking was scheduled for today, and the chairman had informed the members to be present at 9am to start the meeting.Opposition members claimed that although they came in time, the chairman did not attend the meeting, and later, an acting chairman was appointed to precede the meeting.Uhana Pradeshiya Sabha UNP member H.U. Susantha said that the chairman came late, postponed the meeting and went away.Our news team attempted to contact UPFA Uhana Pradeshiya Sabha Chairman Ranjith Ekanayake to comment on the charges but his mobile phone was out of service.Meanwhile UPFA controlled Dompe Pradeshiya Sabha budget which lost at the previous time was passed unanimously today.When our news team contacted Dompe Pradeshiya Sabha Opposition Leader Udaya Kumara Jayawardana to comment on the budget, he said that the decision was taken for the benefit of the residents in the area.Although there are 22 members including 13 UPFA, 8 UNP and One JVP member in the Dompe Pradeshiya Sabha, there were only 8 UPFA and one UNP member present during the vote taking.However  Dompe Pradeshiya Sabha Opposition Leader Udaya Kumara Jayewardene said that all UNP members had decided to vote for the budget today.Meanwhile Homagama Pradeshiya Sabha budget was defeated with 2 majority votes during the second vote taking today.Ten members voted for the budget while 12 members voted against it when it was presented for the second time. One UPFA member abstained from voting while 9 of his fellow members and the Deputy Chairman joined their opposition counterparts to vote against the budget.Meanwhile Matara Pradeshiya Sabha was presided today by acting Chairman Lasantha Sanjeewa as its Chairman lost his position after the budget for next year was defeated twice.

hits._id: Jobs to Magampura harbour employees in a Rajapaksa government

Former President and current MP Mahinda Rajapaksa said that steps will be taken to provide jobs to employees taking part in the Magampura harbour sathyakgraha under his government.
He said so while expressing his views to media after a discussion held with representatives from the Matara District local government yesterday.

hits._id: Hospital activities disrupted due to GMOA strike

_source.content:
Daily activities of government hospitals around the country have been disrupted due to the token strike launched by GMOA and Medical Services United Front this morning.
GMOA started the strike from 8am today stating the state service and free health service are influenced by Budget proposals. 
The strike will continue until 8.00 am tomorrow.
GMOA media spokesman Dr. Samantha Ananda stated that the strike will not be held at Lady Ridgeway Children’s hospital, De Soyza women’s hospital, Maharagama Cancer hospital and Kidney Treatment units.
Our correspondents stated that many patients who sought treatment at government hospitals throughout the country were inconvenienced due to the strike. 
They stated that emergency activities were carried out however.
Meanwhile, eight supplementary medical workers including Public Health Inspectors have joined the strike.

The proceedings in Parliament commenced at 2.15 pm.

hits._id: A single person cannot topple a Gvt.- Prez

_source.content:
President Maitripala Sirisena says that a single person cannot change governments and to change a government a people’s view should be created in the country against the prevalent government.
The President said so while participating at the opening of the Sri Jayewardenepura Kotte Electorate main SLFP office yesterday.  
Meanwhile President Maitripala Sirisena said that the main requirement that should be fulfilled in the development sector was electricity.
Participating at the programme in Colombo yesterday for introducing Solar Power to one million houses the President pointed out that excessive electricity bill was the reason for him not residing at Presidential House

hits._id: Authority on Private degrees returned to professional bodies - SB's gazette notification cancelled on Presidents directives.

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa directed the Higher Education Ministry to immediately cancel the gazette notification which empowered to establish private institutes to offer academic degrees without essentially obtaining endorsement from relevant professional bodies.Higher Education Deputy Minister Nandimitra Ekanayake said that a new gazette notification canceling the previous one will be issued in the cause of time.Earlier it was made mandatory to obtain an endorsement letter from the relevant boards before setting up of a private institute to offer degrees of Medical Science, Engineering, Architecture and several other professions.However a special gazette notification was issued empowering private degrees to be offered without the endorsement, and Sri Lanka Medical Council, Sri Lanka Engineering Institute, Government Medical Officers Association and Federation of University Teachers Association objected the Higher Education Ministry gazette notification.

hits._id: Update: Fonseka reinstated with Civic rights, medals & General title

_source.content: The voting rights and the ranks, medals and other privileges including the pension have been restored for former Army Commander General Sarath Fonseka.The Election Commissioner Mahinda Deshapriya said the decision to restore voting rights for General Fonseka was taken in compliance with the Presidential pardon given to General Sarath Fonseka by President Maithreepala Sirisena recently.The Election Commissioner said that according to the provisions in the Constitution, General Fonseka would be able to enter his name to the voter registration list in the future.At the same time, a senior officer attached to the Election Secretariat said that authorities are considering whether General Fonseka could be reinstated in his parliament seat if General Fonseka’s successor Jayantha Ketagoda resigns from parliament.    Meanwhile the Defence Ministry has returned his ranks, medals and other privileges including his pension which he had been stripped during the previous regime.Update: Wednesday, 28 January 2015 - 15:14.......................................................................Fonseka reinstated with Civic rights & General titleFormer Chief of Defense Staff Sarath Fonseka has been reinstated as a General with immediate effect.Medals that were awarded to Sarath Fonseka earlier, including Rana Wickrama medal, awarded for exceptional service to the Sri Lanka Army will also be returned.The Election Commissioner announced that General Sarath Fonseka’s civic rights also have been reinstated.

_source.content:
The issuance of Halal certification by the All Ceylon Jamiyyathul Ulama has come under further scrutiny following a statement made in parliament yesterday by the countrie’s Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe.

Speaking in parliament yesterday Wickremesinghe noted that Halal certification should be issued by the Sri Lanka Standards Institution.


			   
			   		
	
			   

However Secretary of the All Ceylon Jamiyyathul Ulama Mursheed Moulasar presiding over a media briefing convened by the ACJU this afternoon noted that the SLSI was incapable of issuing Halal certification.


			   
			   		
	
			   

Meanwhile Cabinet Spokesperson Minister Keheliya Rambukwella was queried by journalists today regarding Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe's statement in parliament yesterday.

In reply Minister Rambukwella had this to say.

hits._id: Appeals Court issues notices for Ranil and Thissa; Injunction from the district court

_source.content:
The Court of Appeal today issued notice on the respondents following a petition filed by UNP Provincial Councilors Shiral Lakthilake and Maithree Gunarathne.
When the petition was taken for hearing today, President of the Court of Appeal Justice Sri Skandarajah ordered the respondents to appear in court on the 16th of September.
Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe, UNP General Secretary Tissa Attanayake and 94 members of the UNP Working Committee and the party Disciplinary Inquiry Committee have been named as respondents in the petition.
The two UNP PC members in their writ application have challenged the UNP Working Committee’s move to expel them from the party.
Meanwhile the Colombo District Court issued an injunction on UNP Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe, General Secretary Tissa Attanayake and the party Disciplinary Inquiry Committee when another petition filed by Deputy Minister of Environment Abdul Cader was taken before Court.
MP Abdul Cader has been called before the UNP Disciplinary Inquiry Committee today for his voting with the government for a recent impeachment in parliament.
Abdul Cader is a UNP parliamentarian who crossed over to the government.
It was revealed that UNP General Secretary Tissa Attanayake had sent a fax message to Deputy Minister Cader calling him for a disciplinary inquiry today.
It was also announced in the Court that the disciplinary inquiry would be held whether Deputy Minister Cader was present before the Disciplinary Committee or not.
Appearing on behalf of Deputy Minister Cader, President Counsel Faizer Mustafa asked the Court to issue an injunction as it was impractical to fix a disciplinary inquiry on the same day parliament adjourns.
Later Colombo Chief Magistrate Pradeep Hettiarachchi issued an injunction today on the respondents which is valid until the 8th of August.

hits._id: SL fishermen are not detained in India- Fisheries Ministry says

_source.content:
Ministry of Fisheries has rejected accusations that the Indian government is detaining arrested Sri Lankan fishermen.

Arrested fishermen will not be detained for a long period of time, the Fisheries Ministry stated.

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickramsignhe stressed that he would not allow communalism to disrupt the national government, which is committed to the protection and strengthening of religious co-existence.  He stated this while addressing an international Islamic summit which commenced today.

hits._id: A Facebook post from the Prime Minister regarding the GMOA issue

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says that no individual is recognized to be more privileged than others and no career path is recognized to be more important than another. In response to a protest launched by the GMOA demanding their children be admitted to popular schools, the premier expressed his views on his Facebook account today. Over 200 GMOA members occupied the auditorium of the Education Ministry yesterday demanding a meeting with the subject minister over the admission dispute.  As their attempt failed, the protestors spent the night within the premises of the Education Ministry. Meanwhile, the protesting doctors left the Education Ministry premises after the Kaduwela Magistrate issued a ruling that protestors should evacuate the ministry premises. In the meantime, a tense situation erupted as protesting doctors found that their vehicles parked inside the ministry premises had been deflated. Later, police intervened in the matter to repair the deflated tires.Meanwhile, functions of government hospitals in the districts of Kurunegala, Kandy, and Matara were disrupted from 8 am to 12 noon due to the token strike launched by the GMOA over the Grade one school admission dispute. The doctors’ trade-union action caused inconvenience to the patients who sought treatment at these hospitals.

hits._id: PM Wickremesinghe expresses his support to Turkey

_source.content:
Foiling the attempt to overturn a democratically-elected government through a military coup would please all people who valued democracy, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has stated.
In a special statement he said he was happy ‘to note that the president and prime minister of Turkey had been able to preserve democratic rule and assured the support of Sri Lanka and its people’.
He expressed his support to Turkey as the attempt to take over the government was hindered by authorities.
A group of military officials attempted to take over the government on Friday. At least 200 people were killed in the incident.

hits._id: EC Chairman hints on election date

_source.content:
The Chairman of the National Election Commission, Mahinda Deshapriya says that elections for 341 Local Government bodies throughout the island will be held on or before February 17th, 2018.
 
Addressing a media conference held at his office this morning (04), the Commission Chairman said that polls will not be conducted on a Sunday nor a public holiday.
 
He further said that instructions have been given to the police to arrest those who conduct propaganda campaigns disturbing the GCE Ordinary Level candidates.
 
The O/L examination will be held from 12th of December to 21st.
 
Responding to a journalists, Election Commission Chairman, Mahinda Deshapriya said that the Local Government polls will cost the government more than 30 million rupees.

hits._id: Local entrepreneurs must be protected: says President-Video

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that the programme the Government has initiated to uplift the local entrepreneur would never be altered.Participating at the special meeting held yesterday with the Small and Medium Women Entrepreneurs President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that the country had achieved several economic victories as a result of the correct policies the Government had followed.This meeting was held for obtaining their views for preparing the 2015 budget.The President said that as a result of the policy of the previous governments of importing everything from overseas, the local industry entrepreneur had been severely affected. The President said that under the correct policy of the current Government the local entrepreneurs were being given impetus.

hits._id: Presidential Task Force to look into the disasters

_source.content:
A Presidential Task Force was established to further manage the disasters that took place due to heavy rains.
President Maithripala Sirisena has appointed the task force which will be headed by Secretary to the President P. B. Abeykoon.
Its first meeting is due to be held on Monday.

Thus people can dial 011 30 30 303 to inform about power cuts.

hits._id: video : The government does not sell state property - says president

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa said today that the country achieved the current development status because the present government, unlike its predecessors, did not sell government institutions.Certain previous governments systematically destroyed government institutions complaining that the government cannot do profitable business and later sold them to their favorites low-priced.Addressing the gathering, the President said that the two institutions were able to record a profit above 1.4 billion rupees last year.20% of the profit was paid as incentives and bonuses to workers and farmers.President Rajapaksa was addressing a ceremony to distribute bonuses and incentives to workers of Sevenagala and Pelawatta sugar corporations which were taken over by the government in 2011.

hits._id: People can Question 19th Amendment

_source.content: Deputy Foreign Minister Ajith P Perera said that people have the opportunity to consult the Supreme Court Opinion about the constitutionality of the proposed amendment after it is gazetted.Accordingly it could be verified whether the proposed amendment should either be passed by two third majority in parliament or hold a referendum.The proposed 19th Amendment was passed by the Cabinet yesterday and soon afterward, it was sent to government printer for gazetting.However Government Printer Gamini Fonseka told our news team that he has not received such a gazette to be printed as yet.Meanwhile Deputy Foreign Minster Ajith P Perera told our news team that the government coalitions also have certain differences of opinion over the amendment.He also said that there is possibility to add amendment to this Draft Bill when it is presented in parliament.The main constitutional proposals of the 19th Amendment include the transformation of the Presidential form of government to a Presidential-Parliamentary system of government and the restoration of the 17th Amendment to the Constitution.The new reforms will result in the President losing the power to dissolve parliament after one year of its election.According, to the proposed reforms the President cannot dissolve the parliament until 4 years of election.The maximum term of a President to hold office has been limited to two terms.Apart from this it has also been decided to re-appoint the independent commissions.He would also retain the power to appoint the Prime Minister and the Cabinet.The Presidential immunity from being sued over matters conducted during his period of office is to also be removed under the proposed reforms.However, the President would remain as the head of the Cabinet, and the commander in chief of the armed forces.However, Deputy Minister Ajith P Perera stated that there are various ideologies among parties affiliated to the government.

Pix by Hatton Ranjith Rajapaksha

hits._id: Govt decides to implement a joint service timetable for SLTB & private buses.

_source.content:
The government has decided to implement a joint service time table for SLTB and Private busses with effect from 15th of January next year.

The Ministry Sub Committee which was appointed to prepare a national bus fare policy took this decision when they met in parliament yesterday.

Private Transport Minister C.B. Rathnayake said Private buses will be allocated 60% slots while SLTB is given 40% under the proposed joint service time table.

Private bus union representatives as well as Chairmen of Provincial Transport Authorities participated in this meeting yesterday.

Lanka Private Bus Owners Association President Gemunu Wijerathna said that the parties did not come to a final agreement with regard to the joint service time table.

hits._id: NFF to refrain from voting at today's UNP no confidence motion

_source.content: The NFF has decided to abstain from voting at the no confidence motion brought by UNP in parliament against the government today.The Party Media Spokesman and former MP Mohammad Musammil said that the party MPs will not participate in the no confidence motion debate as well.The no-confidence motion against the Government moved in parliament by the UNP is scheduled to be taken up for debate today and tomorrow.The UNP recently moved this no-confidence motion in parliament signed by 26 MPs against the Government’s failure to prevent the influx of dangerous drugs including narcotics into the country.A Government affiliated party, JHU had recently expressed various views severely critical of narcotics influx into the country.  However JHU Media spokesman Nishaantha Sri Varnasinghe said that although his party central committee had met last afternoon, it had not been possible to reach a consensus.He said that accordingly discussions would be held today as well and it would be reveled tomorrow as to whether the JHU would vote for or against the no-confidence motion or adopt any other line of action.The JVP and TNA representing the Opposition said that they would meet this forenoon and take a decision about it.

hits._id: A risk of Dengue becoming an epidemic

_source.content:
The Health Ministry stated that the current dengue threat could develop in to a epidemic level due to the rainy weather prevailing in the country during the next two months.
 
Dengue experts warned about a possible epidemic during a meeting chaired by Ministry Secretary Dr. Nihal Jayatillake at his office yesterday.
 
13 thousand 500 dengue cases were reported during the last 5 months and 46 percent of the cases were reported from the districts of Colombo and Gampaha.
 
The Health ministry stated that the majority of victims were school children.
 
Meanwhile a dengue hit law faculty student of Colombo University died this morning while receiving treatment at the Colombo National Hospital.
 
Addressing a meeting on the side line of the World Environment Day held at Temple Trees today President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that certain government institutions did not work with responsibility so much so that they failed to overpower the killer dengue threat today.

hits._id: The government is facing the consequences of taking over opposition MP's ; says Opposition Leader.

_source.content: Opposition Leader Ranil Wickramasingha states that the government and the President are facing the consequences of taking over opposition MP’s to the government.Addressing a media briefing opposition leader said there are many shortcomings when implementing the 18th amendment to the constitution.

hits._id: If provincial councils are abolished why is election held; questions opposition leader.

_source.content:
Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremasinghe says that he asks the Government why it holds the provincial council election if it abolishes the provincial council.
 
The Opposition Leader said so while participating at a people’s rally held in Maligawatta in Colombo yesterday.

hits._id: TNA accepts Presidents invitation

_source.content: The Tamil National Alliance says that they are prepared to accept the invitation extended by President Mahinda Rajapaksa.TNA Leader R Sambanthan stated that they will accept the invitation subject to the implementation of the recommendations of the Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission and the enactment of the consensus reached during discussions with the government.Speaking recently at the budget debate President Mahinda Rajapaksa invited the TNA to join hands to ensure peace, development and reconciliation.

hits._id: Be aware of threats against the country - says President

_source.content:
President  Mahinda Rajapakse states that the current government is not one that  destroys national heritage; rather it is one that safeguards the  country’s national heritage.
Speaking  further President Rajapakse also stated that the government is on a path  to develop the country while respecting all races and religions.
The President made these statements while speaking at a public gathering held in the Chilaw region.
Meanwhile,  speaking at a function held at the Puttalam – Thabbowa – Bodhimalaka  Pushparama vihara President Mahinda Rajapakse stated that the public  should be vigilant regarding threats against the country.

hits._id: Inland Revenue Act To Be Redrafted With International Standards

_source.content:
Government has taken steps to instruct the Legal Draftsman to redraft the Inland Revenue Act according to international standards improving clarity and transparency.
The Inland Revenue Act No 10 of 2016 provides legal provisions to impose income tax in Sri Lanka and due to periodical amendments made to the act since its enactment have made it complicated.
Simplification and modernization of the act according to acceptable tax principles that helps in attracting investors has become a timely requirement.
2016 budget proposed to amend the Inland Revenue Act to accommodate foreign investments and to exempt income tax on foreign currency inflows.
The budget also proposed a new Act named ‘Foreign Exchange Management Act’ to be introduced to facilitate foreign investments.
The Cabinet of Ministers have approved a proposal made by Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake on this purpose.

hits._id: First Cabinet meeting after reshuffle, today

_source.content:
The cabinet is scheduled to meet for the first time today (May 09) since the recent cabinet reshuffle.
 
Government sources say that protocol normally has been to have cabinet discussions held on Tuesdays.
 
However since the inauguration of the new session of Parliament took place yesterday, the Cabinet meeting was required to be rescheduled for today.
 
Priority will be given at the meeting to discussions regarding the next steps to be taken by the Good Governance Government.
 
In addition, attention will also be drawn to the issue concerning the Deputy Speaker post.
 
MP Thilanga Sumathipala resigned from the post last month.
 
Meanwhile, the Parliament is scheduled to meet at 1 pm today.

hits._id: Government played the most pivotal part in forwarding the nations health care system; President.

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapaksa states that it was his government that played the most pivotal part in forwarding the nations health care system into new horizons.

Speaking further President Rajapaksa noted that the current government was spending considerable amounts of funds on behalf of the education as well as health care sectors.

President Rajapaksa's comments came during the inaugural ceremony which was held to inaugurate the renovation of the Nuwara Eliya hospital which is being carried out at an estimated cost of 6686 million rupees.

Expressing his views further president Rajapaksa noted that subsequent to his government taking over the reigns of the country in 2005, estate hospitals which were in a decrepit state were acquired by the central government, there by providing a qualitative health service to the estate community.

Moreover President Mahinda Rajapaksa toured the Nuwara Eliya town this morning while engaging in cordial discussions with the area residents.

hits._id: President extends service of Navy Commander

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena granted a six month service extension to Navy Commander Vice Admiral Ravindra Wijeyagunaratne today.

hits._id: Next parliamentary session commencement ‘time’ decided

_source.content:
The time of commencement of the next parliamentary session has been announced.
 
Responding to a query, Parliament’s General Secretary Dhammika Dassanayake said that the new session would begin at 12.15 pm on 8th of May.
 
Reports say that President’s staff had informed the Parliament’s secretariat regarding this.
 
Dassanayake said that a new Gazette will be issued after President Maithripala Sirisena returns to Sri Lanka from the UK today (Apr. 23).
 
President issued a Gazette on 12th of this month proroguing the Parliament, however, the time of commencement of the session was not been mentioned in it.

hits._id: Parliament will Debate Pillai's committee on the 17th and 18th.-Video

_source.content: During the party leaders’ meeting this morning, it was decided to debate in parliament on the 17th and 18th of this month, whether Navi Pillai’s Committee is allowed to enter the country to investigate alleged human rights violations.However the JVP has decided to add amendments to this proposal which had already been submitted to parliament with signatures of nine ruling party MPs.JVP Leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake stated that the amendment papers with six changes have been handed over to the Secretary General of parliament today.A vote will be taken after the 17th and 18th of June during which parliament would debate the government’s proposal on the UN issue.However the UNP stated that it will announce whether the party will participate in the debate after its parliamentary group meets on the 17th of June.Meanwhile TNA MP M.A. Sumandiran who participated in the party leaders’ meeting today said his party’s parliamentary group will meet soon to take a decision regarding their participation in this debate.He also said that the government checking the parliament’s opinion regarding this issue is an attempt by them to humiliate the parliament as the government has already declared its objections to the UN Committee.

hits._id: SL-Pakistan Foreign Office consultations begin

_source.content:
The Foreign Secretaries of Sri Lanka and Pakistan, Prasad Kariyawasam and Tehmina Janjua, will lead the respective Foreign Ministry delegations to the Fifth Foreign Office consultations that will take place in Colombo tomorrow (17).
Discussions during the consultations are expected to focus on all relevant areas of cooperation between the two countries including trade and investment, tourism, science and technology, education, immigration, defence and sports.
Foreign Office Consultations between the two countries were last held in Islamabad in 2014.
The Pakistan Foreign Secretary Janjua will pay a courtesy call on President Maithripala Sirisena tomorrow.

hits._id: Right To Information Draft Bill Is Of Int’ Standards –Government

_source.content:
The Government says the Right to Information draft bill scheduled to be tabled in Parliament on the 23rd of June is of international standards.
Co-Cabinet Spokesperson Minister Gayantha Karunathileke speaking at the weekly Cabinet media briefing this morning said the previous government failed to table the Right to Information bill.
The Minister said the previous government was never willing to table a Right to Information Bill. He said they openly debated the bill but rejected to table it.
However Minister Karunathileke said a Canadian organization has commended the draft bill and rated it as the 7th best RTI bill in the world.

hits._id: President highlights importance of protecting local industries

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says it is important to have a policy which gives prominence to local industries when strengthening the national economy.
 
The President said this addressing the launch of Leather and Footwear exhibition at the BMICH today.
Meanwhile, the World Wetlands Day was commemorated with the participation of President Maithripala Sirisena at the 'Ape Gama' in Battaramulla today. 
In another event, the newly printed Rs. 1000 note to commemorate the country's 70th Independence Day celebrations was presented to President Sirisena today. 
Central Bank Governor Dr. Indrajit Coomaraswamy and other officials attended the event.

hits._id: Sri Lanka ready to become region’s technological hub; President says at BIMSTEC summit

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena reiterated the commitment of the government to establish a BIMSTEC Center for Technology Transfer Facility to contribute to the collective drive for economic advancement.
The President made these remarks, addressing the BIMSTEC Summit held in Goa, India yesterday.
The President further stated that Diversification and modernisation of economies, infrastructure development, knowledge exchange, increased access to technology, enhanced capacity building, and the expansion of trade and investment can no longer be held back.
Leaders of the BIMSTEC meeting commended the President Maithripala Sirisena for the democratic transformation taking place in Sri Lanka.
President Sirisena met with several leaders on the sidelines of the BRICS Outreach Summit.
Meeting with the Foreign Minister of Myanmar Aung San Suu Kyi, the President commended Myanmar's leader who had led a long term struggle for democracy.
Aung San Suu Kyi who commended the democratic transformation occurring in Sri Lanka, expressed her satisfaction over President Sirisena’s political journey and gave assurance of the desire to strengthen bilateral relations between the two countries.
The President who also met Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, expressed his thanks for the invitation, and noted that it would consolidate the perennial relations between the two countries.
Indian Premier also noted that he invites Sri Lanka to deepen relations with India, beyond norms and regulations.
He also stated that the arrival of Sri Lankan President for the summit conferred strength to the entire region.

hits._id: Building a prosperous country to commence from next year; says President

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena stated that the year 2017 which has been named as the year to eradicate poverty, will see the initial steps been taken to build economic prosperity in the country.
An 8 member committee headed by Minister Sarath Amunugama has been appointed to look in to eradicating poverty.
Meanwhile, President Maithripala Sirisena declared open a cartoon exhibition in view of the completion of 50 years in the career of Cartoonist Camelous Perera.

hits._id: Students who excelled O/L 2015 meet the President

_source.content: The 12 students who excelled in GCE Ordinary Level examination 2015 met President Maithripala Sirisena at the Presidential Secretariat today.President’s Media Unit stated that the President, who commended the achievements by the students, offered them cash rewards and laptops.Meanwhile, a female web designer who made history by creating a website at the age of nine and earned a BSc Degree in Information Technology at the age of 11 also met President Maithripala Sirisena today.

hits._id: Government ready to fulfil the needs of estate community President

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that the government is prepared to fulfil the needs of the estate community without waiting for anyone else to do so.
 
Speaking at a UPFA meeting that was held in Thalawakele yesterday the President stated that the government took steps to provide facilities to the estate community since 2005.

hits._id: We have given an opportunity to the protestors to remove the President from his position : says Minister Nimal Siripala

_source.content: Minister Nimal Siripala says that they have given an opportunity for the protestors who are aiming to remove the President from his position.He stated this while attending a ceremony in Elagamuwa area, Kekirawa last evening.The Minister added that the Opposition leader has said he will overturn Rajapaksa regime, and so they have given the opportunity to do so. However, he also said that they have provided the people with a united and undivided country to live independently. And this fact alone is enough for people to vote for President Mahinda Rajapaksa ten times.Meanwhile, Minister S.M. Chandrasena who joined the occasion stated that the Opposition was unable to appoint a common candidate thus far.He added that their party has taken all measures including choosing a candidate for the upcoming Presidential election. However, the opposition still haven’t selected a common candidate between Chandrika Bandaranaike, Karu Jayasuriya, Maduluwawe Sobhitha Thera and Ranil Wickramasinghe.

hits._id: Health Ministry investigation on Ragama hospital labour room dispute.

_source.content: The Health Ministry has taken measures to conduct an inquiry regarding the incident which occurred yesterday at Ragama Teaching Hospital.The Director of the Hospital Doctor Mahinda Samaranayake told our news team that 2 Director Generals have already commenced the inquiry.The Government Midwives Services Association stated that 11 midwives attached to the labour rooms of Ragama Teaching Hospital have been detained since the 26th of the month.Later, a clash occurred when the junior staff and midwives tried to rescue the detained midwives yesterday.Several Midwives, 7 Junior staff members as well as 2 nurses who received injuries are currently receiving medical attention.However, the nurses of the Ragama Teaching Hospital are still engaged in a trade union action.The Chairman of Government Nursing Officers’ Association Saman Ratnapriya stated that even though they carry out essential services, the trade union action will not be suspended until their safety is ensured.

hits._id: The GMOA has decided to educate the President over the communiqué issued yesterday by the Presidential Secretariat with regard to Malabe Private Medical School

_source.content:
The GMOA has decided to educate the President over the communiqué issued yesterday by the Presidential Secretariat with regard to Malabe Private Medical School.GMOA media spokesman Dr. Samantha Ananda said that there are contradictions between the discussion they had with the President and the content of the communiqué issued by the Secretary to the President.
The GMOA and President Maithripala Sirisena have come to 4 agreements with regard to the Malabe Private Medical School issue.
Among them is to suspend recruitment for Malabe Private Medical School and not to award medical degrees until the institution fulfils the standards recommended by the government.
At the same time, GMOA Secretary Dr. Haritha Aluthge explains how its membership is pressing them to go for trade union action again.

hits._id: The court, not the Minister,  has power to give a verdict on the  Avant Guard issue;Reiterates Joint cabinet spokesperson Rajitha Senarathna

_source.content: The Joint Cabinet Spokesman and minister Rajitha Senarathna said the Court is responsible for giving a verdict over the Avant Garde incident. He stated it is not the role of the Justice Minister.Minister of Justice and Buddhasasana Wijedasa Rajapakse told parliament recently that he had objected to the arrest of former Defense Secretary Gotabhaya Rajapaksa in connection with the incident.Minister Rajapakse said that the government does not counsel native proctors.Cabinet spokesman was questioned ,if there was a connection  between the Avant Garde incident and the conspiracy in the Maldives.The Navy Commander has submitted a report to the Ministry of Defense describing the transfer of functions by Avant Garde Security firm to the Sri Lankan Navy.

hits._id: Yet another video against Sri Lanka.

_source.content:
Foreign Ministry representatives from voting countries of the UN Human Rights Council are scheduled to attend a conference hosted by the Global Tamil Forum in the British Parliament on the 27th of this month.
A GTF spokesman said that British parliamentarians, both in the government and opposition, are among a host of invitees scheduled to address the conference.
Leader of the Tamil National Alliance R Sampanthan and TNA MP MA Sumanthiran are also on the guest list.
A GTF spokesman said that the first ever preview of the ‘No Fire Zone’, yet another film against Sri Lanka will be screened at the conference.
The full documentary is also scheduled to be screened in Geneva during the UNHRC session.

hits._id: Minister Lakshman Yapa is lying - allegations from the Hela Urumaya

_source.content:
Casinos is a much spoken about topic in the country at present.

The government had to withdraw two announcement relating to Casinos from parliament following objections not only from the Opposition but also from some parties of the government itself.

Deputy General Secretary of the Jathika Hela Urumaya Udaya Gammanpila even went to extent of calling Minister Lakshman Yapa the Minister for Casinos.

He said that the Minister was lying about the episode.

hits._id: Japan pledges assistance for reconciliation and new Constitution

_source.content: Defence Minister of Japan Thomomi Inada said that action should be taken under a common basis to ensure peace in the Indian Ocean. She stated this during a meeting held with visiting Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe this morning. She has also stated that relations between Sri Lankan armed forces and Japanese armed forces should be made closer accordingly. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has told that peace and security in the Indian Ocean is the basis for economic stability in Sri Lanka for years. Meanwhile, the government of Japan has decided to appoint a special envoy for Sri Lanka to coordinate the island’s sustainable development activities. According to Japanese Cabinet Secretary Yoshihade Suga, Japanese Prime Minister’s advisor Dr. Hirotho Isumi will be appointed to the new post. Japanese Cabinet Secretary Yoshihade Suga announced this during a discussion he held with visiting Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Prime Minister’s Office this morning. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe met Japanese Deputy Prime Minister Taro Azo and thanked him for the development assistance extended to Sri Lanka by the government of Japan.

hits._id: President sends condolences over the death of Tamil Nadu Chief Minister

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has published a tweet expressing his condolences over the death of Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa Jeyaram. 
President Sirisena’s tweet states that Jayalalithaa was honoured by her supporters.  
The message has also extended the president’s condolences to the family of the former Tamil Nadu Chief Minister and the people of Tamil Nadu.
Meanwhile, former president Mahinda Rajapaksa tweeted that Chief Minister Jayalalithaa Jeyaram had won the hearts of the people of Tamil Nadu.
He has also extended his condolences to the family of late Jayalalitha and the people of Tamil Nadu.

hits._id: Removal of Facebook ban imminent - PMD

_source.content:
President's Media Unit says necessary steps are being taken to ease the restrictions imposed on Facebook.
 
Through this discussion, the government is working on to create a mechanism to ensure the necessary protection and surveillance and lift the temporary restriction on access to the Facebook site.
 
The restrictions on Facebook would most probably be lifted after that discussion.
 
The President's Media Division also said that President Maithripala Sirisena has highlighted the importance of having a mechanism to regulate the social media.
 
He had said that such a mechanism is required to avoid social media being used to incite racial disharmony and damage personal images.
The government decided to restrict access to social media sites temporarily last week, in order to curtail the misuse of the social media in a manner detrimental to the national harmony.
The President has instructed the relevant authorities to take necessary steps immediately to bring normalcy to the country and ensure such disturbances would not recur and take legal actions against those who are responsible for those illegal activities.

hits._id: Government acquisition of Neville Fernando Hospital takes place with the signing of the agreement

_source.content:
The signing of the agreement with regard to the  hand over of  Neville Fernando hospital to the government was held this morning, during a ceremony with the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena.
Chairman of Malabe Private Medical School Dr. Neville Fernando and General Manager of Bank of Ceylon D.M. Gunesekera signed the agreement.
Addressing the gathering, minister of Highways and Higher Education Lakshman Kiriella said that the hospital was not taken over by the government but it was donated by Dr. Neville Fernando.
Addressing the gathering , Health Minister Rajitha Senarathna said that Neville Fernando hospital will function in the capacity of a teaching hospital in the near future.
The medical facility has an estimated value of the 3.5 billion rupees and it is equipped with all necessary equipment to upgrade to the level of a teaching hospital.
This hospital will be maintained as an independent body by a special board similar to that of Sri Jayewardenepura hospital.
44 specialists and 70 general physicians are currently serving at the Neville Fernando hospital.

hits._id: Every necessary action will be taken to eradicate drug menace - President

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena stated that every necessary action will be taken for the control, prevention and eradication of drug use while the laws regarding the raid of drugs will be tightened. He further asserted that all obstacles which authorities had to face during the exploitation of their powers and the execution of law will be removed and a positive atmosphere for everybody to perform their duties with confidence and resilience will be created.
The President made this statement addressing the assembly at the 64th Anniversary of the All Ceylon Excise Sergeants’ and Guards’ Association held yesterday at the New Town Hall in Colombo. It is the intention of the government to operate the institutes which bring in revenue for the government such as the Excise Department, Inland Revenue Department and Customs free of fraud and corruption. The President also said that he would never stoop to such practices as calling those institutes representing businessmen. In the interim the presenting of a souvenir and emblem to the President marking the inauguration of the Maritime & Naval Week took place at the President's House yesterday.

hits._id: Local Councils convene at auditoriums

_source.content:
The Ministry of Provincial Councils and Local Government says that the sessions of Local Government bodies which will be formed by 6th of March will be held at the auditoriums of the respective councils.It is because the number of councillors has doubled as a result of the new electoral system.
Meanwhile, the Election Commission says that they expect the names of councilors for the additional lists before 2nd of March so that the entire list of Local Government councillors can be gazette by 3rd of March.

hits._id: Let’s act with understanding while forming stronger bonds; President says in his Deepawaali message

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena stated that the hope for this years Deepawali festival should be to make a determination to promote harmony and reconciliation.
The President expressed these views in a message issued in view of the Deepawali festival which falls today.
President Sirisena also stated that after decades of darkness today is a day which could be considered as a great opportunity to proceed towards a brighter future.
The President also stated that it important to act with understanding thus building strong bonds with one another.
Meanwhile, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe issuing a message in view of the Deepawali festival stated that although to divide was easy, to unite was hard and hence everyone should take up that challenge.
The National Deepawali festival was held at the Temple Trees yesterday under the patronage of the President and Prime Minister.

hits._id: Senior SLFPers meet with former President

_source.content:
Former Prime Minister, D.M. Jayarathna says that ways and means to unite the SLFP and the Joint Opposition were discussed during the Central Working Committee meeting held under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena yesterday (22).
 
Meanwhile, SLFP Senior Ministers, W.D.J. Senevirathna, and Susil Premajayantha had a discussion with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa yesterday.
 
It was stated that discussions were centered on to how to settle the current differences in opinion within the SLFP.
 
Minister W.D.J. Senevirathna said that attention was drawn to the SLFP’s written proposals that were presented to the Joint Opposition.

hits._id: 26 SLFP members who abstained from voting on NCM, meets PM

_source.content:
The 26 Sri Lanka Freedom Party parliamentarians who abstained from voting on 'no-confidence motion' against Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe have met with President and Prime Minister separately.
 
During the meeting with the President, they have informed that they would stay in the Unity Government.
 
Thereafter, they had a meeting with the Prime Minister. During that meeting, they have asked the PM to allow the 16 SLFP MP's to rejoin the government.
 
State Minister Piyasena Gamage disclosed these details.

hits._id: President's stand on giving nominations to Mahinda Rajapaske is vague; the Hindu reports

_source.content: Hindu news paper reports that there seems to be lack of clarity about President Maithripala Sirisena’s position on the Sri Lanka Freedom Party led United People’s Freedom Alliance’s move to provide former President Mahinda Rajapaksa with a ticket to contest in the August 17th parliamentary polls.Ever since the UPFA general secretary Susil Premajayantha’s statement was made public on Friday, announcing the nomination of Mahinda Rajapaksa, silence has been the response of the President.This was not the case on earlier occasions, when the President’s office promptly denied reports in sections of the press about a possible meeting between the two leaders.But, the absence of any emphatic reaction from President Maithripala Sirisena need not be construed as a sign of his approval for former President Rajapaksa’s nominationHowever, preparation of nomination list of the SLFP has not been finalized yet. Meanwhile, Western Provincial Council Chief Minister Prasanna Ranatunga said that an alternative plan is ready for former president Mahinda Rajapaksa to contest the election if he is denied nominations under UPFA at the last snag.He stated this to the newspaper briefing program "Paththare Visthare" on Hiru TV this morning.

hits._id: President suspends issuing of permits to transport cattle

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena has ordered to temporarily suspend issuing of permits to transport cattle.

hits._id: Update: MS – MR meeting; SLFP MPs can’t take part in other partie's rallies

_source.content:
A consensus has been reached that SLFP MPs would not participate in rallies held demanding that Mahinda Rajapaksa be made the UPFA prime ministerial candidate.Agreement has been expressed at the discussion held between President Maitripala Sirisena and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa that this should be implemented according to a decision the party central committee had taken.A senior SLFP minister who participated in the discussion said the former president’s faction too had given the nod to this proposal put forward by President Maitripala Sirisena’s faction.Another meeting demanding that former president Mahinda Rajapaksa should be nominated as the prime ministerial candidate is scheduled to be held in Kurunegala yesterday.Several political parties constituting the UPFA have organized this rally.The Minister said further that at the SLFP Central Committee meeting a decision had been taken recently that SLFP MPs should not participate in those meetings.However some MPs had ignored this decision and had on different occasions taken part in these meetings.The senior Minister said further that with the President Maitripala Sirisena faction pointing out that this was a problem for party unity and discipline, the nod was given for SLFP MPs for not participating in such meetings in the future. Update : Thursday, 07 May 2015 - 8:30--------------------------------------------------------------------
Maithri-Mahinda talks inconclusiveFormer minister Dallas Alahapperuma said that the meeting held today between President Maithreepala Sirisena and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa ended on a negative note.However Minister Duminda Dissanayake said the meeting was 100% successful.MPs Kumara Welgama, Bandula Gunawardana, Dallas Alahapperuma, G.L. Peries and Mahindananda Aluthgamage represented the former president’s faction in today’s discussions.At the same time, Opposition Leader Nimal Siripala de Silva, ministers Duminda Dissanayake, M.K.D.S. Gunawardana and SLFP General Secretary Anura Priyadarshana Yapa accompanied the President in the discussions today. Former Minister Faizer Mustafa was also present at the meeting venue.The discussions today were focused on 5 major factors. SLFP General Secretary Anura Priyadarshana Yapa said, among them are: the prime ministerial candidacy in the forthcoming general election, dissolving of local government institutions, contesting the election under UPFA, giving nominations to candidates and politicization of police financial crime investigation Division.After the discussions, MP Alahapperuma said that the meeting ended without any satisfactory accord but further discussions would continue unhindered.At this point, journalists asked about the President’s response to the proposal that former president Mahinda Rajapaksa should be fielded as the prime ministerial candidate.Answering to journalists, MP Alahapperuma quoted the President as saying that the SLFP Central Working Committee should be consulted with regard to that matter.Although the former president’s faction stated the discussions ended on a negative note, Agriculture Minister Duminda Dissanayake said discussions are 100% successful.However MP Kumara Welgama said that two factions are currently operating within SLFP.But Minister Duminda Dissanayake said there is no division within the party.Update: Wednesday, 06 May 2015 - 07:36 PM......................................................................Mahinda - Maithree meeting todayThe meeting between President Maithreepala Sirisena and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa will be held today at 1.30 pm at the President’s office of the parliament complex.SLFP General Secretary Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Susil Premajayantha and Opposition Leader Nimal Siripala de Silva have been named to participate on behalf of the President’s faction while MPs Kumara Welgama, Bandula Gunawardana and Dallas Alahapperuma have been picked to represent former President Rajapaksa’s faction.The President and the former President were scheduled to meet on March 25th, but the organizers cancelled the meeting later.Update : Wednesday, 06 May 2015 - 08:14------------------------------------------------------
MS & MR to meet tomorrowFormer Minister Bandula Gunawardana stated that the meeting between President Maithreepala Sirisena and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa will be held tomorrow.He said the meeting would be held at 1 o’clock in the afternoon at the President’s office of the parliament complex.SLFP General Secretary Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Susil Premajayantha and Opposition Leader Nimal Siripala de Silva have been named to participate on behalf of the President’s faction while MPs Kumara Welgama, Bandula Gunawardana and Dallas Alahapperuma have been picked to represent former President Rajapaksa’s faction.These 6 MPs would meet this evening to have preliminary discussions on the treaties to be adopted during the meeting between the two presidents.The sources close to the two factions stated the former President’s representative group would submit a five-fold proposal to the President’s representatives during the meeting this evening.Meanwhile the UPFA stated in a statement today that the foundation of the scheduled meeting between President Maithreepala Sirisena and former President Mahinda Rajapaksa is to win the forthcoming general election.The President and the former President were scheduled to meet on March 25th, but the organizers cancelled the meeting later.Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that certain people have forgotten gratefulness.He sated this during a Bodhi pooja organized by the local residents to invoke blessings to the former President Rajapaksa at the Henkaduwa Ancient Temple in Tangalle yesterday.

hits._id: JO Group leader makes a revelation

_source.content:
The Joint Opposition says for the first time in history, the Cabinet Ministers have voted against their own government.
 
The Group Leader of the Joint Opposition said this addressing a media conference at Parliament this morning (Apr. 05).

hits._id: UNP requests for an investigation following Sri Lanka's humiliating defeat to India

_source.content: UNP MP Niroshan Perera requested at the parliament today to hold an inquiry regarding the humiliating defeat of the Sri Lankan cricket team against India.He said this while joining the debate of Sports Ministry’s heads of expenditure.The heads of expenditure of the Sports and Higher Education Ministry’s were taken for debate today during the committee stage debate of the budget.

hits._id: Election Commission asks LG candidates to curtail promotions by Jan. 31

_source.content: All election offices of candidates, cutouts, and posters related to Local Government elections, should be removed before 31st of January, says Chairman of the Election Commission, Mahinda Deshapriya.

hits._id: US support Sri lanka for its 2 years request to work on UN human rights council resolution

_source.content: The United States commended Sri Lanka for agreeing once again to co-sponsor the UN resolution promoting reconciliation, accountability, and human right and applauded the administration of President Maithripala Sirisena for its continuing efforts to promote reconciliation. The US invites like-minded UNHRC member, countries to support the new resolution to support Sri Lanka whose government earlier this week urged the UN Human Rights Council core group to give Sri Lanka a 24-month extension to work on the US sponsored resolution that awaits a favourable response from the UN body. Issuing a statement on the draft resolution on Sri Lanka presented to the UN Human Rights Council on March 13th by the United States and other members of the Friends of Sri Lanka Core Group, the U.S. State Department said the resolution reflects the United States' enduring commitment to lasting peace and justice for all the people of Sri Lanka. The United States said it worked in close consultation with the United Kingdom, Montenegro, and Macedonia, and in partnership with the Government of Sri Lanka, to draft the resolution.

hits._id: President Rajapakse arrives in the island.

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapaksa returned to the country after a four-day official visit to Uganda
 
President Mahinda Rajapaksa commenced  his four-day official visit to Uganda - on May 11th afternoon. 
 
This was President Rajapaksa’s second official visit to Uganda. 
 
The last visit was to attend the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in 2007.
 
Uganda’s President Yoweri Museveni visited Sri Lanka last November.
 
During the visit, President Rajapaksa held bilateral talks with Uganda’s President Yoweri Museveni and delivered the keynote address at the Commonwealth Local Government Conference.

hits._id: President to address the Anti-Corruption Summit today

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has left for London to take part in the Anti-Corruption Summit 2016. President Sirisena will address the summit today.
The Anti-Corruption Summit will be held today under the patronage of British Prime Minister David Cameron.
President left to London yesterday and was received at the Heathrow Airport by Queen’s special representative Bruce Holder, who is the Deputy Lieutenant to Queen Elizabeth and Kathryn Colvin, Special Representative of the Ministry of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs and the officials of the Sri Lanka High Commission.
The invitation to attend the summit was extended by the British Prime Minister when he met him at CHOGM, held in Malta last January.
The President will hold bilateral discussions with Cameron during this visit.

_source.content:

hits._id: PRIO shortlists President Maithripala Sirisena for Nobel Peace Prize 2017

_source.content: The Peace Research Institute of Oslo has shortlisted Sri Lanka President Maithripala Sirisena for the Nobel Peace Prize 2017. PRIO Director Henrik Urdal will publish an updated shortlist before the official announcement of this year's winner of the Nobel Peace Prize the PRIO website said. The Peace Research Institute Oslo conducts research on the conditions for peaceful relations between states, groups and people. Based on independent assessments, PRIO Directors have offered their personal shortlists for the Nobel Peace Prize each year since 2002. Anyone can be nominated, but only a number of people have the right to nominate, including members of national assemblies and governments, current and former members of the Committee, Peace Prize laureates, professors of certain disciplines, directors of peace research and foreign policy institutes, and members of international courts. As such, the Director of PRIO holds the right to nominate, but refrains, given his active role as a commentator. The laureate is normally announced on the Friday of the first full week of October. Harpviken's 2017 Nobel Peace Prize Shortlist ·        The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and Susan N. Herman·        The Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS)·        Maithripala Sirisena, President of Sri Lanka·        The White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense) and Raed al Saleh·        Jeanne Nacatche Banyere, Jeannette Kahindo Bindu and Dr Denis Mukwege The reasons mentioned by the PRIO to nominate Sri Lanka President Maithripala Sirisena: "President of Sri Lanka Maithripala Sirisena has initiated a comprehensive set of reconciliatory initiatives to heal the wounds of the civil war which culminated in a military onslaught by the state military on the Tamil Tigers (LTTE) in 2009. Sirisena’s insistence on inclusive reconciliation, therefore, stands out as an example to be followed, especially in a situation where support for the International Criminal Court (ICC) and other transitional justice mechanisms is deteriorating. In early 2017, the Sri Lankan Consultation Task Force on Reconciliation Mechanisms released its final report. This goes hand in hand with a range of other efforts, including a consultative process on constitutional reform. Resistance from the political opposition is real, and so are the prospects for failure. The President himself is susceptible to criticism, having held posts with the former government that overran the LTTE. A Nobel Peace Prize to President Sirisena would fit a tradition of honouring pragmatic leaders who show political courage, and it would draw attention to reconciliation as a key to sustainable peace".

hits._id: President says Sri Lanka solves issues step by step

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says Sri Lanka is taking the process to ensure human rights and reconciliation forward step by step.
The President made these remarks during a meeting with Prince Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.
The President pointed out if the government would take hasty actions on those, the extremist groups will take advantage.
He said two years are sufficient for Sri Lanka to complete the subjects adopted by the UNHRC resolution. He invited Prince Hussein to visit Sri Lanka to witness the progress the country has achieved. President Sirisena and the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights met yesterday (22) in New York.
The President pointed out this task should be performed with thorough understanding about the internal political and cultural matters and international politics.
United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights commended Sri Lanka’s progress in these matters.
He said he will be more satisfied if this journey of Sri Lankan government will be speeded up.
He commended the actions taken to establish the Office of Missing Persons.
He requested to appoint officers for this office from all communities so that every community can accept the actions of the office.
He added the UN Human Rights Council will give its fullest support to Sri Lanka in this regard.

hits._id: We should give priority for the future of our Motherland – President

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has said that we should give priority for the future of our Motherland first and not the personal interests of each and every person. He said this as a reply to a question often asked him, what he would do after completing the five year term.
The President made these remarks, speaking at a ceremony to present appointment letters to Co-Chairmen of the District Coordination Committees held at the Presidential Secretariat, yesterday (06).
Expressing his views regarding the political situation of the country , he said that even though the government has paid attention to implement a new constitution not yet any official discussions were held or nor any proposals were accepted.
President Sirisena further said that in contrary to the actual situation some sections of the society are attempting to promote racism in the country and he added that the implementation of the new constitution will not be done in a hidden manner.

hits._id: Local Government Election To Be Held Promptly – Min. Faizer Mustapha

_source.content:
Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils Faizer Mustapha says a Local Government Election will be scheduled after the terms of all local government bodies came to end yesterday.
Speaking at a media briefing today Minister Mustapha said he will not let activities of respective local government bodies to come to a standstill.
Furthermore Minister Mustapha said Municipal Councils and Urban Councils will also come under the commissioner, while respective District Secretaries will undertake operations of Pradeshiya Sabhas.
He said President Sirisena is of the view that activities of the dissolved Local Government bodies will not be hampered.
The terms of 23 bodies including that of the Colombo Municipal Council came to an end at midnight yesterday.
The institutions include 17 Municipal Councils, one Urban Council and 5 Pradeshiya Sabhas.
Accordingly the terms of 335 local government bodies concluded as of yesterday.

hits._id: Indian Support requested by SL to repatriate remaining refugees

_source.content:
The Sri Lankan government is keen on getting assistance of the Indian government to enable quicker voluntary repatriation of the remaining refugees

With one more batch of Sri Lankan Tamil refugees returning from Tamil Nadu to Sri Lanka, the Sri Lankan government is keen on getting assistance of the Indian government to enable quicker voluntary repatriation of the remaining refugees.

Secretary, Ministry of Prison Reforms, Rehabilitation, Resettlement and Hindu Religious Affairs V.Sivagnanasothy said that they expect that the Indian government would assist with regard to housing and road development in places of resettlement.

On Tuesday, 41 refugees including 26 women, will reach Colombo from Chennai and Madurai.

The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees provides free air tickets as well.

hits._id: “Lifting of tea ban shows exemplary diplomatic ties between SL & Russia” - President

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says that the manner in which Russia had revoked the ban imposed on Sri Lanka’s tea imports was a reflection of cordial friendship between the two countries.
 
In a Twitter message, the President said, “Sri Lanka's diplomacy with Russia has always been exemplary. The way the tea exports issue is yet another example of this friendship. Prompt action by the government has paid off. This is also a time to thank Russia for cordiality”.
 
The Russian authorities decided yesterday (25) to revoke the ban with effect from 30th this month.
 
A delegation of Sri Lankan technical experts set out for Russia yesterday to discuss the matter regarding the ban on tea.
 
The 9-member technical team included Tea Board Chairman Rohan Pethiyagoda and Director General of Agriculture Department Dr. Rohan Wijekoon.
 
The Sri Lankan embassy in Moscow said that the team had held discussions with Russia’s Central Government Dairy Resources and representatives from Plant Food Health Services about the ways and means to improve quality standards of goods exported by Sri Lanka to Russia.

hits._id: UN Chief congratulates President’s first anniversary in office

_source.content:
The United Nations Secretary-General Ban ki-moon has congratulated President Maithripala Sirisena, the Government and the people of Sri Lanka on the first anniversary since the country's political transition.
In a statement issued in New York, the UN Chief said he is encouraged by the Government's commitment to a broad reform agenda that aims to realize durable peace, stability and prosperity for the Sri Lankan people.
The Secretary-General acknowledged the initial steps the Government has taken to strengthen good governance, advance reconciliation and implement the resolution of the Human Rights Council of October 2015.
He urged continued progress in these areas and emphasized the need for inclusive consultation processes to address issues of transitional justice.
The Secretary-General said he supports the Government's efforts to advance a nation-wide dialogue to achieve a long-term political settlement acceptable to all.
In this regard, he welcomed the Government's announcement to commence constitutional reform and called on all stakeholders to cooperate in a spirit of inclusion and good faith.

hits._id: Deposition of Relics in Kaluganga Reservoir to be Held on 25th

_source.content:
The Moragahakanda – Kalu Ganga irrigation development project is considered the biggest irrigation project implemented under the Mahaweli Development Project.
The ceremony of depositing relics in Kalu Ganga reservoir will take place under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena on the 25th of this month.
The construction work of Moragahakanda reservoir, which began in 2007, was prolonged during the past few years.
However, construction work was streamlined last year, resulting in the completion of 75% of work by now.
The government expects to complete the work and vest it upon public by the end of the year.
The Public Coordinating Officer of Moragahakanda, Kalu Ganga development project P.G. Dayananda noted that 500,000 persons in Rajarata will benefit from the relevant project, directly and indirectly.

hits._id: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Nawaz Shariff to the island during the 1st week of January

_source.content:
Pakistan’s Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will arrive in Sri Lanka during the first week of January during which the two sides will sign several agreements including a pact on combating money laundering and terrorism financing.
 
This will be Sharif’s first visit to Sri Lanka since President Maithripala Sirisena took office a year ago.
 
Sharif last visited the island in November 2013 for the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting.
 
10 Memorandums of understanding and pacts are to be signed during the Pakistan Prime Minister’s visit, covering a range of key areas.
 
Besides pact on combating money laundering and terrorism financing, the two countries will sign agreements in youth development field, exchange of statistical and census data, science, technology, scientific and technological cooperation, health and culture among others.

hits._id: Special traffic plan around Independence Square for the funeral of Davuldena Maha Nayaka Thero

_source.content:
The funeral of the Chief Prelate of Amarapura Nikaya, Agga Maha Panditha, and most Venerable Davuldena Gnanissara Thera will be held with state honours at the Colombo Independence Square this afternoon.
The remains of the late Nayake Thera which are lying in state at the Sri Vidya Vijayaramaya on Pagoda Road Nugegoda will be escorted in a special vehicular parade.
The cortege is due to leave at 1pm. It will parade Pitakotte Junction, Athul Kotte, Parliament Road, Ayurveda Junction, Castle Street, D.S. Junction, Horton Place and Lotus Roundabout before it reaches Independence Square.
The Sri Lanka Army receives the remains at the Lotus Junction and will escort it to Independence Square along Independence Avenue.
The funeral will commence with the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.
Meanwhile, Police headquarters stated that a special traffic plan has been introduced around Independence Square from 1pm due to the funeral.
Accordingly, vehicular traffic entry to Independence Avenue has been restricted from Independence Roundabout and foundation Road.
Police also said that vehicular traffic entry to Independence Square will be stopped from Administrative junction.
Independence Avenue and all roads to Independence Square will also be closed from 2.30 pm.

hits._id: Joint Opposition says Parliament was prorogued to undermine issues

_source.content:
Various views are being expressed regarding the proclamation to prorogue Parliament for the first time in several decades.
The President issued the order under powers vested in him by Article 70 of the Constitution.
Joint Opposition Group Leader Dinesh Gunawardana said that this would cause several political issues in the future.
However, State Minister Ajith P. Perera speaking to media following a programme in Kalutara said that this would give a fresh start to the government.
The next session will commence on 8th of May while the SLFP is also to decide in the meantime if they are to leave the Unity Government or not.
The second session of the current parliament will, therefore, commence with the President taking the Chair to make a special statement on the government’s action plan.
There has been a single instance in history where the Parliament had to be dissolved after the action plan has been presented.
This was in 1964 where a group of SLFP MP’s voted along with the UNP against the action plan resulting in the dissolution of Parliament.
