hits._id: New laws imposed governing use of pesticides

_source.content:
The Ministry of Health states that the government has decided to mint new laws governing the use of pesticides.

The ministry noted that pesticides manufactured at substandard levels have resulted in causing a myriad of health related issues.

According to the Ministry of Health around 10,000 are hospitalised annually while around 2000 out of this figure are said to die due to various ailments.

hits._id: Nurse's officers association objects midwifery training committee.

_source.content: The Government Nursing Officers’ Association refuses to accept the committee appointed by the Health Ministry to take a decision regarding the midwifery training for the nursing officers.Speaking to a media briefing held in Colombo today, the chairman of the association Saman Ratnapriya said the Health Ministry did not inform their association regarding the appointment of the committee.However, when inquired from the Government Midwife Services Association, its secretary Devika Kodituwakku said they are ready to accept the committee.Meanwhile, the Deputy Health Minister Lalith Dissanayake told our news team that all factions should support the committee instead of protesting against them.

hits._id: Mother tongue, religion and history compulsory for Local students in International and private schools.

_source.content:
The Government had decided to make compulsory the mother tongue, religion and history to local students who are attending international and private schools in the island.
 
The Cabinet also gave its approval to amend the necessary educational Act to empower the Ministry authorities to regulate and monitor the international and private school curriculum.
 
The Government has also decided to set up a Private School Unit with legislative powers under the purview of the Ministry of Education in order to make observations over the manner the international and private schools teaching students these subjects in the future.

hits._id: A supplementary estimate of 144.42 million for vehicles and housing for MP’s and Ministers

_source.content: A supplementary estimate of 144.2 million rupees was presented to parliament today to procure vehicles and refurbishment of houses of government ministers and MPs. Government chief Whip Minister Gayantha Karunathilaka table the estimate. At the same time, a tense situation erupted as leader of the house minister Lakshman Kiriella objected Joint Opposition MP Dinesh Gunawardana’s questioning why shop spaces at Ampara Bus Terminal are not provided to the residents in the area.

hits._id: A scheme to impose tax on fertilizer and water – says former President Mahinda Rajapaksa #GenElecSL

_source.content: Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that the current government is engaged in a scheme to impose tax on fertilizer and water.He stated this during his address at a public rally held at Kekirawa public ground yesterday.Addressing the rally, former Minister S.M. Chandrasena said that the votes of the North and the East are not essential to form a government.

hits._id: UNP questions government's stance regarding Minister Maithreepala's statement

_source.content:
The United National Party today called into question the government’s stance with regards to the recent statement made by Minister Maithreepala Sirisena in which he mentioned threats to the safety of his life.

UNP MP Gayantha Karunathilleke addressing a media briefing held in Colombo today noted that the government should take immediate steps to ensure the security of Minister Maithreepala Sirisena.

hits._id: President Sirisena to visit Pakistan tomorrow

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena will undertake a 3-day visit to Pakistan beginning from tomorrow (Mar. 22), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.
 
He has been invited by the President of Pakistan Mamnoon Hussain to attend the National Day of Pakistan.
 
President Sirisena will hold discussions with his Pakistani counterpart President Hussain, Prime Minister Shahid Khaqan Abbasi.
 
He will attend the signing of four Memoranda of Understanding on Youth Development between Sri Lanka and Pakistan, between the Bandaranaike International Diplomatic Training Institute of Sri Lanka and the Foreign Service Academy of Pakistan, between the Institute of National Security Studies of Sri Lanka and the Institute of Strategic Studies Islamabad and between the Sri Lanka Institute of Development Administration and National School of Public Policy, Pakistan.
 
During his visit, President Sirisena will declare open the re-furbished International Buddhist Centre in the diplomatic enclave in Islamabad.

hits._id: Update: Would parliament be dissolved tonight?

_source.content: There is speculation in the political circle today whether parliament will be dissolved tonight.However, several UNP and SLFP senior members told our news team that they are not clearly aware of such a decision.However, many people believe that parliament would be dissolved tonight.At the same time, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera confirmed to our news team that a Cabinet meeting would be held this evening as usual.A rumor began to spread after certain government top stakeholders hinted of dissolving parliament, during discussions with minority parties.Meanwhile, views about dissolving parliament tonight or a few days later were expressed inside and outside of parliament today.Participating in the adjourning debate over the 20th amendment, former minister D.E.W. Gunasekera concluded his speech stating that it could be his last speech in parliament.      Meanwhile, leader of the house and minister Lakshman Kiriella answered MP Dinesh Gunawardana with regard to the latter’s question about former president Mahinda Rajapaksa’s security details.At this juncture, speaker Chamal Rajapaksa’s intervention also posed a hint about dissolving parliament tonight.Another dialogue between JVP MP Sunil Handunnetti and Minister Joseph Michael Perera also concluded with rising speculations that the parliament would be dissolved tonight.At the same time, journalists enquired foreign minister Mangala Samaraweera during a media conference held in Colombo today whether the parliament is dissolved tonight.Meanwhile, Minister S.B. Dissanayake told a media conference convened by the SLFP today that the President expects to dissolve parliament after the 20th Amendment is passed in parliament this evening.At the same time, SLFP Media Spokesman and former minister Dilan Perera said that the parliament should be dissolved after passing the 20th Amendment.He stated this during a media conference convened by Socialist People Front in Colombo this afternoon.Update: Wednesday, 24 June 2015 - 19:36---------------------------------------------------Party leader Hakeem makes an aggressive speech in ParliamentSLMC face trouble by rejecting former President Mahinda RajapakseThe SLMC Leader Rauff Hakeem told in parliament today that he was entrapped in a different issue by working to defeat former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.Urban Development and Water Supple Minister Rauff Hakeem stated this by opening the adjourning debate on new electoral system today.During his aggressive speech, minister Hakeem stated the Opposition leader and the Chief Whip of the Opposition hinted yesterday that he has become cat’s paw of the Prime Minister.Rejecting such allegations, minister Hakeem said that the UNP also has a selfish goal. Referring to a backroom clique, he said that a particular minister is behaving like a dictator in the ministerial sub committee for changing of electoral system.He also said that the authority which gazatted the 20th Amendment should be enquired from that particular backroom clique.He stressed he did not accept, that only the preferential system is changed under the 20th Amendment. Nobody has behaved in such a dictatorship manner during such occasion in the past. Even though his proposals are not accept, an opportunity should at least be given to discuss them. He also said that certain television channels have been leased to publicize that the same number of seats are allocated under the new electoral system as well.He introduced such system as a march towards Constitutional authoritarian ship. Minister Hakeem also warned that the SLFP should beware of these dictatorial persons.

hits._id: Government Printer to appear before bonds commission today

_source.content:
Acting Government printer, has been summoned to the Presidential Commission Investigating the Bond Issue, in order to resolve the problem that has arisen with regard to the date of the gazette notification issued under the current government on the treasury bonds.
Acting government printer Gangani Liyanage is to be produced before the commission at 10 am today.
The former additional director of central bank debt department Mohammed Aseem has also been summoned.
The commission temporally halted its action due to an issue that arose with regard to a circular issued on the treasury bonds last Thursday.
Secretary to the ministry of finance Dr. H.S Samaratunga who was summoned to the commission for the hearing of evidences noted that the circular on the treasury bonds was issued on the 1st of January 2015.
It was revealed that this was issued during the former president Mahinda Rajapaksa and the former minister of finance time in office.
Meanwhile, the Joint Opposition has organized a protest to be launched this morning in front of the central bank in Colombo stating that evidences relating to the presidents commission investigating the bond issue are not being heard in an unbiased manner.

hits._id: Liquor shops, slaughter houses, race bookies, casinos and clubs closed for 2 days.

_source.content: The government has also instructed to shut down all Liquor shops, slaughter houses, Meat sales outlets, race bookies, casinos and clubs for the next two days.State Administration and Internal Affairs Ministry has advised all provincial Chief Secretaries and District Secretaries regarding the matter.The government declared a Vesak week from 11th to 17th of the month.This year’s theme will be ‘Practice good conduct through Dhamma’.

hits._id: JO requests for MR premiership

_source.content:
Joint Opposition’s (JO) MP Kumar Welgama says former President Mahinda Rajapaksa should be appointed as the Prime Minister in order to protect the SLFP. 
Addressing a meeting in Agalawatta yesterday, he said that the 96 elected MPs of the UPFA could form a SLFP government if they obtained the support of a group, serving in the current government.
 Meanwhile addressing a public gathering in Matale, Deputy Minister Nandimitra Ekanayake said the current government will not collapse even if its SLFP members withdrew.

hits._id: "SLFP will not join UNP to contest LG polls" - Duminda

_source.content: SLFP General Secretary Minister Duminda Dissanayake says that they would contest as a broad alliance at the forthcoming local government election. Following a discussion at the Presidential Secretariat today (03), he said that they would not contest together with the UNP. SLFP Ministers and MP’s as well as electoral organizers participated in the discussion, held under the patronage of the President Maithripala Sirisena. Although invitations were sent to Joint Opposition MP’s as well they were absent.However, the JO had sent a letter signed by 42 members citing 7 conditions for them to consider joining to work with the SLFP. Meanwhile, Minister Gayantha Karunathilaka said that the UNP would contest the forthcoming Local Government elections as the United National Front. This was in response to questions raised by journalists at a media briefing held at Sirikotha regarding the statement made by Minister Rajitha Senarathna that the two main parties will contest together. Meanwhile, Minister Gayantha Karunathilaka stated that double standards of the Joint Opposition were obvious during the debate on the Constitutional Assembly Steering Committee Interim Report.

_source.content:
The JVP states that the verdict given by the Court of Appeal should be adhered to with regard to the impeachment against the chief justice.

JVP MP Vijith Herath made this statement while speaking at a press conference held at the Party Headquarters.


			   
			   		
	
			   

However, deputy speaker Chandima Weerakkody stated that he will act according to the ruling made by the speaker.


			   
			   		
	
			   

Meanwhile, the UNP advisory council has convened as of now under the patronage of party leader Ranil Wickramasinghe to discuss the future steps to be taken with regard to the impeachment.

It is reported that the party general secretary will make a special statement with regard to the decisions taken at this meeting.

However, speaking at a press conference recently JVP Politburo member MP Anura Kumara Dissanayaka made the following statement regarding the actions of the UNP.


			   
			   		
	
			   

Speaking to our news team, Deputy General Secretary of the UNP MP Jayalath Jayawardena responded in the following manner.


			   
			   		
	
			   

MP Anura Kumara Dissanayaka expressed to following views regarding the supremacy of the parliament.


			   
			   		
	
			   

MP Jayalath Jayawardena responded in the following manner to MP Dissanayaka’s comment.

hits._id: Wannila Aththo makes a request for a ministry

_source.content:
Veddha Chieftain Uruwarige Wannila Aththo says that government should assign the matters concerning the indigenous community to a separate ministry.
He stated this at the indigenous community day celebrations in Mahiyanganaya- Morabedda yesterday.

hits._id: Provide the parties views about Geneva resolutions within 2 weeks

_source.content: The president has requested the all – party conference to submit within two weeks the views of the political parties on the Geneva Resolutions.The Presidential Media Division said that the parties that participated in the conference had expressed their consensus to do so.The all-party conference seeking the views of party leaders on the way the Government should act with regard to the Geneva Resolution was held at the Presidential Secretariat last afternoon.At this conference there was common consensus to hold this all – party conference in the future as well.Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, Opposition Leader R. Sampandan and representatives of 21 political parties’ representing the parliament participated in the All Party conference.Three representatives including the general secretary of each political party had the opportunity to participate in the conference.In addition, representatives from JVP, SLMC and EPDP also joined the All Party Conference.Although Lanka Samasamaja Party and Democratic Party do not represent parliament, the party leaders Dr. Tissa Vitharana and Field Marshal Sarath Fonseka also joined the all party conference.

hits._id: Government Doctors work at Private Hospitals is unethical

_source.content: The Minister of Health & Indigenous Medicine Dr. Rajitha Senarathne stated that severe action will be taken against those Government Doctors who work at Private Hospitals on their working hours.Accordingly, the Ministry is expecting to start raiding at Private and Government Hospitals to put an end to this unethical practice, the Minister added.Similarly Government employed Doctors working at Private Hospitals on their duty time will be subjected to legal action he emphasized. This law will be common for all Specialist Doctors, Administrative Doctors, and Medical Officials similarly.

hits._id: Impermanent world has no permanent designations says Minister Maithreepala

_source.content:
Minister of Health Maithreepala Sirisena states that in an impermanent
world there are no permanent personalities or designations.

Speaking at the Suwa-Kala award presentation ceremony which was held at the Ministry of Health yesterday, Minister Sirisena added that despite having received many accolades, it is fruitless if one had failed to obtain the accolades of the public.


			   
			   		
	
			   

Meanwhile the Frontline Socialist Party made a revelation regarding the dreams of parliamentarian Anura Kumara Dissanayeke.

hits._id: President says that there is a programme to face the drought

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that although the Government cannot control the drought, there is a clear progarmme for facing it and providing relief to people affected by it. The President said so while addressing several conferences representing women organized under the theme  “ Rata Rakina Nil Pavura” yesterday.On this occasion the President said that the Government was now in the process of bringing about also the economic victory to the people.The President also said that the current Government had done a huge amount of development work on behalf of women in a manner that no Government had done up to now.

hits._id: The Election Commissioner goes to Human Rights Commission  101 election rule violators arrested

_source.content:
A discussion is being held between Election Commissioner Mahinda Deshapriya and the heads of the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission.
A Human Rights Commission spokesman said that DIG in-charge of Election duties Gamini Navarathna, several officials of the Ministry of Law and Order and the Defence Ministry are also participating in the discussion.
Human Rights Commission Chief Dr. Prathibha Mahanama Hewa told our news team that today’s discussion will take special emphasis on the deployment of government servants on election campaigns.
Meanwhile Acting Police Media Spokesman SSP Ajith Rohana said that more policemen will be deployed in the areas where a higher number of election rule violations are reported from.
He also said that 101 election rule violators have already been arrested, and the highest number of election related complaints was made against each other by candidates of a same party.

hits._id: An attempt to distance the Muslims from the government - says President.

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapakse states that attempts are made within the country to distance the Muslims from the Government.

President points out that no matter who tries to achieve narrow political gains, Muslims who remember the history will never distance from the government.

President made this statement while addressing the Muslim community in Kandy at temple trees.

hits._id: President hints of a Cabinet reshuffle

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena stated today that he is ready to make a change in the fisheries portfolio. President Sirisena was speaking at a ceremony organized to distribute freehold land deeds at the Maagam Ruhunpura International Conference hall today.

hits._id: TNA supports the new constitution

_source.content:
Reports state that the Tamil National alliance will continue to support the ongoing process to draft a new constitution for Sri Lanka despite internal dissensions.
The TNA, which met twice last week, decided to accept leader R. Sampanthan’s advice, that despite doubts about getting a favourable outcome from the constitution-making process, the process should be supported because there is no alternative.
Sampanthan’s plea for cooperation also rested on the hope that the personal and explicit commitment of President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe to promoting ethnic reconciliation through appropriate constitutional provisions would stay through the process and influence the final outcome.

hits._id: Displaced in North to receive poll rights

_source.content:
The government is drawing plans to introduce a new act before parliament which will enable those who are displaced in the countries North to cast their ballots during the upcoming provincial polls.
 
The proposal in this regard which was presented to parliament by Minister Rauff Hakeem, if sanctioned would enable displaced persons in the North since 1983 to cast their ballots in their original places of settlement.
 
According to a spokesperson from the Ministry of Justice, if a displaced individual is able to prove his or her status as IDP, their names would in turn be included in a special voters name list.
 
Meanwhile, various views are being expressed by political parties with regards to the upcoming Northern Provincial polls.
 
UNP MP & Party General Secretary Thissa Aththanayeke who addressed a gathering in Manikhinna today observed that if the government fails to host the upcoming Northern polls appropriately, such a situation would give rise to a myriad of issues.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Meanwhile certain political parties are of the opinion that polls in the North should be held subsequent to a revision on the 13th amendment to the constitution which withdraws police & land powers vested within the Northern provincial council.
 
The following are views expressed in this regard by General Secretary of the UNP MP Thissa Athanayeke, Minister Wimal Weerawansa, Parliamentarian Vijitha Herath, Leader of the DNA Sarath Foseka & JHU Leader Venerable Omalpe Sobhitha Thero.

hits._id: Agricultural Economy will be strengthened under new regime - says Common Candidate Maithreepala Sirisena

The 16 Sri Lanka Freedom Party members who recently quit the Unity Government say they will have a discussion with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa this Sunday (May 20).
 
Addressing a media conference in Colombo this morning, a member of the group, former Minister, Lakshman Yapa Abeywardana disclosed it.
 
Meanwhile, MP Dayasiri Jayasekera said they are not a part of the government now.

hits._id: A speedy investigation by govt with regard to the attack on fishermen in front of the fisheries Ministry.-Video

_source.content: The Government has decided to hold an immediate investigation about the pelting of stones at the fishermen engaged in an agitation in front of the Fisheries Ministry at Maligawatta in Colombo.A Government spokesman said that he expresses his regrets with regard to the incident faced by the fisher folk at a Government premise.The spokesman said further the Government’s attention had even now been drawn on the incident.It is also significant that many have condemned the attack a group loitering at the Ministry premises had directed at the group of fishermen engaged in an agitation in front of the fisheries Ministry at Maligawatta in Colombo.Deputy Fisheries Minister Sarath Kumara Gunaratna also said that he apologizes to the persons concerned with regard to the attack.Fishermen and multi-day trawler owners from Chilaw, Kalpitya, Negombo and Wennappuwa totaling more than 500 staged an agitation in front of the Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Ministry day-before-yesterday.This agitation asking for eight demands including the banning of foreign trawlers engaged in fishing within Sri Lankan boundaries was organized by the All Island Fisheries Union.Tension cropped up when a stones were hurled suddenly from the direction of the Fisheries Ministry at the fishermen staging the agitation,While four fishermen engaged in the agitation sustained injuries, the fishermen charged that hooligans staying in the Ministry premises had attacked them.Expressing his views about the incident Minister Dayaasrita Thissera too told our news team that he condemns the attack directed at the fishermen.

However after the discussion finance minister Ravi Karunanayaka calling a special media brief at the parliament complex stated that the allocation offunds to the provincial councils has been done according to the constitution.

hits._id: No agreement with IMF on education; Minister Bandula replies to Opposition Leader-Video

_source.content: Education Minister Bandula Gunawardana said that the government has not signed any agreement with the IMF to slash education in the country.The Minister convened a media briefing in Colombo today to reply to Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe’s statement which he made yesterday. Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe told a group of professionals in the education sector yesterday that the MoU between the IMF and the government will be annulled under a future UNP government.Speaking during a media briefing held in Colombo today regarding the statement made by the Opposition Leader, Minister Bandula Gunawardana stated that he personally inquired from the President regarding the matter.According to the Minister, the President has clearly mentioned that if the allegation is proved true he will immediately resign from office.

hits._id: No opposition at ETCA discussions- National Policy Ministry

_source.content:
The Ministry of National Policy and Economic Affairs says that news reports alleging professionals walked out from discussions on ETCA scheduled to be signed with India were false.
Issuing a statement the Ministry said the Government is still holding discussions about ETCA with professionals, business associations and trade unions.
The Government is also holding discussions with India, China and Singapore to reach economic and trade agreements.
The Government’s policy is to make Sri Lanka the economic hub of the Indian Ocean.
The statement also says that the aim of these discussions is to create 200,000 jobs and revamp the rural economy.
The Ministry said that the news reports charging that revenue proposals have been removed from the national development plan were also not true.

hits._id: A UNP MP prepares to self immolate in the parliament chambers

_source.content: A Badulla District UNP MP Vadival Suresh told parliament today that he will self immolate inside the chambers tomorrow if the government does not take action to increase the wages of estate workers. The MP made the hostile statement during the committee level debate on the heads of eight ministries including Plantation Industry, Telecommunication and Digital Infrastructure and Internal Affairs are discussed during the committee level debate in parliament today.

hits._id: New port city agreement signed by 3 parties

_source.content:
The tripartite agreement to build the proposed Colombo Port City after renaming the previous project as New International Financial City was signed this afternoon.
The three signatories to the new agreement are Western Province Development Ministry, Urban Development Authority and CHEC Port city Colombo Private Limited.
Accordingly, the agreement signed for the Colombo Port City on September 16th, 2014 will be replaced by the new agreement.
Under the new agreement signed today, 269 hectares of the sea off the South of Galle Face ground will be filled to build the proposed financial city.
36 more hectares than that of the total hectares given for the project has been granted under the new agreement. 
However the government stated earlier that land hold of none of the filled lands will be given to foreigners.
Once the new financial city is completed, it will be managed under a new parliament Act titled Colombo International Financial Center Act to be passed in parliament.

hits._id: President talks about Presidential election.

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa has completed his fourth year in office under the second term today.He was elected to parliament from Beliatta electorate for the first time in 1970.Later, he was sworn in as the 5th Executive President of Sri Lanka on November 19th, 2005.He launched the humanitarian operation in 2006, and within two and half years, his government was able to eliminate LTTE terrorism from the country.In 2010, he called an early presidential election two years ahead of the scheduled time, and secured a victory of 57.88% and sworn in as the President again for another six years.President Rajapaksa expects to contest for a third term under the 18th Amendment to the Constitution.

hits._id: President meets with UN Secretary General; discussions held on Sri Lanka’s future

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena who is currently in New York to participate in the United Nations General Assembly has met with UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon yesterday.

Our Correspondent in New York Hishan Welmilla stated that the meeting took place at 10AM New Time yesterday.

Discussions had focussed on the future outlook for Sri Lanka.

President Maithripala Sirisena had also held discussions with Commonwealth Secretary General Kamalesh Sharma, and Pakistan’s Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.

hits._id: No ISIS In Sri Lanka: Sagala Rathnayake

_source.content:
ISIS operations are not carried out in Sri Lanka and the Government has taken adequate measures to prevent foreign terrorist organizations from making use of Sri Lanka, the Minister of Law and Order and Southern Development Sagala Ratnayaka confirmed to Parliament yesterday.
Creating a religious dialogue and awareness with the co-ordination of Muslim politicians, religious leaders, Ministry of Education, Department of Muslim Religious and Cultural Affairs and civil organizations such as All Ceylon Jamiyathul Ulma (ACJU) and National Shoora Council are the key measures the Government has taken in order to dissuade the Muslim community from joining in extremist activities.
According to the Minister, necessary action is now underway with the assistance of teachers as well as parents to represent all the communities at schools. Supervision of the immigration and emigration system for identified extremists in the country and people who return from countries known for terrorism after engaging in foreign education, occupations or other activities is also a measure properly in place. Adding more to the list, the Government has also prevented the propaganda spread of extremist ideas though social media, and taken proper measures against this by deactivating accounts that spread ISIS ideas, as well as taking legal action against any lecturers or institutions who propagate such extremist ideas.

hits._id: LTTE banned for further 5 years in India

hits._id: Relax travel advisory to Sri Lanka ; Ministry of External Affairs requests of UK

_source.content:
The Sri Lankan government has urged the British Foreign and Commonwealth office to tone down a travel advice on Sri Lanka which was updated last month.
External Affairs Ministry spokesman Rodney Perera said that the Sri Lankan High Commission in London is pursuing the matter with the British authorities.
The Sri Lankan government had last September raised concerns with the British government over the travel advice and urged them to amend it.
Tourism industry officials in Sri Lanka had raised concerns over the impact the travel advice may have on British tourists visiting Sri Lanka.

hits._id: Former President reveals a new betrayal by government

_source.content:
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa says that the government has produced a draft bill in parliament to amend the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act No. 25 of 2002.
 
The former President in his communiqué further emphasizes that the structure of the initial act will change significantly with many clauses being changed through the new draft bill.
The prevailing law is only applicable to nations while the amendment will facilitate the infiltration of organizations such as the International Criminal Court.
The former President highlights that the proposed amendment is coupled with the Office on Missing Persons Act which was previously introduced by the present government and the Act which was brought forward to enforce the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance, in Sri Lanka.
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa in his communiqué further notes that the draft bill will facilitate the implementation of the provisions in the International Convention for the Protection of All Persons from Enforced Disappearance Act No 5 of 2018.
A mechanism should be in place to obtain evidence from Sri Lanka for a case that is being heard in another country regarding crimes that are said to have taken place in Sri Lanka.
Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa in his communiqué thus stresses that the objective of the proposed amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act of 2002 is in fact, to pave way for such a mechanism.
Meanwhile, the former president stated that the general public will respond in the near future to the suppressive programme adopted by the government to imprison leaders in the opposition.
The former president made this comment addressing a ceremony at the Jumma Mosque in Mukarawewa – Horowpathaana this morning.

hits._id: Prime Minister agrees to SLFP proposals

_source.content:
Minister Susil Premajayantha says that Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe agreed to the proposals made by the SLFP with regard to the new Constitution.
President Maithripala Sirisena, in his capacity as the chairman of the party appointed a committee to decide the stance of the SLFP over the Premier’s proposal to set up a new Constitution.
Minister Premajayantha stated that the Premier has agreed to the nine amendments proposed by the SLFP.
 He also said that the abolishing of the Executive Presidency and amending the parliament election system have been given priority in the party proposals.
SLFP has already handed over its proposals to the Speaker.
Meanwhile the JVP says that different political camps seem to be using the new Constitution to hide their political incompetence.  Addressing a media conference held in Colombo today, party leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake further described the situation.
He further said that all political parties that represent parliament should be given equal opportunity in the new Constitution.
Meanwhile Samajawadi Janatha Peramuna says that it will not object to the new Constitution in the event it ensures social dignity and freedom to all communities.
Addressing a media conference held in Colombo, MP Chandrasiri Gajadheera further expressed his views on the matter.
At the same time, addressing another media conference, Pivituru Hela Urumaya leader and MP Udaya Gammanpila said that the amendments to the Constitution should be brought as 20, 21 and 22nd  Amendments to abolish the Executive Presidency, Electoral system and devolution of power.

hits._id: Diplomats Tour Underdeveloped Areas In Polonnaruwa

_source.content:
A group of foreign representatives, including 33 Ambassadors and High Commissioners visited underdeveloped areas in the Polonnaruwa district Monday (March 14) with the aim of providing aid to develop these areas.
The delegation commenced their tour from the Medirigiriya, Meegaswewa area and inspected the areas including Wadigawewa, Godapoththa, and Palliyagodalla.
President Maithripala Sirisena hosted a lunch for the delegation in Polonnaruwa.
Following the lunch, the diplomats visited the Mahawelitanna village in the Welikanda Divisional Secretariat as well as the Sinhapura School and Muslim and Tamil villages in Kudapokuna.
The delegation included Ambassadors and High Commissioners of Japan, Netherlands, Canada, Germany, Switzerland, Myanmar, Iran, Brazil, Korea, Italy, Pakistan, Egypt, Vietnam and Maldives.
Local Government and Provincial Councils, Minister Faizer Mustapha has organized the tour.

hits._id: Government services disrupted due the strike by doctors and professionals

_source.content:
State services including health services were disrupted today after 18 professional trade unions launched an island wide strike in protest of curtailing benefits for government servants.
The strike which started at 8 o’clock this morning throughout the country has badly affected the functions of government hospitals including the Colombo National Hospital thereby brining OPD services and clinics to standstill.
GMOA General Secretary Nalin de Herath told our news team that the strike is a success today.
In addition to GMOA, 17 other trade unions including Engineers, Accountants, Educational Administration, Auditing, Inland Revenue and Survey have also joined the strike today.
Officers of the Sri Lanka Administrative Service have also resorted to work to rule trade union action in protest of the curtailing of their benefits by the budget.

hits._id: India assists to rescue Lankans in Yemen

_source.content: Due to the volatile situation in Yemen, the Government of Sri Lanka said it is making arrangements to evacuate all Sri Lankans in Yemen.The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement  that the Ministry in coordination with the Sri Lanka Embassy in Muscat, Oman, is exploring all possible avenues to ensure the safe return of the Sri Lankans.Reportedly there are around 120 Sri Lankan expatriates, including students in Yemen and they are principally residing in the capital, Sana'a and other main cities, such as Hodeida, Aden and Mukalla.The Sri Lanka Mission in Muscat is in contact with some Sri Lankans in Yemen, who are directly monitoring the welfare of the Sri Lankans in their present locations, the Ministry said.The government has also sought the assistance of the UN Office in Sana'a and the International Organization for Migration in Colombo in the evacuation efforts.The Ministry said it continues to closely monitor the situation in Yemen and is making every effort to ensure the safe evacuation of Sri Lankans in Yemen back home.Meanwhile, the Indian Government has promptly agreed to the request of the Government of Sri Lanka to bring the stranded Sri Lankans along with Indian nationals in Yemen, who are to be evacuated by special flights and ships.Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ajith P. Perera, instructed the Sri Lanka High Commission in New Delhi and the Sri Lanka Embassy in Muscat to communicate with the Ministry of External Affairs of India and the Indian Embassies in Muscat and Sana'a to coordinate the evacuation process.Families of the Sri Lankans in Yemen have been requested to provide the contact details of their relatives to the Ministry. 2 hot lines are available and the numbers are  0115839414 / 0112323015.

hits._id: Final decision on electricity tariff concession to be announced today; Opposition asks further relief.

_source.content:
Ceylon Electricity Board Chairman W.B.Ganegala said that the government will come to a final agreement on the adjustments to the revised electricity tariffs today.
 
The CEB earlier decided to implement the new tariffs with effect from April 20 under the recommendations given by the Public Utilities Commission.
 
But President Mahinda Rajapaksa addressing the UPFA May Day rally in Colombo said yesterday that no tariffs would be hiked for the consumers using upto 60 units and concessions would be granted to others using upto 180 units.
 
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
 
However Opposition political parties staged various protests against the revised electricity tariffs in and out of parliament during the last few days.
 
Even the UPFA coalitions too proposed the government to grant some relief to electricity consumers.
 
Our news team contacted several party officials to get their comments on the relief announced by the President on May Day yesterday.
 
UNP General Secretary Tissa Attanayake was first to express his views to our news team:
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
 
When contacted the JVP, its polite bureau member MP Anura Kumara Dissanayake expressed his views to our news team.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
 
Leader of a government coalition Democratic Leftists Front, Minister Vasudeva Nanayakkara said that he applaud the decision taken by the President to give relief to the consumers.

hits._id: President makes special statement on Bond report

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena made a special statement on the report and the recommendations of the Presidential Commission of Inquiry that probed the alleged bond scam.The President said that he would take actions to retrieve the losses amounting to Rs. 11,145 million from those who are accused of the bond scam.He added that steps will be taken to move legal action against the accused.The Commission report said that the Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe should not have acted upon promises given by the then Governor of the Central Bank, Arjuna Mahendran.The Commission has also recommended filing cases against former Minister Ravi Karunanayake, who had given false evidence, under the Bribery and Corruption Act and the Penal Code. The President also said that the Commission report has already been sent to the Attorney General recommending future legal actions through the Criminal Investigation Department and Bribery Commission. The Commission has also recommended probing the bond issuances took place during the 2008-2015 period.The Presidential Commission of Inquiry on the alleged bond scam handed over their report to President Maithripala Sirisena on 30th of December.Here is the statement of President:President's full statement:

hits._id: Prime Minister addresses the South Asian Diaspora Convention in Singapore today

_source.content:
Sri Lanka and Singapore will sign several bilateral agreements during Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe's three-day official visit to Singapore at the invitation of Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.
A possible Sri Lanka-Singapore Free Trade Agreement is being studied as both countries are keen to pursue the deal to enhance bilateral trade.
The FTA is expected to comprise of commitments in trade in goods, services, investment and government procurement, according to Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry.
During the visit, Prime Minister Wickremesinghe will deliver the Special Address at the Third South Asian Diaspora Convention, organized by the Institute of South Asian Studies today.
He will also meet with Singaporian business leaders at an event organized by International Enterprise, Singapore tomorrow.

hits._id: Expedite the report regarding the death of the two Jaffna students; President instructs Attorney General

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has instructed the Attorney General to expedite the post-mortem report of the two university students who were killed in Kokkuvil, Jaffna on 21st October. 
The President said that action would be taken to grant compensation to the families of the students concerned, after the report is received. 
Jaffna University Vice Chancellor, lecturers and student representatives met the President yesterday and held a discussion regarding the murders.
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and minister of Rehabilitation, Resettlement and Hindu Religious Affairs D. M. Swaminathan also participated in the discussion. 
On this occasion the student representatives requested that the President have the post-mortem report issued without delay.

hits._id: Update : Discussion on Midwifery training dispute fails; says 2 unions GMOA and a union still in discussion. : Video

_source.content: Three trade unions who participated in today’s discussion to find a solution to the midwifery training dispute said that talks failed.The Government Nursing Officers Association, the All Ceylon Nurses Association and the Government Family Health Services Officers Association held discussions today.Following the discussions held at the National Blood Center in Narahenpita, the unions said the Government Service United Nurses Association and the GMOA wanted further discussions regarding the issue.Meanwhile a Health Ministry spokesman told our news team that the Government Service United Nurses Association and the GMOA will hold another discussion soon following which a decision will be reached regarding the midwifery training dispute.Update : Friday, 02 May 2014 - 07:11 PM----------------------------------------------------A discussion with the health Minister about the Midwifery training issue.The Government Nursing Officers Association and the Government Family Health Services Association said that none of the unions have been invited to the discussion organized by the Health Minister to discuss on the current dispute between the two factions.However it is stated that the Government Medical Officers Association and the Government Service United Nurses Association have been invited.Health Minister Maithreepala Sirisena said during a media briefing yesterday that a meeting is arranged to discuss the prevailing midwifery training dispute this afternoon.GMOA Central Committee member Dr. Nalinda Herath said that representatives of his Association would participate in today’s meeting.Government Service United Nurses Association’s President Muruththettuwe Ananda Thera said that although his organization received an invitation, a decision whether to participate in the meeting will be taken today.Government Nursing Officers Association’s President Saman Rathnapriya said that if an invitation is extended, his representatives will definitely participate in the meeting.At the same time, Government Family Health Services Association has also not been invited to the meeting.Meanwhile the Nursing strike that started at Kurunegala hospital has spread to several others hospitals in the island.Update : Friday, 02 May 2014 - 8:01------------------------------------------------------Only 2 nurses associations invited for Ministers discussion over Midwifery training disputeThe Government Nursing Officers Association and the Government Family Health Services Association said that none of the unions have been invited to the discussion organized by the Health Minister to talk on the current dispute between the two factions.However it is stated that the Government Medical Officers Association and the Government Service United Nurses Association have been invited.Health Minister Maithreepala Sirisena said during a media briefing yesterday that a meeting is arranged to discuss the prevailing midwifery training dispute tomorrow afternoon.GMOA Central Committee member Dr. Nalinda Herath said that representatives of his Association would participate in tomorrow’s meeting.Government Service United Nurses Association’s President Muruththettuwe Ananda Thera said although his organization received an invitation, a decision whether to participate in the meeting will be taken tomorrow morning.Government Nursing Officers Association’s President Saman Rathnapriya said that if an invitation is extended, his representatives will definitely participate in the meeting.At the same time, Government Family Health Services Association has also not been invited to the meeting.Meanwhile the Nursing strike that started at Kurunegala hospital has spread to several others hospitals in the island.Although Government Nursing Officers Association claimed their trade union actions affected the Colombo National Hospital, a senior hospital official said that the routine work of the hospital continues as usual.However functions of the Accident Ward and the ICU of the Kurunegala hospital have been affected due to the nursing strike.

hits._id: Bandula Gunawardena's Request For Debate Turned Down

_source.content:
The cabinet rejected Parliamentarian Banndula Gunawardena’s request to have a discussion regarding the unacceptability of allocation of insufficient funds through the budget for education. 
Parliamentarian Bandula Gunawardena produced this proposal to the cabinet today morning under order 17.  The deputy speaker stated that the request regarding the above cannot be granted.
However a tensed situation arose in the parliament as soon as Parliamentarian Bandula Gunawardena produced this proposal.

hits._id: Russia’s Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs commends the friendship between President Maithripala Sirisena and President Vladimir Putin

_source.content:
Russia’s Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Igor Morgulov stated that the friendship between President Maithripala Sirisena and Russian President Vladimir Putin is a turning point for the bilateral relations between the two countries.
President’s Media Unit stated that the deputy minister made this remark at a special ceremony held last night to mark 60 years since establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries.
President Maithripala Sirisena has graced the event as the chief guest.

hits._id: Tense situation in Parliament over Petroleum strike

_source.content: A tense situation erupted in parliament today as ruling and Opposition MPs expressed their views over the Petroleum strike. Later, the speaker was compelled to temporarily adjourn parliament sessions. Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe expressed his views about the strike followed by JVP leader Anura Kumara Dissanayake, Joint Opposition MPs Dinesh Gunawardana and Namal Rajapaksa. Meanwhile, the Nation Building Levy Amendment Bill was also passed with amendments in parliament today.

hits._id: Former President says the meanings of words Reconciliation and Good Governance have been distorted

_source.content: Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa accused the government of misinterpreting the words good governance and reconciliation.He expressed these views during a religious ceremony held in Karandeniya area in Galle yesterday.

hits._id: Dengue likely to rise to epidemic level in several areas of Colombo

_source.content: According to the Health Ministry, Dengue fever cases in MHO Divisions of Dehiwala, Kohuwala, Kaduwela, Kolonnawa, Angoda, Moratuwa and Katubedda is likely to rise to an epidemic level.The Ministry has already instructed relevant units to carry out a programme tomorrow in all schools, government offices and other premises within these divisions to probe for dengue breeding grounds.

hits._id: "Maithree Paalanaya Pleases US" - Nisha Bishwal

_source.content: US Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Nisha Biswal said that US President Barack Obama and his administration was pleased with the new type of governance in Sri Lanka.She expressed these comments after calling on President Maithripala Sirisena last afternoon at the Presidential Secretariat.The US Assistant Secretary of State said that the world is talking  about Sri Lanka’s democracy “for all the right reasons”.President Maithripala Sirisena had said during the discussion that a conducive environment has been built to rebuild bilateral ties between Sri Lanka and the US.The President also said that he expected the US to act with proper understanding with regard to issues pertaining to human rights.President Sirisena also stated that Sri Lanka needs to continue its programme of reconciliation and hence requested US Assistant Secretary of State Nisha Biswal to buy time for this purpose.Meanwhile, speaking at another event held in Colombo, President Maithripala Sirisena said that one should not fear to face challenges.

hits._id: The President to address UN General Assembly; Measures to eradicate narcotics will be top on agenda

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena is scheduled to address the UN General Assembly this evening in US time. The President also intends to propose a special program on an international level to eliminate drug abuse, during his address. Meanwhile, a special luncheon was held yesterday hosted by UN Secretary General Ban-ki Moon for the state leaders participating in the 71st session of the UN General Assembly. Several state leaders including President Maithripala Sirisena participated in the event, where US President Barack Obama has informed his Sri Lankan counterpart that the transformation taking place in Sri Lanka sets as an example to the world. The US President has also expressed his wishes to extend support for the country. In addition, President Maithripala Sirisena has met the UN Secretary General Ban-ki Moon and UN High Commissioner Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid Al-Hussein during the event.

hits._id: Foreign Ambassadors called to the Ministry of External Affairs

_source.content:
The External Affairs Ministry is to brief the diplomatic community about Sri Lanka’s current progress and the stance to be adopted at the forthcoming UNHRC sessions.

This briefing will take place at a conference with all High Commissioners and ambassadors stationed in Colombo at the External Affairs Ministry this morning presided by External Affairs Minister Professor G L Peiris.

Ministry Director General of Communications Rodney Perera said during this meeting, Minister Peiris will explain the steps taken by the government to implement LLRC recommendations, the National Action Plan and also steps taken towards the rehabilitation of former LTTE cadres.

Attention would also be drawn towards development activities undertaken by the government including the strengthening of democracy in the Northern Province and the steps taken to recruit new hands to the public service.

hits._id: President invited for Modi's swearing in ceremony

_source.content: Indian media reports that the Indian Government has extended a formal invitation to President Mahinda Rajapaksa to participate in the swearing-in ceremony of Prime Minister - elect of India Narendra Modi.The swearing in ceremony of India's Prime Minister elect is to be held on May 26 at the forecourt of Rastrapathi Bawan.Modi conveyed this wish of his to President Pranab Mukherjee when he met him on Tuesday.The President seemingly welcomed it as a ‘good idea’ and has passed this on to the ministry of external affairs which is now examining the proposal.There is no recent precedent for inviting foreign heads of governments when an Indian prime minister has been sworn in, but Modi has a penchant for doing the most unusual.SAARC nations include Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan.BJP sources say Modi apparently wants to send out through this invitation a “very strong signal of a neighbour-friendly new government.

hits._id: Casino removed from Packer s hotel; a new gazette notification to parliament.

_source.content:
The Investment Promotion Ministry says that under the Strategy Development Act, a new gazette notification will be put forward in the future for providing tax relief for constructing a hotel complex without CASINO.

Strategy Development Ministry Secretary M. M. C. Ferdinandu told our news team that accordingly tax relief would accrue to the hotel project proposed to be constructed at the D. R. Wijewardhana Mawatha in Colombo under a 400 million US dollar investment.

Cabinet approval was given recently to a luxury hotel project with gambling betting facilities belonging to the Crown Casino Group of James Packer of Australian nationality.

Accordingly the gazette notification relevant to it under the Strategy Development Act was scheduled to be debated in parliament last Thursday and Friday.

Several parties representing the Government and Opposition parties too expressed their objection to some clauses pertaining to Casino.

In addition civil organizations and religious leaders too protested against taking up the relevant gazette notification for debate.

However the debate on the relevant gazette notification was postponed on consideration of opinions expressed at discussions held at a meeting of party leaders held with the President at the chair.

However, speaking to our news team Minister Lakshman Yapa Abeywardena stated that the gazette notice will be presented to parliament after it has been amended.

hits._id: Opposition party leaders write to the Speaker

_source.content:
Meanwhile a group of opposition party leaders including the leader of the opposition forwarded a letter to the speaker requesting a meeting to discuss the impeachment debate.

The letter was in protest of the impeachment report being taken up for debate on the 10th and 11th of this month.

The letter had further stated that, both former speaker Anura Bandaranayaka and Justice Amaratunga had clearly stated the powers of the parliament and that only the Supreme Court has the authority to interpret the constitution and that only Supreme Court interpretations of the constitution stands.
The letter was signed by Opposition Leader Ranil Wickramasinghe, Chief Opposition Whip John Amaratunga, Team leader of the Democratic National Movement Anura Kumara Dissanayaka and MPs Vijitha Herath and Mavei Senadhiraja.

However, the UNP has decided to take part in the Parliamentary debate regarding the impeachment report scheduled to be held on the 10th and 11th.

Speaking to our news team UNP MP Ajith P. Perera stated that the decision was taken during the parliamentary team meeting.

TNA MP P. Ariyanendran stated that the Tamila National Alliance will make their decision on whether to take part in the debate or not tomorrow.

JVP MP Vijitha Herath stated that the decision of the JVP will be taken following the meeting with the speaker tomorrow.

Speaking at a meeting in Arndigama in Anumaduwa, SLFP General Secretary Maitreepala Sirisena stated that certain individuals in the judiciary seem to be acting without understanding the limit of their authority.

The United National Party states that the government should apologize to the public.

hits._id: Sri Lanka – Singapore FTA signed

_source.content:
The much looked forward to Free Trade Agreement between Sri Lanka and Singapore was signed at the Presidential Secretariat in Colombo today (Jan. 23).
 
The Free Trade Agreement is expected to boost the trade between the two countries as it would facilitate duty-free access to selected goods and services of each other.
 
The signing of the FTA took place following the bilateral discussions between visiting Prime Minister of Singapore Lee Hsien Loong and President Maithripala Sirisena at the Presidential Secretariat.
 
The Singapore Prime Minister arrived in Sri Lanka yesterday on an invitation extended by the President.
 
The Minister for Development Strategies and International Trade Malik Samarawickrama and S.Iswaran Minister for Trade and Industry of the Republic of Singapore signed the Free Trade Agreement on behalf of the respective Governments, in the presence of President Sirisena, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.

hits._id: Update: President directs to cut gas prices by 250 rupees with effect from tomorrow.-Video

_source.content: President Mahinda Rajapaksa has given directive to reduce the price of a domestic gas by 250 rupees per cylinder with effect from tomorrow.He was speaking at a ceremony organized to mark the Pensioners’ Day held at the Pensioners Holiday Resort at Wedamulla in Kelaniya this morning.President Rajapaksa said the ruling government ended the era in which pensioners were dumped like toothpicks, and meted out justice to them.Meanwhile Cooperative and Internal Trade Ministry stated in a notice that the gazette notification with regard to the new gas price will be issued tonight.The ministry also says that the world gas price has declined to 756 US Dollars per metric ton by now from its previous price in January this year, 1 thousand17 US Dollars per metric ton.The Internal Trade Ministry notice further states that the current domestic gas price 2 thousand 396 rupees will be reduced to 2 thousand 146 rupees per cylinder due to the new price reduction. Update: Thursday, 09 October 2014 - 07:08 PM------------------------------------------------------Domestic gas price reduced by 250 rupees on President's orderPresident Mahinda Rajapaksa has directed Finance Ministry officials to reduce the price of a domestic cylinder of LPG gas by 250 rupees.President’s Media Unit stated that the President has give directive to slash gas price during a ceremony held to mark Pensioners’ Day held at the Pensioners Holiday Resort at Wedamulla in Kelaniya this morning.The current price of a cylinder of domestic LPG gas is 2 thousand 486 rupees.

hits._id: 95% of the landmines in the North and East removed.

_source.content:
The Economic Development Ministry says that 95 per cent of the landmines in the North and East have been removed. 
The Ministry points out that by now the National De-mining Centre is successfully de-mining the North and East. 
The Army Engineering Task Force too is taking part in de-mining the 96 square Kilometers that still remains to be de-mined.
Although the Government wanted to resettle the people after the end of the war, the existence of landmines in certain areas in the North and East was an obstacle for resettlement. 
However the Government is in the process of successfully completing the task of de-mining. 
It is said that Australia, Japan, China, India as well as organizations including the UN have provided assistance to the Government in the task of de-mining.

Members of the Delimitation Committee have visited the ministry to handover the report today but have failed to do so, since the minister is currently overseas and the secretary to the ministry, Kamal Padmasiri has not been in at the time.
Head of the Delimitation Committee Ashoka Peiris speaking to media stated that it was agreed with the secretary to the ministry to handover the report to the Minister of Provincial Councils and Local Government on the 2nd of January.
He furthermore stated that compiling the report was delayed as a result of the lack of facilities available.

hits._id: UPDATE :Video: The first Ranil, Karu, Sajith Powwow ends successfully - a decision to meet again.

_source.content:
A special powwow between Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremasinghe and MPs Sajith Premadasa and Karu Jayasuriya was held at the Opposition Leader’s office last afternoon with regard to the Supreme Council proposed to be appointed by the UNP.
 
In a special release issued the UNP said that at the powwow lengthy discussion was held with regard to the proposed new machinery for putting the party on a victorious path.
 
It was decided at the powwow that further discussion should be held on the subject. 
 
Speaking to media after the powwow MP Karu Jayasuriya said that the discussion had been held in a positive manner with regard to the party’s future.
 
In addition MP Sajith Premadasa who participated in the powwow said that several proposals were presented to Party leader Ranil Wickramasinghe.
 
Speaking to our news team UNP General Secretary Tissa Attanayake said that however the party would hold several rounds of discussion during the next few days and speedily begin the party’s victorious journey.
UPDATE : Wednesday, 16 October 2013 - 7:54 AM
------------------------------------------------------------
Discussions between Ranil, Sajith and Karu begin

The special discussion between parliamentarians Ranil Wickramasinghe, Sajith Premadasa and Karu Jayasuriya regarding the proposed supreme council has begun at the UNP headquarters. 
A senior spokesperson of the UNP stated that the discussion will focus on the number of representatives that will be appointed for the council and its duties. 
In addition the discussion will also focus on the actions the UNP will take during upcoming elections. 
The UNP’s working committee which convened on the 5th of this month gave parliamentarians Ranil Wickramasinghe, Sajith Premadasa and Karu Jayasuriya the authority to engage in discussions regarding the proposed supreme council. 
Although the discussion was scheduled to be held last Thursday it was postponed till today following a request by MP Sajith Premadasa.









Tuesday, 15 October 2013 - 07:05 PM
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ranil, Sajith and Karu meeting today.

A discussion is scheduled to be held between Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremasinghe, and MPs Sajith Premadasa and Karu Jayasuriya today about the proposed Supreme Council. 
A senior UNP spokesman said that discussion was due to be held at this meeting with regard to the number of members to be appointed to the council as well as the role of the council. 
In addition to this, attention would be drawn at this discussion on party operations at future elections. 
At the Working Committee meeting held on 5th this month authority was vested with the Opposition Leader and MPs Sajith Premadasa and Karu Jayasuriya for discussing about this Supreme Council. 
Although that discussion had been scheduled to be held last Thursday it was decided to be held today on the request of MP Sajith Premadasa. 
Tuesday, 15 October 2013 - 08:01 AM

hits._id: Dayasiri fooled us - says the UNP

_source.content:
Addressing journalists, UNP MP Ajith P Perera said that Jayasekera had said until yesterday that he would not join the government.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
However UNP MP Lakshman Kiriella said in a media briefing this morning that MP Dayasiri sat in the UNP nomination board to select candidates for the North Western Provincial Council election yesterday.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Although MP Dayasiri refused reports about his plans to change sides several times in the past, our news team revealed on the 8th of August last year that he was preparing to defect.
 
5 UNP candidates from the Kurunegala district were elected to parliament in the general election held in 2010.
 
MP Dayasiri Jayasekera came first in the preferential vote list by obtaining 134,000 votes in the Kurunegala district.
 
The next in line in the Kurunegala UNP preferential vote list is North Western Provincial Councilor Naleen Bandara. Naleen Bandara obtained 29,000 preferential votes in the 2010 General election.
 
Naleen Bandara is now qualified to fill the parliament seat vacated after the resignation of Dayasiri Jayasekera.
 
When our news team contacted Naleen Bandara, he said that he was scheduled to have a discussion with Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe this afternoon.
 
Meanwhile 6 out of 8 UNP PS members of the Panduwas Nuwara Pradeshiya Sabha including its Opposition Leader joined the government just after Dayasiri Jayasekera’s resignation.
 
Dayasiri was the UNP’s Chief Organizer of the Panduwas Nuwara Constituency of the Kurunegala district.
 
Opposition Leader of the North Western Provincial Council Samansiri Peris said his fellow UNP members Wimal Dayananda, Janaka Tilakasiri, Darshana Sampath, Mano Kumara Edirisinghe and Hemantha Pallewatta have also joined the government.
 
Expressing his views on the party defection, former Opposition Leader Samansiri Peris had this to say.

hits._id: Muthuhettigama warns SLFP will defeat no confidence motion against Wijedasa

The deputy minister stressed that they will not allow the backbenchers of the United National Party to move the motion.
Meanwhile, addressing a public meeting in Anuradhapura yesterday, the leader of the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna, Anura Kumara Dissanayake said many people express their opinions on the present government's failure.
The National Freedom Front meanwhile said that the government is trying to hide the Central Bank bond scam by highlighting the alleged murder of Wasim Thajudeen.Its leader, MP Wimal Weerawansa said this addressing a meeting in Ratnapura yesterday.
