hits._id: An efficient Defence Minister for the country after August 17th: says Prime Minister

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said that there would be an efficient Defence Minister in the Government that would be created on August 17th.Participating at a people’s rally held in Wariyapola yesterday, the Prime Minister said that therefore no one should have any fear with regard to security.

hits._id: "A council to advice Parliament & Gov."- PM

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says that it has been proposed through the 19th Constitutional Amendment to appoint a State Council to advice the government and the parliament.The Prime Minister expressed these views at a event that was held at the Weheragodella Ancient Raja Maha Vihara in Sedawatte.

hits._id: MR Questions Discontinuation Of Previous Projects

_source.content:
Former President Parliamentarian (MP) Mahinda Rajapaksa says the country is currently facing an economic backlash due to the present government discontinuing projects initiated by the United People’s Freedom Alliance (UPFA) led government.
Speaking at an event in Kurunegala the Former President said he informed the new government to continue projects and called for investigations if any wrongdoing is uncovered.
He likened the present crisis to a vehicle that has not been in use for a period of one year and attempting to restart it causes concerns.

hits._id: Don't betray the motherland even if the whole family is imprisoned: says former President Mahinda Rajapakse

_source.content: Former President Mahinda Rajapakse made a request from the current government to protect the motherland that was liberated.He made this comment addressing a gathering at Ampara – Maha-wapi temple yesterday.

hits._id: Election propaganda ends at midnight tonight

_source.content: All propaganda activities related to the Local Government election ends at midnight tonight (Feb. 07).Police headquarters also announced that if anyone enters a polling station under the influence of alcohol, he will be arrested.In addition, if candidates bring persons under the influence of alcohol to polling stations, legal actions will be taken.Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education announced that due to the local government election, all schools in the island would be closed on Friday (Feb.09).The Ministry said that the 19 schools and two Colleges of Education that will be used for election-related activities would be closed from today till Friday.

hits._id: India requests Sri Lanka to free their fishermen in view of the Deepawali festival

_source.content:
The Indian Government has requested the Fisheries Ministry to release 86 Indian fishermen in view of the Deepavali festival which falls on November 10th.
However the Hindu newspaper quoted Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalitha Jeyaram as saying that the 86 fishermen would be freed next Wednesday.
When contacted the Fisheries Ministry, one of its senior officers told our news team that the subject minister has consented to respond positively to the request by the Indian government.
He also said that the 86 Indian fishermen would be freed on the condition that seven Sri Lankan fishermen, currently in the custody of Indian authorities, are freed.

hits._id: Justice K.T. Chitrasiri takes oaths as Acting CJ

_source.content:
Supreme Court Judge, K. T. Chitrasiri took oaths before President Maithripala Sirisena as the Acting Chief Justice.
He took oaths this morning (Mar. 28).

hits._id: President expresses condolence regarding Una McCauley's passing away

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena has expressed his condolence regarding the passing away of the UN Resident Coordinator and UNDP Representative in Sri Lanka, Una McCauley.

hits._id: Foreign Affairs Adviser Dr. Nonis

_source.content: Former Sri Lankan High Commissioner to Britain Chris Nonis has been appointed as the Adviser on Foreign Affairs to President Maithripala Sirisena today (06).

hits._id: President orders report on bottled water

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has ordered the secretary to the Ministry of Health to submit a report immediately on the price and quality standard of bottled drinking water.
 
The President issued this directive after it was found that certain businessmen are selling low-quality bottled water for high prices, in the wake of prevailing dry weather.
 
This was highlighted at a meeting in the Presidential Secretariat where issues faced by masses due to dry weather were discussed.
 
The meeting was held today (Apr. 05).
 
It was revealed 143,235 families in 9 districts are affected by the dry weather.

hits._id: Travel ban on Foreign Passport holders to some areas in North lifted: Restrictions on transport of items to North also relaxed.

_source.content: Since civil life has returned to normalcy across the island, it has been decided to lift the travel ban imposed in some parts of the country on foreign passport holders.The Ministry of Defence stated that the decision was taken following a directive by President Maithripala Sirisena, at the first national security council meeting under the leadership of the new President.Meanwhile, the list of goods prohibited from being transported to the North was also reviewed at the meeting.Accordingly the transportation of explosive goods, weapons, camouflage costumes and binoculars would not be allowed to the North while all other goods will be permitted.

hits._id: Government says that subjects under new ministries will not be an issue

_source.content: Several political party representatives expressed their views today on the gazetting of subjects under new ministries which took place recently. It is noteworthy that according to the gazette notification, for the first time in history, the National Lotteries Board which was coming under the purview of the Ministry of finance was assigned to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Subjects coming under the purview of 4 new ministries was announced through a gazette notification yesterday.  Accordingly, 33 institutions including the Treasury, National Budget Department, Inland Revenue, Customs, Excise and Insurance Board will come under the Ministry of Finance and Media. Ravi Karunanayake who was the minister of finance, took oaths as the minister of foreign affairs during the cabinet reshuffle, and 5 institutions falling under the purview of the respective ministry was gazetted. Accordingly, the National Lotteries Board, Development Lotteries Board and 3 other Institutions have been gazetted under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Meanwhile, 8 institutions including the Land Commissioner General’s Department, Land Reforms Commission and Surveyors Department have been gazetted under the Ministry of Land & Parliamentary Reforms which falls under the purview of Minister Gayantha Karunathilake. The EPF and Department of Project Management & Monitoring has been gazetted under the new Ministry, titled Development Affairs falling under the purview of Minister Thilak Maarapana. Previously, the EPF and Department of Project Management & Monitoring was under the Ministry of National Policy and Economic Affairs. Several political representatives expressed their views on the subjects falling under the purview of new ministries.  Deputy minister, Ajith P Perera, MP Kumara Welgama and State minister Sujeewa Senasinghe and Ministers Chandima Weerakkody and Mahinda Amaraweera expressed these views.

hits._id: A loan office to be set up for the government treasury

_source.content:
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe says that a loans office where payment of loans obtained by sri lanka can be made, will be set up and joined to the Government Treasury.
The Prime Minister mentioned this at the opening ceremony of the Sri Lanka Bankers’ Institute’s new building yesterday.

hits._id: Nurses unions reject P B Jayasundara committee recommendations for labour room issues.

_source.content: The Nursing Associations have raised objections to the P.B. Jayasundara Committee recommendations to provide midwifery training only to the nurses who are attached to maternity hospitals and maternity units.The Nurses Unions opined that the recommendations have ignored the rights of the nursing service.The Health Ministry decided recently to provide midwifery training to nurses but the family health workers raised grave objections to the ministry decision.Nurses unions as well as family health workers resorted to intermittent trade union actions during the last few months.Later the Health Ministry appointed a committee presided by Finance Ministry Secretary Dr. P.B. Jayasundera.Health Ministry Secretary Sudharma Karunarathna and Additional Secretary V.P. Somarathna appointed as other members of the Committee.The Committee recommendations were submitted to the Cabinet recently.The Public Service United Nurses Union, the Government Nurses union and the All Ceylon Nurses Officers Association said that they would never accept the committee recommendations.However Government Family Health Service Officers Association President Devika Kodituwakku said the P.B. Jayasundera Committee has given successful recommendations to the midwifery training issue.

hits._id: "No room for revival of terrorism" - PM

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe reiterated that there is no room left for the revival of terrorism in any part of the country.He said the goal of the government is to build a country for all communities to live, irrespective of their race or creed.Addressing the heads of media institutions at Temple Trees this morning, the Prime Minister stated that all should make commitments towards such a goal.He also said that an office under the patronage of former President Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga has been set up already, with the intension of restoring communal harmony.He added that the next goal of the government is to restore financial disciplines and new institutions have already been established to cope with the issues.The 19th constitutional amendment has already been presented in parliament as promised during the Presidential election. Pointing out that several factions have filed cases against the new amendment with the Supreme Court, The premier stated that steps would be taken to pass the new amendment after the Supreme Court delivers its verdict.In addition, discussions have commenced with political parties in order to change the current electoral system.The Prime Minister said that a final decision would be taken once the discussions are completed.

hits._id: A question from Ranil to the President.

_source.content: Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe questioned today who has been maintaining links with the LTTE.Addressing a ceremony held at the UNP headquarters Sirikotha today, the Opposition Leader further questioned what steps have been taken by the government with regard to the assets owned by Tamil Diaspora in Europe.

hits._id: 100 thousand jobs from Opposition Leader to UNP youth's.-Video

_source.content: Opposition Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe says that under a UNP government steps will be taken to provide one hundred thousand jobs to youths dedicating themselves for the party.The Opposition Leader said so while participating at a people’s rally held at Lunuwatta in Uuva Paranagama in Badulla yesterday.

hits._id: Delay of local government polls raised in parliament today again

_source.content:
Foreign Minister Mangala Samaraweera said in parliament today that Sri Lanka does not intend on withdrawing from nor boycotting the SAARC summit to be held in Pakistan.  
Minister Samaraweera said this while making a statement to announce Sri Lanka’s stand with regard to the 19thSAARC Summit to be held in Islamabad.
Meanwhile, MP Dinesh Gunawardana questioned about the date that local government polls are to be held, in parliament today as well. 
Answering the MP, leader of the house minister Lakshman Kiriella said that the anticipation of the UNP is to have the local government polls as soon as possible.
Simultaneously, a dialogue was also held about the issues relating to the delimitation of wards.  At that juncture, speaker Karu Jayasuriya intervened to respond to the matter.

hits._id: An alternative front from the Alliance apart from the SLFP

_source.content:
It is reported that certain factions of the SLFP and the UPFA will act as a separate front within parliament.

Sources from the MEP under the leadership of Dinesh Gunawardana states that a decision will be taken as to how the party will function after convening the Parliament.

Meanwhile, leader of the NFF, Wimal Weerawanse states that a dialogue has been initiated with other political parties in the Alliance to function as an Alternative National Front.

Secretary of the Democratic Leftist Front, MP Vasudewa Nanayakkara stated that discussions are underway with other parties that are against the National Government regarding the current situation.

Leader of the Lanka Samasamaja party Professor Thissa Vitharana also stated that discussions are underway with other parties to act against the National Government.

hits._id: No final decision regarding compensation- Minister of Disaster Management

_source.content:
The Ministry of Finance announced yesterday that a maximum compensation of one hundred thousand rupees would be given as compensation to the families of the victims of the Meethotamulla tragedy.
The maximum compensation to be given for property damage is 2.5 million rupees.
However, following a media briefing held with the Minister of Disaster Management Anura Piyadarshana Yapa, he noted that the government has not yet arrived at a final decision with regard to compensation. 
Issuing a communiqué the Ministry of Finance later noted that the families of the victims would be provided with one hundred thousand rupees compensation.
This would be provided by the ministry, through the national insurance trust fund, under the insurance scheme active for natural disasters.
The Ministry of Finance also emphasized that the treasury will allocate compensation for the families of victims, and issue necessary provisions for the responsible units in order to take immediate action, as soon as the government finalises the decision.

hits._id: Electricity generation trials begin at Moragahakanda

_source.content:
Releasing of water from the Moragahakanda Reservoir for hydro-power generation commenced this afternoon (02) under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena.
With the prevailing showery weather condition, the water level required to generate electricity from the Moragahakanda Irrigation project was reached yesterday.
25 megawatts of electricity will be added to the national grid following testing activities scheduled to take place over a period of 4 days.
Speaking at the occasion, President Maithripala Sirisena stated that this was a dream he envisioned for the people in Rajarata, for a long time.
Meanwhile, 20 new district and electoral organizers of the SLFP received their letters of appointment from President Maithripala Sirisena today.
The organizers have been appointed to Kandy, Gampaha, Colombo, Galle, Anuradhapura, Puttalam, Ratnapura, Ampara, and Batticaloa districts as well as to the Nuwara Eliya electorate.

hits._id: Maithripala - the Common Candidate. UNP G20 Panel Decides.

_source.content: G20 Elections Committee of UNP has chosen Maithripala Sirisena as the Common Candidate & final decision at the UNP Working Committee: UNP Sources.

hits._id: Subjects under 4 Ministries gazetted; National and Development Lotteries Boards under the Foreign Ministry

_source.content:
Subjects coming under the purview of new Ministries including Finance and Media, Foreign, Lands and Parliamentary Reforms as well as Development Affairs have been gazetted.
Accordingly 33 institutions including the Treasury, National Budget Department, Inland Revenue, Customs, Excise and Insurance Board will come under the Ministry of Finance and Media.
Meanwhile, the National Lotteries Board, Development Lotteries Board and 3 other Institutions have been gazetted under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The National Lotteries Board and Development Lotteries Board previously operated under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Meanwhile, the Land Commissioner General’s Department, Land Reforms Commission and Surveyors Department have been gazetted under the Ministry of Land & Parliamentary Reforms.
The EPF and Department of Project Management & Monitoring has been gazetted under the new Ministry, titled Development Affairs.
Previously, the EPF and Department of Project Management & Monitoring was under the Ministry of National Policy and Economic Affairs.

hits._id: President's challenge on commission reports

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena is challenging to hold the debate on Bond commission report and other large scale fraud reports, before the LG polls.

hits._id: Japanese investors meet President

_source.content:
A group of representatives of the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry Economic Mission, who visited Sri Lanka to explore new business and investment opportunities, met with President Maithripala Sirisena at the President’s Official Residence, in Colombo today ( Jan. 25).
 
A group of 77 members from the JCC have joined in this tour to Sri Lanka and this is the biggest team of Japanese investors to arrive in Sri Lanka since 1979.
 
The President has said that as Sri Lanka is looking to increase the investment opportunities in the country, the Government is ready to assist the Japanese investors.
 
Dr. Akio Mimura, Team Leader of the JCCI Economic Mission said that Japan is expected to explore investment opportunities in many fields, including industry, infrastructure, steel, software, transport and aviation.

hits._id: Don t infuse government Oxygen says Opposition leader in Jaffna

_source.content:
Opposition leader Ranil Wickramasinghe states that public of the North have more immediate and important concerns than the merging of the Northern and Eastern Provinces.
Speaking at an election rally held at the Nallur Park in Jaffna he further stated that the United National Party is the only party capable of uniting all Sri Lankan races.

			   
			   		
	
			   
Elaborating further the opposition leader stated that the North required a political solution and to achieve that the approval of the international community and the support of the public of the South is needed.

hits._id: Cut-off-point of the Year-5 scholarship examination reduced.-Video

_source.content: Education Minister Bandula Gunawardana said that the cut-off-point of the Year-5 scholarship examination has been reduced from 163 to 157.Addressing a meeting held at the Watareka Junior School today, the minister said this was enabled after the number scholarships has been increased from 15 thousand to 25 thousand in the 2015 budget proposals.At the same time, President Mahinda Rajapaksa said during the budget speech that the current Year-5 scholarship grant of 500 rupees will be increased upto 1500 rupees.Minister Gunawardana said that Year-5 scholarship recipients will be paid the new study grant with effect from the month of January next year.

hits._id: UNP and JVP supporters join SLFP

_source.content: A group of UNP and JVP supporters has extended their support to the SLFP after meeting with President Maithripala Sirisena today (25).The meeting took place at the President's House in Kandy.President Sirisena was in Kandy today to pay homage to the sacred tooth relic.

hits._id: A revelation by Mahinda Amaraweera

_source.content: The General Secretary of the United People's Freedom Alliance, Minister Mahinda Amaraweera says that they have not decided yet to take over administration of any Local Government institution in alliance with any party.

hits._id: Discussions to empower students commence

_source.content:
A discussion on empowering students under the Sustainable Schools Project was held under the leadership of President Maithripala Sirisena at the Mahaweli National College of Education yesterday.
President Sirisena also took time to answer questions posed by students.

hits._id: Supreme Court decision regarding draft bill on new foreign exchange presented to the parliament soon

_source.content:
The Supreme Court announced today that the decision regarding the compliance of draft bill on new foreign exchange with the Constitution would be informed to the Speaker of the House soon.
Currently, the draft bill has been submitted to the parliament in lieu of the prevalent foreign exchange control act.
The government states that the novel draft bill has been prepared in line with the latest regulations functioned in most of the foreign countries.
Moreover, through this, the Sri Lankans abroad are encouraged more to send money to the motherland.
However, Opposition complains that via this action, the powers vested on the parliament to control public finance would be abolished.
Accordingly, the government has requested for the opinion of the Supreme Court.

hits._id: Report of Delimitation Committee will be sent to Government Printer this afternoon

_source.content:
The Government Printer states that it will take another week to complete the process of gazetting the Delimitation Appeal Committee report.
Government Printer Gangani Liyanage stated even if the report is received by this afternoon, it will take another week to complete the proofreading.
She went on to say that the exact date of publishing the relevant gazette could be announced only after receiving the report this afternoon.
Meanwhile, Secretary of the Ministry of Provincial Council and Local Government Kamal Pathmasiri said that necessary measures are being taken to ensure that the report of the Delimitation Appeal Committee is being completed.
He further said, once the minister confirmed the report with his signature, it will be separated according to provinces before being sent to the Government Printer.
At the same time, Ministry Secretary Kamal Pathmasiri also said that the process of  printing and  publishing  the relevant gazette will take approximately one to two weeks.
However, subject minister Faizer Mustapha announced at a media conference held in Colombo yesterday that the report of the Delimitation Appeal Committee would be gazetted today.

hits._id: Parliament debate on Geneva begins today

_source.content:
The OHCHR report submitted by the United Nations Human Rights Commissioner for Human Rights Zeid Ra’ad Al Hussein at the UN Human Rights Council will be taken up for debate in Parliament today.
The reports were tabled in Parliament by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe on Tuesday and will be debated today and tomorrow.

hits._id: President Sirisena meets Pope Francis today

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena left the Island yesterday morning (13) for a visit to the Vatican on an invitation by the Holy See.
The highlight of the President’s visit will be an audience with His Holiness Pope Francis at the Vatican which takes place today.
This is the second time the President meets the Pope and when the last time His Holiness visited Sri Lanka the Holy Father was welcomed by President Maithripala Sirisena.

hits._id: "Culture develops a Country" - President

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena says that a country develops by building on its culture, heritage and local values.The President stated that several such examples can be drawn from developed countries.President Maithripala Sirisena expressed these views at an event held in view of the 83rd All Island Sinhala Poets Federation held at the Kuliyapitiya Central College Auditorium.The President further stated that it was every persons responsibility to safeguard the country’s language, culture and ancient art.

hits._id: Principals informed to keep schools clean before April 26th

_source.content: The Ministry of Education has informed principals of all government schools to get their schools cleaned before the 2nd term starts on the 26th of April. The ministry stated that these steps were taken in an attempt to maintain a dengue free school system. All principals have also been instructed to obtain assistance from parents and old pupils in this endeavour.

hits._id: Midwifery training to a nursing group confirmed

_source.content: An uproar was created recently with regard to providing midwifery training to nursing personnel. That was in coincidence with various unions protesting against it.However Government Service United Nursing Union said that at a discussion held with the Health Minister at the Health Ministry yesterday, the Health Ministry approval had been given for providing midwifery training to group B of year 2009

hits._id: All set for LG polls: Distribution of polling cards & ballot boxes begins

_source.content:
Authorities say that the preparations are complete for tomorrow's Local Government election.
The Election Commission said that the distribution of polling cards and ballot boxes will begin this morning (Feb. 09).
The number of eligible voters is 15,760,862.
Votes will be cast to elect 8325 councillors for 340 local government bodies. 
The Election Commission said that 175,000 government officers have been deployed for election duty.
The Chairman of the Election Commission Mahinda Deshapriya said that legal action will be taken against any public servants who avoid election duties.

hits._id: GMOA members at the Education Ministry demanding schools for children

_source.content: Over 200 members of the Government Medical Officers Association who have currently occupied the auditorium of the Education Ministry are demanding a meeting with the minister in charge over the Grade One admission dispute. The members of the GMOA visited the Education ministry this morning complaining that their children have not been admitted to popular schools as yet. Member GMOA central working committee Dr. Prabhath Sugathadasa stated that his fellow members will not leave the Education ministry premises until they are provided a meeting with the minister. Meanwhile, the media unit of the Education Ministry released a notice this afternoon with regard to the demand by the GMOA.  The Education Ministry states in its communiqué that the GMOA has been continuously pressurizing the education ministry that their children should be admitted to popular schools. The communiqué further states that even though there 352 national schools functioning throughout the country, the GMOA members are demanding their children be admitted to 12 popular schools. Meanwhile, the GMOA has decided to launch a token strike tomorrow based on this dispute.  Accordingly, the token strike will be launched in government hospitals in the districts of Kurunegala, Kandy and Matara.

hits._id: CID investigates a strange post on President’s Twitter account

_source.content:
The Criminal Investigation Department has initiated an investigation on a strange post published on the Twitter Account of President Maithripala Sirisena.
However, President’s Media Unit stated that it cannot confirm yet whether the President’s Official Twitter Account is hacked or not.
An excerpt of the speech made by the President at the inauguration of the second session of the 8th Parliament was published on his Official Twitter page yesterday (May 08).
However, another post which contradicted the President’s speech was published on his Official Twitter page.
The abnormal post was withdrawn shortly.
The President’s Media Unit stated that the CID has initiated an investigation with regard to the strange post published without the knowledge of the administrator.

hits._id: A Petition To The Supreme Court Asking For A Referendum Over The Bhikkku Draft Bill

_source.content:
Pivituru Hela Urumaya (PHU) has decided to go before the Supreme Court requesting a referendum over the Draft Bill presented to parliament in order to register a Theravada Ecclesiastical Code.
Party General Secretary and MP Udaya Gammanpila stated during a media conference held in Colombo today, that human rights have been violated by this new Draft Bill.
The proposed draft bill to register a Theravada Ecclesiastical Code has now become a controversial matter amongst Bhikkus.
However President Maithripala Sirisena said yesterday that the new draft bill will not be be passed in a hurry.
Addressing a gathering of the Maha Sangha, he said the new Draft Bill will only be passed with the blessings of the Maha Sangha.

hits._id: No room for issues based on language differences – says the President

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena says that there should be no room for issues in the country based on language difference.  The President stated this while participating in the prize giving of All Island Tamil Language Day held at Dharmaraja College in Kandy. President Maithripala Sirisena also noted that a language should be the voice of humanity and that anyone in the country should be able to pursue their studies or conduct administrative work in their respective languages.

hits._id: Allegations about Dengue eradication from a University Professor

_source.content:
Sri Jayawardene University Zoology Division Professor Nissanka de Silva says that the steps taken by the Government for Dengue Eradication have been unsuccessful. 
Speaking to our news team, the professor said that the Government did not consult the experts of the University System as well on Dengue eradication.
The professor pointed out that although fumigation for Dengue eradication should be carried out at the proper time, the health authorities performed it in the wrong way. 

			   
			   		
	
			   
Our news team inquired about this from Health Ministry Secretary Dr. Nihal Jayathilaka.
The Secretary said that in the future the Ministry hoped to obtain the cooperation of University experts as well.

hits._id: Dayasiri Assumes Duties

_source.content: Dayasiri who swore in before President Maithripala Sirisena for the post of Sports Minister on 4th September assumed duties today as the Minister of Sports.

hits._id: Election is useless; UNP says in Parliament

_source.content:
Asking an oral question in parliament today UNP MP Ajith P Perera said that holding elections are of no use in an environment where independent commissions are inoperative.
 
Subsequently a debate occurred between chief government whip Minister Dindesh Gunawardana and UNP MP Ajith P Perera.

hits._id: Top Govt officers to be sent to the village to look into issues - President.

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that top Government officers would be sent to the village to look into the problems of the village.
 
The President said that decisions taken at discussions held in Colombo providing relief to people were sometimes not implemented properly at village level. 
 
President Mahinda Rajapaksa said so at a discussion held at Presidential Secretariat yesterday with woman entrepreneurs engaged in small and medium scale enterprises.
 
On this occasion the President said that Government officers were doing an injustice to people by not carrying out their duties properly and  that he would take all steps possible to prevent this situation.

hits._id: Report on ‘elephant issue’ due this week

_source.content:
The report on the human-elephant conflict will be delivered this week, government sources said.
The report prepared by Justice Nimal Dissanayake contains results of a detailed investigation carried out in two and half months. Help of the public, media, NGOs, government officials and unions were taken to prepare it.
Steps will be taken from the Ministry of Sustainable Development and Wildlife to curb the issues identified in the report.

hits._id: An Indian Premier on an official visit to SL in March after 28 years.

_source.content: The External Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera, called on Prime Minister Narendra Modi yesterday.Prime Minister Narendra Modi lauded the people of Sri Lanka for the successful conclusion of elections, which had been watched with great regional and international interest.He congratulated President Sirisena and Prime Minister Wikramasinghe for the impressive victory, which was a vote for unity and change in Sri Lanka.He expressed hope that President Sirisena’s victory will advance peace, reconciliation and development in Sri Lanka, and peace and progress in our region.Describing Sri Lanka as a truly close neighbour and friend, Prime Minister offered India’s continued support and partnership to Sri Lankan Government and people in realising their aspirations.President Maithripala Sirisena is expected to visit India in February, his first international visit after taking over.Indian Premier Modi will visit Colombo in March, which would be the first state visit by an Indian Prime Minister to Sri Lanka since 1987.External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj will travel to Sri Lanka ahead of that and also chair the India-Sri Lanka Joint Commission meeting at the time.

hits._id: State Minister Wijewickrama assumes duties

_source.content:
The newly appointed State Minister of Provincial Councils and Local Government, Sriyani Wijewickrama assumed duties at the Ministry today (18).
 
Ministers Faizer Mustapha, Nimal Siripala de Silva, and Vijith Wijayamuni Zoysa were also present at this occasion.

hits._id: Rules about Collecting of funds in schools made strict

_source.content: Education Minister Akila Viraaj Kaaryawasam said that in the future no one would be allowed to act ignoring circular instructions.The Minister said that till sufficient money was set apart by the next budget, fund collection in schools could be done only with the approval of the Ministry.The Minister said so at a discussion held with National School Principals at the Isurupaaya Education Ministry yesterday.

hits._id: What's the destiny of BBS?

_source.content:
Bodu Bala Sena (BBS), General Secretary Ven. Galagodaatte Gnanasara Thera demanded President Maithripala Sirisena to prove whether the BBS had harmed any community in the isle.
And he also urged the President Maithripala to appoint a Committee to investigate on any alleged wrongdoings of BBS.

hits._id: Pakistan promises to help solve SL’s fertilizer shortage

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena says that Pakistani Prime Minister Shahid Khaqan Abbasi has promised him to send 40,000 MT of fertilizer to Sri Lanka.

hits._id: Officials accept the revelations made by HIRU CIA on the Wilpaththu destruction

_source.content: A group of officers from the Wildlife Conservation Department engaged in an inspection tour in Wilaththi-kulam area adjoining Wilpaththu yesterday, This was for further investigations on the deforestation activities taking place in the area which were exposed by Hiru, CIA in the past few days. Responding immediately, President Maithripala Sirisena issued directives to the respective authorities to immediately investigate into the matter. The President furthermore ordered the authorities to broaden the borders of Wilpaththu National Park, including all the adjoining forest reserves and to gazette it. The President also instructed the authorities to appoint a special inspection team including journalists, to compile a report on the constant deforestation activities taking place in Mannar and Puttlam districts. Accordingly, a special inspection team from the Wildlife Conservation Department was dispatched to the area of concern yesterday. Hiru CIA and Venerable Pahiyangala Ananda Sagara Thera of the Environmental Organizations Collective too joined the inspection team and witnessed the construction and infrastructure development activities in the area being expedited.    These illegal forest clearing activities are taking place in woods designated as a reserved forest under extraordinary gazette number 1759 / 2 dated 21st May 2012. President Maithripala Sirisena once stated that this illegal resettlement carried out based on political requirements of the previous government sets a wrong example. However, it can be seen that the president’s name has been used in providing infrastructure facilities such as electricity.  We further observed that construction activities are taking place in the area disregarding the orders made by President Maithripalaa Sirisena in May last year.

hits._id: State of Emergency lifted

hits._id: Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office to the Island.

_source.content:
Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office Alestair Bird arrived in the island this dawn.

Our Airport Reporter said that the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office arrived in the island by a Qatar Airways plane at about 3.20 this morning accompanied by two other representatives.

Foreign Affairs Ministry Secretary Dr. Karunatilake Amunugama said that the Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office was scheduled to hold discussions with the Sri Lankan Government Authorities with regard to a number of matters that have an impact on both countries.

The Foreign Affairs Ministry Secretary said further that the Ministry hoped to brief the British government about the Sri Lankan government’s development programme of activities carried out especially in the North and East after the war.

Reports say that in addition discussions are also scheduled to be held with regard to the next Commonwealth Summit due to be held in Sri Lanka.

The Foreign Affairs Ministry Secretary said further that Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office was expected to hold discussion with several top Government representatives during the time of his stay in the island.

hits._id: Next Indian parliament will be against Sri Lanka - says Vaiko Pakistani News paper alleges India created Terrorism in Sri Lanka

_source.content:
The Indian parliament recently refused to pass a resolution similar to that passed by Tamil Nadu against Sri Lanka.
 
The general election to appoint the next Indian parliament is scheduled to be held next year.
 
Pro LTTEr Vaiko issued a warning stating that when the new parliament is appointed the stance of the Indian parliament regarding Sri Lanka will change.
 
However, a Pakistani newspaper today reported that the protests by Tamil Nadu against Sri Lanka had an adverse impact on the entire region.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
MDMK general secretary Vaiko said the next Indian parliament will pass a resolution pressing the Sri Lankan government for a referendum.
 
Talking to the press persons, he said that the Central government could no longer push the Sri Lanka issue to the backburner as it had become a people’s movement.
 
Vaiko said the present Indian parliament will not do it because its days are numbered but the next parliament will pass the resolution.
 
 
Meanwhile, Pakistans the Nation news paper has carried out an analysis regarding Indo Sri lanka relations. 
 
With DMK President M. Karunanidhi’s decision to quit both the Union Cabinet and the Congress-led United Progressive Alliance, the political environment in India has taken another turn. 
 
The anti-Sri Lanka sentiment has grown stronger. 
 
He has argued that continuing in the government and the alliance would do great harm to the Sri Lankan Tamils.
 
Of late, the Sri Lankans visiting or staying in India have been harassed, assaulted and booed, especially in southern India. 
 
As reported by The Hindu, “a Buddhist monk from Sri Lanka was assaulted by three unidentified persons on board the Tamil Nadu Express, just as it arrived at Chennai Central Railway Station.
 
This is the second such attack in three days, the first being on a monk at the Big Temple in Thanjavur.
 
Recently, Sri Lankan cricketers participating in the IPL matches were barred from playing in Chennai by the AIDMK-led government of Jayalalitha.
 
According to Wikipedia, “From August 1983 to May 1987, India, through its intelligence agency, the RAW, provided arms, training and monetary support to six Sri Lankan Tamil militant groups, including LTTE. 
 
During that period, 32 camps were set up all over India to train these militants.
 
Sri Lanka, however, has developed strong ties with other regional countries like Pakistan, China and Bangladesh, who have supported it in difficult times and continue to do so even after its victory against scourge of terror.

hits._id: A Scarcity of Dhal and Sugar predicted by Wholesale Trader’s Association

_source.content: The government has imposed a new maximum price index to six essential items including Dhal and Sugar from the new budget for the year 2016.The Secretary of Wholesale Trader’s Association in Pettah, K. Nadan told Hiru News that it is impossible to sell dhal and sugar at the fixed price imposed by the government. Therefore, a scarcity of dhal and sugar is predicted in the country.According to newly fixed prices, one kilo of Dhal is sold at 169 Rupees.However a price is not yet fixed for Sugar. Therefore a kilo of unpacked and packed sugar is still priced at 87 and 95 rupees each, which were fixed previously.However, wholesale traders point out that the new price indexes bring greater difficulties in sales and this would lead to a serious scarcity of Dhal and Sugar in Sri Lankan Market in near future.

hits._id: Gazette with number of councillors for LG bodies published

_source.content:
The gazette notification constituting the number of members of all local government bodies has been published.
The Government Printer confirmed this to Hiru News.
The gazette notification has been published under numbers 2043/56 and 57.
In addition to the number of councillors in local government bodies, establishing Norwood and Maskeliya Pradeshiya Sabhas in the Nuwara Eliya and Agrapathana and Kotagala Pradeshiya Sabhas in Ambagamuwa region has also been included in the gazette notification.
Minister of Local Government and Provincial Councils, Faizer Mustapha signed the gazette notification on the 1st of this month.
The Ministry said that the number of councillors in each local government body has been determined based on the geographic and demographic features of each region.
It is noteworthy that, with the amendment to the Local Authorities Elections Act, the number of local government bodies will increase from 336 to 341 while the number of councillors will increase from 4,486 to 8,356.

hits._id: SAITM Students Withdraw Contempt Of Court Case Against Health Ministry

_source.content:
A contempt of court case filed against Health Ministry and the Secretary to the Ministry was withdrawn today by the petitioners.
On November 26, 2015, five SAITM students filed a contempt of court case against Health Ministry and Health Ministry Secretary Anura Jayawickrama with the Supreme Court.
The students, through their petition, said that the Health Ministry gave an undertaking in 2014 to facilitate necessary clinical practices for them in a government hospital. This undertaking was given when a Fundamental Rights petition filed by the five students was considered by the Supreme Court. However, nothing has been done to carry out this undertaking, the students claimed through the petition.
Considering this application, the Supreme Court bench comprising of Justice Chandra Ekanayake, Justice Sisira de Abrew and Justice Eva Wanasundera allowed for the withdrawal of the petition.
When the case was taken up today, the petitioners informed the Supreme Court that the government has taken steps to give clinical practices at Avissawella Base Hospital and Kaduwela MOH. Therefore, the petitioners requested permission to withdraw the case.

hits._id: President visits Holocaust Memorial & Jewish Museum – [Photos]

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena yesterday (Feb. 16) visited the Holocaust Memorial and the Jewish museum in Berlin.
The Holocaust Memorial has been built to remember the Jewish victims of the Holocaust. Memorial, which has been designed by architect Peter Eisenman and engineer Buro Happold holds the names of approximately 3 million Jewish victims.
The memorial construction began on April 1, 2003, and was finished on December 15, 2004. Inauguration took place on May 10, 2005, sixty years after the end of World War II.
Ministers Ravi Karunanayake, Daya Gamage, Malik Samarawickrama and Mahinda Samarasinge also joined the President in this visit.

hits._id: Wikileaks reveals how Canada helped LTTE

_source.content: Wikileaks has revealed the support received by the LTTE from various elements in Canada during the conflict.Canada’s Conservative-minority government domestically designated the LTTE/Tamil Tigers under Canada’s Criminal Code on April 10th, 2006. The Canadian government did not, however, list the many Canadian front organizations for the LTTE, despite the fact that Canada's anti-terrorism act allows their government to designate front organizations.In the past, the Canadian Security Intelligence Service has stated that eight front organizations support the Tigers in Canada.Experts have estimated that in the 1990s, over 80 percent of the Tamil Tigers’ military budget came from overseas sources, and various reports have estimated that the Canadian Tamil diaspora was a source of between 1 to 10 million US Dollars annually.Approximately a quarter of the world’s Tamil population lives outside of Sri Lanka.Canada is home to the largest Tamil diaspora, estimated at roughly 200,000.A recent report from Human Rights Watch focused on signs it had found of extensive extortion by the Tigers within the Canadian Tamil community.

Special protection is provided to the Colombo Remand prison where Yoshitha Rajapaksa is currently in remand custody to prevent outsiders entering the Prison premises.The Prisons Department says that Yoshitha Rajapaksa, the second son of Former President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was remanded along with 3 others arrested are detained in a separate cell.Prisons Commissioner General H N C Danasingha stated that Kaveesha Dissanayaka who was also arrested along with them has however been admitted to the Prisons Hospital.Yoshitha Rajapaksa and 4 others were ordered by the Kaduwela’s Magistrate’s Court to be remanded till the 11th of next month.Kaduwela Chief Magistrate Dhammika Hemapala gave out this order after the FCID arrested the accused and produced them before Courts.Yoshitha Rajapaksa was arrested over the use of State Assets for the promotion of the CSN channel and using undeclared funds for the commencement of the channel.Meanwhile CSN chairman Rohan Weliwita, former CEO Nishantha Ranatunga and 2 other individuals were also arrested in connection with the case.Prisons commissioner general H NC Danasingha stated that Yoshitha Rajapakse and the others are detained in one cell.------------------------------------------- Ex-Pres says Son Yoshitha was arrested for false accusationsFormer President Mahinda Rajapaksa’s son, Yoshitha Rajapaksa and 4 others were ordered by the Kaduwela Magistrate’s Court to be remanded till the 11th of next month.

MP’s Johnston Fernand, Rohitha Abeygunawardana, D V Chanaka and Lohan Ratwatte were also present.

hits._id: President recollects the first victim of terrorism.

_source.content:
President Mahinda Rajapakse yesterday delivered the key note address at the Commonwealth Local Government Conference 2013 held in Kampala, Uganda, under the theme ‘Developmental Local Government: Putting Local Government at the heart of Development”.
 
President Rajapakse said Sri Lankans have consistently regarded local government as the most practical expression of the ideals and aspirations of a functioning democracy.
 
The President further said that local government was among the first target of the terrorism. 
 
Restoring local government and accelerating economic growth were the priorities of Sri Lanka immediately after the end of the war.
 
President Rajapaksa said the first victim of terror was the mayor of Jaffna in the North.
 
He said the twin pillars of durable peace and political stability have opened doors for Sri Lanka to move forward on accelerated economic and social development.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Ugandan Presidnet Yoweri Museveni, delivering the inaugural address also commended Sri Lanka’s efforts in ending terrorism in the country and assured Ugandan’s presence at the commonwealth heads of government meeting in Colombo.

hits._id: President says he will not retire after 2020

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena says he will not retire by 2020 as he has to fulfil a lot more responsibilities.
He said this while addressing the May Day rally organized by the Sri Lanka Freedom Party at Mawediwembu in Chenkalady, Batticaloa today (May 07).
Only a few out of the 16 former SLFP Ministers who resigned from the government recently were present at the rally.
Except, MP. S. B. Dissanayake others - Dayasiri Jayasekera, Dilan Perera, and Thilanga Sumathipala were not seated on the stage.
They waited at the entrance of the sports ground.
However, other members of the group, Chandima Weerakkody, Lakshman Yapa Abeywardana, W. D. J. Senevirathna, Anura Priyadarshana Yapa, Susil Premajayantha, Susantha Punchinilame, Anuradha Jayarathna, Taranath Basnayake, T.B. Ekanayake, Sudarshani Fernandopulle and Sumeda J Jayasena were absent.

hits._id: SLFP 66th anniversary : A special traffic plan along Baseline Road

_source.content: The Sri Lanka Freedom Party will mark its 66th anniversary at the Campbell Park, Borella in Colombo today (03). Thousands of supporters are expected to arrive at Campbell Park, Borella, to celebrate the occasion under the patronage of SLFP Chairman, President Maithripala Sirisena. The Sri Lanka Freedom Party was founded by S.W.R.D Bandaranaike in 1951  and, since then, has been one of the two largest parties in the Sri Lankan political arena. It first came to power in 1956 and since then has been the predominant party in government on a number of occasions. The Sri Lanka Freedom Party is the main constituent party in the United People's Freedom Alliance. Meanwhile, a special traffic plan will be implemented along the Baseline Road from Indram junction to Borella Junction from 11am.

The Chairman of the Sri Lanka Administrative Association Ranjith Ariyarathna said that several members of his association including the Gampaha District Secretary Sunil Jayalath also participated in the discussion. 
He quoted the president as saying that the government accepted responsibility and the incident was regretted.
Meanwhile, a group of members attached to the Sri Lanka Administrative Association held a discussion with Public Administration Minister Ranjith Madduma-bandara this afternoon.
The Chairman of the Sri Lanka Administrative Association Ranjith Ariyarathna said that an ultimatum was given to deputy minister Ramanayake to apologize before February 3.
He said that strict trade union action will be taken if the deputy minister doesn’t apologize.

hits._id: No ministers for the UNHRC sessions;foreign affairs Ministry confirms

The Foreign Affairs Ministry confirmed that Government  Ministers would not participate in the Human Rights Commission session held in Geneva in March.
Foreign Affairs Ministry Secretary Karunatilake Amunugama told our news team that only Government officers would participate in the session this time.
The Secretary said that staff of the Defence Ministry, Attorney General's Department, and Foreign Affairs Ministry would thus participate in the session.
Foreign Affairs Ministry Secretary Karunatilake Amunugama said further that the Government was prepared to successfully face any resolution moved at the session against Sri Lanka.
Meanwhile co-convenor of the Platform for Freedom Dr. Nimalkaa Fernando said that a powerful resolution should be brought forward against Sri Lanka at the Human Rights Commission session this time.
That was at a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday.

			   
			   		
	
			   
The JHU says that this statement is statement against the country.
JHU national organiser Nishaantha Sri Warnasinghe expressing his views with regard to this stated as follows:

			   
			   		
	
			   
The Patriotic National Movement says that persons against the country like this  will not be allowed to carry out their agendas.
PNM secretary Dr. Wasantha Bandaara expressing his views on the subject stated as follows

			   
			   		
	
			   
Meanwhile Russia has said that it would provide the support necessary for defeating the resolutions put forward against Sri Lanka  by western countries.

hits._id: Cabinet Approves Reintroduction Of Capital Gains Tax

_source.content:
Cabinet of Ministers has granted approval for the government to reintroduce the Capital Gains Tax (CGT) scheme.
Announcing the cabinet decisions Wednesday (June 15), the government said during the last few decades there has been a massive increase in the private capital in the country.
According to the government, the increase in prices of land attributable to the large infrastructure developments carried out through government funds have enabled the land owners to make significant capital gains free of taxation. This resulted in the increase in the inequality of income distribution.
 The Cabinet Committee on Economic Management therefore has agreed to reintroduce the Capital Gains Tax to rectify the situation.
The proposal made by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe as the Chairman of the Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs to draft a new Capital Gains Tax Regime, was approved by the Cabinet of Ministers.

hits._id: General Amnesty Period For Illegal Firearms Concludes Today

_source.content:
The general Amnesty period granted to hand over illegal firearms to the government will conclude today.
The Ministry of Defense said persons returning weapons will not be subject to any fines or punishments for holding a weapon.
The general amnesty period was announced on the 30th of May.
The Defense Ministry said it will conduct raids from tomorrow in search of illegal firearms.

hits._id: Final decision on “State of Emergency” to be made at Security Council Meeting

_source.content:
The Minister of Law and Order, Ranjith Madduma Bandara says that the final decision with regard to the “State of Emergency” will be announced after the next Security Council Meeting.
 
The “State of Emergency” was imposed on 6th of March by President Maithripala Sirisena following the spread of riots in Kandy.
 
It was imposed under the powers vested in him through the Section 11 of the Public Security Ordinance.
 
The President does have the power to impose “State of Emergency” for a period of 10 days in such circumstances.
 
However, if the state of emergency needs to be extended further, Parliament should ratify it.
 
The President informed the speaker of the ruling of emergency regulations on March 9th.

hits._id: Update : Video:  Special meeting between commonwealth heads of government today as well - CHOGM 2013

_source.content:
A special meeting between commonwealth heads of government will be held today as well in Battaramulla, where special attention will be paid to issues faced between countries. Yesterday the 1st and 2nd executive sessions of the Commonwealth heads of government meeting were held at the BMICH during which issues faced by small countries as well as matters relating to international trade were discussed. Following yesterday’s meeting a special dinner was held for the delegates with the patronage of Price Charles. UPDATE: Saturday, 16 November 2013 - 8:15 AM-----------------------------------------------------CHOGM 2013 begins with Sri Lanka chairing the summitThe 1st and 2nd executive sessions of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting were held this afternoon at the BMICH subsequent to the inauguration ceremony held at the Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapakse Theater.

State leaders and representatives of all countries were present for these two sessions except the British Premier David Cameron.

The sessions began after President Mahinda Rajapakse assumed duties as the chairman of the summit.

Discussions were centred on topics such as challenges faced by small states, the role of civil society in development, participation of youth in development and international trade.

Following the conclusion of the 1st executive session the executive committee of the Commonwealth Youth Council including its chairman met with the state leaders taking part in CHOGM.

The state leaders taking part in CHOGM were updated regarding topics discussed during the Commonwealth Youth Summit which was held in Hambantota over 5 days.

An epistle bearing proposals that were passed during the youth summit was also handed over to the heads of government present.

Subsequently the topics discussed and the proposals put forth by the youth council were discussed during the 2nd executive session of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

A press conference has been scheduled for this evening to notify the press regarding what was discussed during the 1st and 2nd executive sessions today under the patronage of President Mahinda Rajapakse and the Secretary General of the Commonwealth Kamalesh Sharma.

Meanwhile, Heir to the British throne, His Excellency Prince Charles visited the National Museum after taking part in the first executive session.

The ministry of external affairs reported that a dinner for the heads of state who are in the country for CHOGM 2013 has been organized by Prince Charles tonight.

Meanwhile, a special meeting between state leaders has been scheduled in Battaramulla tomorrow.
 Friday, 15 November 2013 - 8:09 PM------------------------------------------------------------------22nd Commonwealth Summit declared open in ColomboThe 22nd Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting began today at the Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapakse Theatre this morning. President Mahinda Rajapakse and the First Lady arrived at the Nelum Pokuna premises at approximately 9.15 this morning which was followed by the arrival of the Commonwealth Secretary General Kamalesh Sharma and his spouse. Next to arrive was the current chairman of the Commonwealth, Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbot and he was followed by state leaders and diplomats who are taking part in CHOGM 2013. These state leaders were welcomed by the first lady, Commonwealth Secretary General Kamalesh and Australian Premier Tony Abbot. The last to arrive was the Prince of Wales, His Excellency and Heir to the British throne Prince Charles. Presidents from Nauru, Samoa, Cyprus, Tanzania, Rwanda, Seychelles and South Africa of the Commonwealth have arrived in the country to take part in CHOGM 2013. In addition, 5 vice presidents, 13 prime ministers, 33 foreign ministers and 9 diplomats representing the member nations of the Commonwealth have arrived in Sri Lanka to take part in the summit. After the conclusion of the CHOGM inauguration, the Commonwealth Heads of Government will be escorted in a decorated vehicle parade to the Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall to participate in the main executive session of the summit. During the main sessions, Present Commonwealth Chairman and Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott will hand over the Commonwealth Chair to President Mahinda Rajapaksa. Later Commonwealth Secretary General Kamalesh Sharma will host lunch for the Heads of Government. After lunch, Heads of Government will have a discussion with the Commonwealth Youth leaders.Update : Friday, 15 November 2013 - 1:11 PM-----------------------------------------------------President Mahinda Rajapaksa inaugurates Commonwealth summit President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that the goal of the Commonwealth is to build cooperation among the member nations and mutually help themselves. Expressing his views during the inaugural address to the Commonwealth this morning President Rajapaksa said that the Commonwealth should give priority to eliminate common poverty first rather than common wealth The President also expressed his views on the economic goals that Sri Lanka achieved after the war.Friday, 15 November 2013 - 12:28 PM--------------------------------------------------------CHOGM heads of government meeting declared open by Prince CharlesThe 22nd Commonwealth heads of government meeting was declared open by Prince Charles at Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapaksa theatre a short while ago.

President Mahinda Rajapakse warmly welcomed Prince Charles and Camila Parker, the duchess of Cornwall.

After the inauguration of CHOGM, the first session is scheduled to be held at the BMICH with President Mahinda Rajapaksa at the chair.
Friday, 15 November 2013 - 10:36-------------------------------------------------------------------------22nd CHOGM kicks off today at Nelum Pokuna. Friday, 15 November 2013 - 8:09The inauguration of the 22nd CHOGM will take place today.

That will be at the Nelum Pokuna Mahinda Rajapaksa theatre and under the chairmanship of heir to the British throne, Prince Charles.

Heads of Government of 23 countries have already arrived in the island to participate in it.

After the inauguration of CHOGM, the first session is scheduled to be held at the BMICH with President Mahinda Rajapaksa at the chair.

Prince Charles arrived in the island last afternoon to participate in CHOGM.

Prince Charles also met President Mahinda Rajapaksa at President’s House last night.

The President’s Media Unit said that a celebration in view of Prince Charles’ 65th birthday which fell yesterday had also been organised at President’s House.

On this occasion a special birthday cake structure had also been prepared on behalf of Prince Charles.
 (update):  නවීකරණය කරනවා, යාවත්කාල කිරීම

hits._id: Proud of the change achieved by Sri Lanka: US Assistant Secretary of State

_source.content:
Talks between the visiting US Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Nisha Biswal and President Maithripala Sirisena are currently underway at the Presidential Secretariat.

Prior to her meeting with the President, the US Assistant Secretary of State met Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe at Temple Trees.

US Assistant Secretary of State Nisha Biswal who arrived in the island early this morning, first met Foreign Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera.

Later, expressing her views to the media, she stated that the US is proud of the change achieved by Sri Lanka.

Addressing the media, Foreign Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera stated that Sri Lanka is taking measures to ensure democracy and the rule of law.

Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights T. Malinowski, who arrived in the island with Assistant Secretary of State Nisha Biswal, also joined the discussion.
Update : Tuesday, 25 August 2015 - 19:00   ----------------------------------------------------
 “Sri lanka Has Improved”- Says US The United states Assistant Secretary for South and central Asian affairs Nisha Biswal says Sri Lanka has improved in restoring democracy and defeating corruption.
She stated this after a meeting with Foreign Minister Mangala Samaraweera this morning. 
She also reiterated that US would continually assist Sri Lanka in her long and hard journey towards progress.
The United States Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Nisha Biswal arrived in the island this morning with Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor Tom Malinowski.
Foreign Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera said that the accountability would be authenticated through a domestic investigative mechanism.
Nisha Biswal is scheduled to meet President Maithripala Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe within the course of the day.

hits._id: Medical practitioners await a decision on Influenza injection

_source.content:
The Ministry of Health says that the recommendation to be given by the special committee appointed to advise on the injection to be administered to control the Influenza virus is yet to be released.
 
The Secretary to the Ministry of Health, Janaka Sugathadasa said that as a consequence there has been a delay in making an injection available to government hospitals.
 
To date, 25 deaths have been reported due to the spread of influenza in the Southern Province, 18 of those victims were children.
 
Most recently a 4-month-old baby died of the virus at Karapitiya Teaching Hospital last Sunday.
 
Meanwhile, Southern Health Director, Dr. G. Wijesuriya said that on a daily basis approximately 60 patients are seeking treatment from government hospitals for the disease.
 
Additionally, according to Sabaragamuwa Provincial Health Director, Dr. Athula Kannangara on a daily basis, approximately 10 patients seek treatment from government hospitals in the province.

hits._id: Attorney General refrains from expressing his views on local government election

_source.content:
The Attorney General has made it known that is not possible to express his views at this time in response to the request made by the Election Commission for clarification on the prevalent legal positioning regarding holding elections for local government bodies that have no problem with regard to demarcation. 
An Election Commission spokesman told our news team that the Attorney General has informed the Commission that since three local government election related petitions were being heard before the Supreme Court, it was not possible to express views regarding the matter out of respect for the Supreme Court.
The Election Commission has written to the Attorney General enquiring about the legality of holding elections in the local government areas where there are no delimitation issues.
The Election Commission has taken this decision after election monitoring organizations informed the Commissioner that elections could be held for 61 local government institutes as they have no delimitation issues.
Meanwhile, PAFFREL has filed a petition with the Supreme Court requesting that an order be given to hold elections in the local government areas where delimitation has been completed.
Meanwhile MP Dallas Alahapperuma says that hereafter it will be impossible for the Government to cover its political nudity on the pretext of demarcation. 
A group of representatives of the joint opposition met Election Commission Chairman Mahinda Deshapriya yesterday and consulted him regarding the local government election. 
Five Matara District MPs representing the joint opposition and a group of former local government councilors met with the election commission chairman Mahinda Deshapriya and held a discussion with him yesterday.

hits._id: JHU's decision on UNP's no confidence motion against the government delayed. NFF, JVP and TNA decision today.

_source.content: The no-confidence motion against the Government moved in parliament by the UNP is scheduled to be taken up for debate today and tomorrow.The UNP recently moved this no-confidence motion in parliament signed by 26 MPs against the Government’s failure to prevent the influx of dangerous drugs including narcotics into the country.A Government affiliated party, JHU had recently expressed various views severely critical of narcotics influx into the country.  However JHU Media spokesman Nishaantha Sri Varnasinghe said that although his party central committee had met last afternoon, it had not been possible to reach a consensus.He said that accordingly discussions would be held today as well and it would be reveled tomorrow as to whether the JHU would vote for or against the no-confidence motion or adopt any other line of action.Another Government partner NFF said that it would reveal its stand about the no-confidence motion today.The JVP and TNA representing the Opposition said that they would meet this forenoon and take a decision about it.

hits._id: Foreign Ministry issues statement on visit by UN Special Rapporteur

_source.content:
Foreign Ministry today (11) issued a statement relating to the 2-week visit by UN Special Rapporteur on the Promotion of Truth, Justice, Reparation, and Guarantees of Non-Recurrence, Pablo de Greiff to Sri Lanka.
He arrived in the country yesterday and will stay in Sri Lanka until 23rd of October.
The statement added that successive Governments in Sri Lanka have been inviting such Special Rapporteurs to the country to obtain their views and expert advice on specific thematic areas.
The Foreign Ministry said that the Governments are not bound by the advice or recommendations of Special Rapporteurs, but can avail of the expert knowledge and experience of Special Rapporteurs who are available to Governments as a resource.
“Their advice and expertise can be obtained by countries in a manner that would benefit institutional capacity building, policy formulation, and policy reform, training needs etc., as a Government may consider necessary” the statement added. 
The Foreign Ministry also said that once de Greiff presents his Report to the Human Rights Council in September2018, it is for the Government of Sri Lanka to decide whether there is anything that the Government considers beneficial to the people of Sri Lanka in his recommendations, and whether the Government wishes to draw on his knowledge, expertise, and advice and consult him further in any manner.

hits._id: Northern CM asks TNA to lay conditions to support ‘no-confidence motion’

Northern Province Chief Minister C. V. Vigneshwaran says that if the Tamil National Alliance supports the government in the ‘no-confidence motion’ which is tabled against the Prime Minister that the TNA should lay down conditions.

The Northern Province Chief Minister had said that neither a single member nor several members representing the TNA have the right to take an arbitrary decision.
 
Meanwhile, TNA will meet tomorrow (Apr. 03) with Opposition Leader R. Sambanthan at the chair to take a decision regarding the ‘no-confidence motion’.
 
That will be held at the Parliamentary complex.
 
However, responding to a query, the Opposition Leader R. Sambanthan said that so a final decision had not so far been made to meet the President or the Prime Minister.
 
Similarly, the EPRLF led by former TNA MP Suresh Premachandran met with the Prime Minister today.
 
Meanwhile, the JVP parliamentary group is scheduled to meet at Parliamentary complex tomorrow.
 
Meanwhile, the Joint Opposition leaders are meeting tomorrow with former President Mahinda Rajapaksa at the chair at the Parliamentary complex, to discuss the ‘no-confidence motion’ and the future political situation.
 
Similarly, the UPFA parliamentary group meets today with President Maithripala Sirisena at the Chair.

hits._id: Medical Council is not the only stakeholder in the SAITM crisis, says Professor Carlo Fonseka

_source.content: The GMOA says that the policy decisions announced by the Government regarding Medical Education Standards and the Malabe Private Medical College cannot be trusted.Participating at a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday GMOA secretary Dr. Naveenda Soysa said that the Government had previously made such announcements on several occasions.The government’s stance over Malabe Private Medical School was announced yesterday.Presidential Secretariat, ministry of Higher Education and the Health Ministry have jointly announced the stance.The notice issued by the government has further described the policy measures that have been taken to ensure standards of medical education and the freedom of education.A decision has been taken to provide clinical training to students who passed the final examination at  Malabe Private Medical School in Homagama and Avissawella government hospitals.It was also stated that it is mandatory for these students to sit an examination conducted jointly by the Sri Lanka Medical Council and University Grants commission.Meanwhile, recruitment to Malabe Private Medical College should be suspended until the Government policy decisions are implemented.Interviews for admission to SAITM  had been held yesterday in spite of  the Government giving a directive to bring to a halt all admissionsMeanwhile views were expressed about medical education at several media briefings in Colombo yesterday.However participating at a function held in Colombo yesterday Sri Lanka Medical Council Chairman Professor Carlo Fonseka said that the Medical Council is not the only stakeholder in the SAITM crisis.

hits._id: Basil and P B Jayasundara appears before the Presidential commission of inquiry

_source.content:
A former minister Basil Rajapaksa and former Financial Ministry Secretary PB Jayasundera appeared again before the Special Presidential Commission of Inquiry on Massive Fraud and Corruption today.
Both Basil  Rajapakshe and PB Jayasundera were summoned by the Commission with regard to investigation in connection with the misappropriation of 155.4 million rupees of the Divi Neguma Department to pay domestic air travel expenses.
Meanwhile, investigations to the extravagant ceremony organized to fill water to the new Hambantota harbor and its opening that cost the then government 130 million rupees were concluded today.
Actor Jackson Anthony and a former Port Authority Chairman Priyath Bandu Wickrama appeared before the Presidential Commission of Inquiry today too with regard to this investigation.
The Special Presidential Commission of Inquiry on Massive Fraud and Corruption initiated investigations following a complaint which cited that funds for the ceremony has been spent without the approval of the Port Authority Director Board.
It also stated that such spending has been made with total disregard to the Port Authority annual budget.

hits._id: COPE report to parliament on the 23rd to parliament.

A committee member told our news team that this report comprised the investigations done with regard to the year 2011.
 
The COPE has started investigating 256 government institutions in 2011 and the final report of 110 will be presented to parliament on July 23.
 
Among the institutions that came under the COPE microscope are Ceylon Electricity Board, Sri Lankan Airlines, Mihin Lanka Airlines, Road Development Authority, Samurdhi Authority and Petroleum Corporation.
 
The COPE will meet again on July 9 before it present the report to parliament on July 23.

hits._id: President addresses UNGA, urges Intl. community to recognize Sri Lanka’s progress

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena calls upon the international community to seriously consider the tremendous progress made by the government towards reconciliation, restoration of democratic freedoms, human rights and the rule of law.
He also urged them to extend the fullest support to the slow, but the steady forward march of Sri Lanka to build a progressive, democratic, free and equal society with high morals and discipline.  
Addressing the 72nd Session of the United nations General Assembly in New York on 19th of September (20th morning in SL time), he pointed out that all are aware that haste will not yield good results and the slow and steady path is the most suitable one to restore religious and communal harmony so that people of all communities could live in peace and harmony as equal citizens.
He said that during the last two and a half years, the government has taken several important steps that are necessary for consolidating democracy, freedom, good governance, and the rule of law.
“Through such transformative steps, we have laid the foundation necessary to forge national reconciliation, and ensure non-recurrence of conflict in our country,” he said.
“As a country that has suffered violent conflict for 30 years, we are drawing from experience and lessons learned to strengthen national reconciliation, and we are determined to prevent the recurrence of conflict. We have given priority in this context to consolidate freedom and democracy in our country, and through a strong foundation of national reconciliation forged through unity and friendship among communities,” the President said.
President Sirisena stressed that the vision of the government is to ensure sustained economic development through the increase of domestic agriculture and industry under an environment friendly policies and programs.

It may be recalled that earlier, the Government of India released 10 Sri Lankan fishermen in Indian custody.With the on-going process for release by the Sri Lankan authorities of the Indian fishermen, both countries would have reciprocated on the fishermen in each other’s custody.
