hits._id: Increasing private sector salary by Rs. 2500 proposal to be presented in Parliament

_source.content:
Two draft proposals for a 2,500 rupee salary increase and a 10,000-rupee minimum salary  in the private sector are scheduled to be presented in the parliament today. 
Minister of Labour and Trade Union Relations W. D. J. Seneviratne will be presenting the two proposals.
This will be the first time that the private sector employees’ minimum salary will be decided by a parliamentary Act.
These two drafts have been prepared as a result of a long-standing trade union demand that was made to the Government.
If the Act is passed, the private sector employees’ minimum salary will be Rs. 10,000, the minimum daily wage will be Rs.400.
The ministry of Labour and Trade Union Relations said that this would have come into effect from January this year, the arrears would also have to be paid.

hits._id: President Maithripala Sirisena Holds Bilateral Talks with Japanese Premier

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena who left for Japan to participate in the G7 state leaders’ summit, held bilateral talks with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe today.
President Sirisena first met with Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina during which the President thanked Bangladesh for the assistance given during the recent disaster situation in Sri Lanka.
Matters relating to the apparel industry were also discussed.
President Maithripala Sirisena later met with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
The Japanese Prime Minister thanked the Sri Lankan President for the assistance given for the G 7 Summit while President Sirisena in return thanked Japan for inviting a Country such as Sri Lanka for the high profile summit.
The Japanese Premier while extending a concessionary loan of 38 Billion Yen also had inquired in to investment opportunities in Sri Lanka.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe also assured that Japan would provide any assistance or guidance to Sri Lanka with regard to enhancing the economy.

hits._id: 25% of subsidized fertilizer cut; Too much chemical fertilizer; says Agriculture Ministry

_source.content:
Fertilizer offered to farmers under a subsidized mechanism has been truncated by 25%.
Accordingly chemical fertilizer offered by the government under the subsidy scheme would be curtailed by a volume of 100,000 tonnes.
Owing to this the government is believed to save around 7 billion rupees per annum.
The government incurs a cost of 26.2 billion rupees per year in order to meet the fertilizer subsidy requirements of farmers.
However according to the Ministry of Agriculture, the volume of fertilizer utilized has exceeded the volume of cultivated paddy land in island.
Hence the ministry plans on directing farmers to resort organic fertilizer instead.
However farmers engaged in two protests before the Mahiyangana fertilizer storage complex as well as the Polonnaruwa Gallella fertilizer storage complex charging that they were unable to obtain fertilizer even by paying for it, despite the governments pledges to offer them fertilizer under a subsidized scheme.
Several of the farmers engaged in the recent protest which was held at Mahiyangana expressed the following views to our news team.

hits._id: President invites investors to the development plan

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena, who is on a state visit to Malaysia, highlighting the investment potential of the island invited the business community of Malaysia to invest in Sri Lanka.
Participating in the Sri Lanka-Malaysia Business Forum organized by the two countries, the President and his delegation met with the business community of Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur last afternoon and discussed identifying new approaches to expand investment and trade opportunities with the Malaysian business community.
The President stated that Sri Lanka offers a wide range of investment opportunities as the government has declared that the focus over the next three years will be on development.
The business forum was organized with the aim of strengthening the cooperative relationship between Sri Lanka and Asian markets.
Speaking at the forum, the Malaysian Minister of International Trade and Industry Datuk Seri Mustapa Mohamed said the Malaysian and Sri Lankan business communities should strengthen cooperation and invest in each other's country to enhance the bilateral trade and investment.
He said Malaysia has a strong presence in Sri Lanka, mainly, in the services, tourism and manufacturing sectors and that the Malaysian government was committed to encourage a conducive trade environment with Sri Lanka and deepen economic engagement.

This programme is carried out by the Presidential Secretariat in keeping with a concept of the President to build a better environment for the physical and mental growth of the children and to protect them.
Save children from various menaces in society, prevent child abuse, ensure the protection of children, enhance of their good health condition, nutrition and welfare, personality development, develop their education and life skills are among the objectives of this programme.

hits._id: Top 10: 5th complaint against Minister Kabir

_source.content:
Joint Opposition MP Kanaka Herath said that the 5th complaint under the Top Ten list against corruption being committed by the current government will be handed over to the Bribery Commission today.
Addressing a media conference held in Colombo this morning, Herath said a misappropriation of 1500 million rupees has been committed in revoking the A350-900 Air bus deal of Sri Lankan Airlines.
Accordingly, a complaint will be filed against Minister of Public Enterprises Development Kabir Hashim, and the board of directors of Sri Lankan Airlines.
MP Mahindananda Aluthgamage who was present at the media conference expressed his views about the decision taken by Athuraliye Rathana Thera to remain as an independent in parliament.
Earlier, the Joint Opposition, under its Top Ten list have filed complaints with the Bribery commission and the CID against Prime Minster Ranil Wickremesinghe, former Central Bank Governor Arjuna Mahendran, Finance Minister Ravi Karunanayake, minister of  Foreign Employment Thalatha Athukorala, minister of International Trade Malik Samarawickrama and the Hambantota Port agreement.

hits._id: Report on power outage to the Parliament on 23rd

_source.content:
A special meeting concerning the sudden power outage was held at Temple Trees yesterday afternoon under the patronage of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe.
The Minister of Power and Renewable Energy, its Deputy Minister, the Ministerial Secretary and the Chairman of the CEB also participated in the meeting.
PM assured that measures will be taken to present a detailed explanation to parliament on the 23rd of this month.
The Premier further stressed that the country is suffering the consequences of not implementing long term plans for the generation of power.
Meanwhile, a police investigation is currently underway with regard to the incident where a transformer exploded at the Biyagama Grid Substation yesterday.
The investigation commenced following a complaint lodged by the substation’s deputy engineer to the Sapugaskanda Police.
Accordingly, a group of crime scene inspectors and officers from the Department of Government Analyst’s inspected grid.
Sapugaskanda Police have presented facts relating to the incident to the Mahara Magistrate’s court.

hits._id: President says his policies have not changed

_source.content:
Addressing the heads of media institutions at Temple Trees this morning President Mahinda Rajapaksa said that his policies have not changed to date.

When journalists asked him his comments on the Commission appointed to probe the disappeared persons, the President had this to say.


			   
			   		
	
			   
 
The President was also asked to comment on the dispute between Sri Lankan and Indian fishermen.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Meanwhile the President said that a group of TNA representatives had held discussions to join the government.

When asked whether any more MPs are in the waiting list to join the government, the President said that the door has now been closed.

The Heads of Media Institutions also brought the attention of the President to the murder of the Superintendent of the Nooriwatta estate in Deraniyagala.

President Rajapaksa telephoned the IGP immediately and obtained a feedback of the investigations into the murder of the superintendent.

He quoted the IGP saying that there were complaints made against the police as well, so investigators have recorded statements from the residents.

Meanwhile views were expressed on the forthcoming heads of Commonwealth meeting.

External Affairs Ministry officials stated that 54 countries have already informed their participation in the meeting.

The officials are also confident that heads of 80 to 85 percent of those countries would attend the meeting.

They also stated that the Canadian Foreign Minister will also participate in the meeting and the Prime Minister could also participate.

Meanwhile Finance Ministry   Secretary Dr. P.B. Jayasundara expressed his views on the expenditure of the Commonwealth meeting.   
 
Addressing a media briefing held in Colombo today, the JVP Propaganda Secretary, MP Vijitha Herath said that the Government has already infused violence into the forthcoming Provincial Council election.


			   
			   		
	
			   

Meanwhile UNP General Secretary MP Tissa Attanayake told a media briefing held in Colombo today that his party has already appointed group leaders to all Provincial Councils.

hits._id: India to maintain positive attitude towards Sri lanka's new political leadership.

_source.content: The External Affairs Minister Mangala Samaraweera, called on Prime Minister Narendra Modi today.Prime Minister Narendra Modi lauded the people of Sri Lanka for the successful conclusion of elections, which had been watched with great regional and international interest.He congratulated President Sirisena and Prime Minister Wikramasinghe for the impressive victory, which was a vote for unity and change in Sri Lanka.He expressed hope that President Sirisena’s victory will advance peace, reconciliation and development in Sri Lanka, and peace and progress in our region.Describing Sri Lanka as a truly close neighbour and friend, Prime Minister offered India’s continued support and partnership to Sri Lankan Government and people in realising their aspirations.Stating that “even a few steps can clearly indicate one’s direction”, Prime Minister Modi expressed his admiration for Sri Lankan leadership’s vision of a “truly Sri Lankan government”, inclusive of all voices, and the initial steps taken by the new Government in Sri Lanka for political reconciliation, inclusiveness and participation.Prime Minister thanked President Sirisena for accepting the invitation to visit India, and looked forward to receiving him at an early date.He also accepted the invitation to visit Sri Lanka at a mutually convenient date.

hits._id: State patronage for Dr. Lester James Peiris's funeral

_source.content:
The government has decided to provide state patronage for the funeral of veteran and respected film director Dr. Lester James Peiris who passed away in Colombo last night (Apr. 29).
 
President Maithripala Sirisena has instructed the Presidential Secretariat to take necessary actions in this regard.
 
Internationally acclaimed Sri Lankan film producer and film director Dr. Lester James Peiris passed away yesterday at the age of 99, whilst undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Colombo.
 
Dr. Peiris attended St. Peter’s College, Colombo, before dropping out to pursue a career in journalism at the age of 17.
 
In 1947, he travelled to England on his mother’s advice to join his brother Ivan Peiris who was there on an art scholarship.
 
Dr. Peiris celebrated his 99th birthday on April 05 under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena at his residence in Thimbirigasyaya.
 
He will be honoured and remembered for the quality – rather than quantity – of his contribution to filmography in Sri Lanka.
 
 Dr. Peiris planted a fresh seed in the film industry, setting a new standard with his creativity.
 
Dr. Peiris who has long been considered as the father of Sinhala cinema revolutionized the Sinhala film industry with his globally acclaimed film “Rekawa” in 1956.
 
In 1957 the film was nominated for the Palme d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival.
 
The internationally acclaimed film director, screenwriter, and film producer went on to produce 28 award-winning movies such as Gamperaliya, Delovak Atara, Golu Hadawatha, Madol Duwa, Weera Puran Appu, Kaliyugaya, Yuganthaya and Baddegama.

hits._id: President abolishes Prime Minister’s Economic Management Committee

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has abolished the Cabinet Committee on Economic Management headed by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe with immediate effect.
The decision was made at the Cabinet meeting held at the Presidential Secretariat yesterday (Mar 27).
Earlier the President had twice directed the CCEM to be abolished saying that in the past nothing productive had come out of the Committee.
The President’s decision was made in spite of a UNP MP submitting his observations stating that it was necessary to continue to have the CCEM.
On this occasion, the President pointed out that necessary deliberations and decisions regarding the economy could be made at the cabinet meeting.
Reports state the President said that if there was a matter that the cabinet should discuss at length or it would be discussed by a cabinet sub-committee.

Speaking further President Mahinda Rajapakse had this to say....


			   
			   		
	
			   

The massive new South Port of Colombo, located mid-way on the lucrative east-west sea route has world class facilities and with its 18-metre draft, can handle even the biggest Triple-E Class vessels carrying 18 thousand containers that are already in service.

hits._id: President Maithripala sends an urgent letter to Mahinda

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena has sent an urgent letter to former President Mahinda Rajapaksa. The letter sent by President Sirisena, in his capacity as the Chairman of SLFP, consists of 5 pages.In his letter, President Sirisena stated that another senior leader of the party, other than the former president should be appointed to the premiership if the UPFA is able to secure the minimum number of 113 seats to form a government in the forthcoming General Election.The President has also revealed several matters in his letter to the former President.He has stated that those who are flattering the former President are giving telephone calls or meeting him in person requesting for Ministerial portfolios following the election.In addition, the letter states that those who call themselves as the followers of former President are strongly attacking the SLFP MPs who assumed ministerial posts.He also stated that the long term political friendship between the former President and himself collapsed due to the misdemeanor of Basil Rajapaksa.In addition, he stated that during the telephone conversation which took place 2 days prior to handing over the nominations, he has reiterated not to contest.However, the former President had become a prisoner of small political parties.The President also emphasized that Former President should take the responsibility of preventing SLFP from falling under the influence of small political parties and groups.And to end the provision which allow these factions to decide the journey of the SLFP.The President also mentioned that during the leadership of the Former President, the SLFP was a party which resisted diversity.He also stated that he had to withdraw since the former President was ready to divide the party and offer nominations separately following minor incidents.Therefore, the President further requested the former President in his letter to use his intellect instead of his heart until the day of the Election.He ended the letter requesting the former President to take measures to win more seats for the UPFA at the election.

Sri Lanka Freedom Party will celebrate its 64th anniversary in Polonnaruwa today under the patronage of party leader, President Maithripala Sirisena.
Former SLFP leaders, including former Presidents Mahinda Rajapaksa and Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga have been invited.
SLFP was founded by the 4th Prime Minister of Sri Lanka late S.W.R.D Bandaranaike in 1951 and, since then, it has been one of the two largest parties in the Sri Lankan political arena.
An Ashirvada Pooja will be held at the ancient Somawathiya Temple from 7 a.m. on September 2 to invoke blessings on the party.
Multi-faith religious ceremonies will be held throughout the week at places of religious worship to invoke blessings on the party, the people and the country.

hits._id: UPFA PCmeeting approves 3 proposals

_source.content: UPFA All Ceylon Provincial Councilors Summit was held at Western Provincial Council Chief Minister’s office today.3 proposals regarding the upcoming General Election was approved during the summit.Representing UPFA, Western Provincial Councilor of Mahajana Eksath Peramuna Sisira Jayakodi organized the summit.According to our correspondent, a tense situation occurred at the commencement of the summit due to the heated debate between SLFP Southern Provincial council Minister of Agriculture U.D.G. Ariyathilake and Western provincial councilor of the same party Lalith Ellawala.However, after the summit concluded, SLFP Eastern provincial councilor Wimalaweera Dissanayake stated that consensus was reached on 3 proposals including facing the forthcoming election under the leadership of President Maithripala Sirisena and former Presidents Mahinda Rajapaksa and Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumarathunga.

hits._id: Police transfers during the Presidential election cancelled

_source.content: Widespread attention had been drawn in society with regard to the agreement allegedly signed between then Opposition leader Ranil Wickremesinghe and then Common Candidate Maitripala Sirisena during the presidential election.That was in coincidence with the disclosure former UNP General Secretary MP Tissa Attananayake made about the alleged agreement after he crossed over to support UPFA presidential candidate, former President Mahinda Rajapaksa.However Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe complained to the IGP saying that there was no truth in the said allegation.Police Media Spokesman SSP Ajith Rohana said at media briefing held in Colombo yesterday that by now the relevant investigations had been completed.On this occasion the police media spokesman also explained the progress of the probe into the alleged conspiracy carried out at Temple Trees on the presidential-election-day night.On this occasion Police media spokesperson also said that the arbitrary transfers carried out in the police department during the recent past would be cancelled.

hits._id: Opposition lights candle sticks in Parliament; Water bottles from Government; JVP on top of tables

_source.content:
Parliament was adjourned until May 7th after a tense situation erupted today as well over the increase of the electricity tariffs.
 
Deputy Chairman of Committees earlier decided to adjourn the house for five minutes after the UNP MPs walked into the chambers with lit candle sticks in hand and started protesting. At this juncture, water bottles from the government side were hurled at the protesters.
 
Later the government members tried to pass several scheduled bills for the day but their attempt was failed as MP Sunil Handunnetti and Vijitha Herath of the Democratic National Front climbed on their tables and started protesting.
 
Meanwhile UNP MP Dayasiri Jayasekera showing a press release issued by Minister Patali Champika Ranawaka questioned about the content in the press release.
 
Media reports stated that the statement made by Minister of Power and Energy Pavithra Wanniarachchi in parliament had hinted the electricity tariff hike was proposed by Minister Ranawaka during his tenure as the subject minister.

hits._id: President leaves for US

_source.content:
President Maithripala Sirisena has left the Island to attend the 72nd session of United Nation's General Assembly, which is being underway in New York.
The Presidential delegation is comprised of 17 persons and they had left the country at around 10.35am today (17).
The President will address the Assembly on Tuesday.
This is the 3rd time that President Maithripala Sirisena is addressing the UN General Assembly.
The 72nd Regular Session of the UN General Assembly began at the UN Headquarters on 12th of September.
The General Debate will open on Tuesday (19), under the theme, ‘Focusing on People: Striving for Peace and a Decent Life for All on a Sustainable Planet’.

hits._id: President to visit India today

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena will be visiting India today to take part in a global anti-tobacco conference in New Delhi. During his two-day visit, President Maithripala Sirisena will take part in the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control which is being participated by 180 countries. The President will address the convention as a special speaker on the inaugural day, tomorrow. He is scheduled to meet with Indian President Pranab Mukherjee at Rashta-Pathi Bhavan. President Sirisena’s visit comes a day after a high-level delegation led by foreign ministers of the two countries met in New Delhi to sort out the fishermen issue.

hits._id: President Advises Ministers, MPs To Visit Disaster Stricken Areas

Addressing a special district development committee meeting at the Kegalle Town Hall this morning, the president further stated that the resettlement of the displaced should be accelerated.
At the same time, President Maithripala Sirisena requested authorities to draw special attention to restore facilities for the affected children, to enable them to get back to school without delay.
The President also inquired from authorities about the prevailing condition of the displaced, who are being sheltered in temporary makeshift camps.

hits._id: Muthuraajawela residents protest against Colombo city garbage

_source.content:
The residents of Kungna-watta in Wattala have staged a protest against Colombo city garbage being dumped in the Muturajawela sanctuary.
Catholic priests in the area have also joined in the protest.
The Chairman of Evergreen Environment Organization B.I. Abdeen and JVP Provincial Councilor Mahinda Jayasinghe expressed their views during the protest.

This covers garbage disposal, garbage separation, transportation and storage.

hits._id: Signing of estate workers collective agreement undecided- [photos]

_source.content:
A tense situation erupted when the estate workers collective wage agreement was about to be signed this morning.
A special discussion between estate worker unions and estate owners is being held at the Labour Ministry.
Labour Minister W.D.J. Senevirathna told our news team the outcome of the discussion will decide whether or not the collective agreement is signed today.
The two factions have agreed on a 730 rupees daily wage, but trade unions have demanded the current 620 rupees wage is increased to 1000 rupees.
Over the last several weeks estate workers in several regions across the country, including upcountry, staged protests to see this demand met.
      Pics by Hatton Ranjith Rajapaksha

hits._id: Thailand warmly welcomes President Maithripala Sirisena

_source.content: President Maithripala Sirisena who left for Thailand today for a four day state visit on an invitation extended by the Prime Minister of Thailand General Prayut Chan-o-cha arrived in Thailand short while ago.The Sri Lankan President is invited to participate in the ceremony to mark the 60th anniversary of diplomatic relationship between Sri Lanka and Thailand.President Sirisena was received in audience by Crown Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn.During this visit, the President will hold discussions with Princess of Thailand and the Prime Minister of Thailand.The discussions will focus on strengthening of Buddhist relationships between the two countries.President Sirisena will also declare open the exposition of Sarvagna dhathu from Mahiyangana Rajamaha Viharaya, in Buddhamanthan Temple in Thailand on November 03rd.A ceremony to place special Samadhi Buddha Statue offered from Sri Lanka to Thailand, in Dharmarama Temple in Thailand will be held under the patronage of President Maithripala Sirisena.

hits._id: Ranil, Chandrika, Sobitha Thero, Fonseka and Arjuna on same stage for a common agenda; Sama-samaja, Communist and alternative group also to contest

_source.content: National Leader of UNP Ranil Wickremesinghe said that his party would support the proposals including the annulment of the Executive Presidency put forward by the National Movement for Just Society.UNP Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe announced his party stand in a meeting organized by the convener of the National Movement for Just Society Maduluwawe Sobhitha Thera today in Colombo.Addressing the same meeting, Maduluwawe Sobhitha Thera said if the government does not react clearly to the proposals put forward by his movement, it has decided to field a common candidate for the forthcoming presidential election.Sobhitha Thera added that everyone despite differences, should get together and select a dependable common candidate for the upcoming Presidential election.UNP Leader Ranil Wickremesinghe expressing his views stated that everyone has agreed to abolish the Executive Presidency, form a government which will be answerable to the parliament, implement the 17th amendment in addition to introducing a Ratio and First-past-the-post system instead of the preferential vote system.  Former President Chandrika Bandaranaike has also sent her greetings to the meeting and it was read out by Attorney-at-law Upul Kumarapperuma.The letter read that she extends her fullest support and blessings to the alliance which was built with the aim of abolishing Executive Presidency, empowering  the 17th amendment and the rights of the citizens as well as forming a democratic government system.Meanwhile Democratic Party Leader Sarath Fonseka said that his party would support the National Movement for Just Society if it fields a candidate.He said that contesting as a common candidate is akin to being sentenced to gallows and that they intend to support a common candidate only when their conscience can accept the candidate’s history, abilities and the mentality.  Democratic People’s Party Leader Mano Ganeshan, National Unity Front Leader Asad Saaly and Moubima People’s Party Leader Hemakumara Nanayakkara also participated. At the same time, representatives from New Democratic Party, New Sihala Urumaya, Ruhunu People’s Party and United People’s Front also participated. Besides, several civil organizations including Free Media Movement, Scholars Collective for a Just Society, Federation of Trade Unions, Lawyers for Democracy, University Association for a Just Society, Former MPs’ Guild, Pensioners Collective for Just Society and Lanka Private Bus Owners Federation participated in the meeting. Although JVP and JHU representatives did not participate in this meeting today, alternative groups of the Lanka Samasamaja Party and the Communist Party participated.

hits._id: Litro Gas Chairman removed

_source.content:
The Ministry of Public Enterprise Development has removed Litro Gas Chairman Shalila Moonesinghe from his post.
Moonesinghe is in remand custody over his alleged links to the hacking of Taiwan's Far Eastern Bank and stealing money.He was remanded until 25th of October today (11).In a media communique, the Ministry said that the Secretary of the Ministry has already instructed Sri Lanka Insurance Chairman to do so.An acting Chairman will be appointed soon, the Ministry added.Sri Lanka Insurance is the main shareholder of Litro Gas Limited. The Criminal Investigation Department arrested Shalila Moonesinghe on Monday.
Moonesinghe is also the Leader of the New Democratic Front, under which President Maithripala Sirisena contested and won the 2015 Presidential Election.
Police acted after state-owned Bank of Ceylon reported a suspicious transfer into one of its accounts of $ 1.2 million from Taiwan Far Eastern Bank, following the withdrawal of some of the money by one of the suspects.
Sri Lankan authorities have so far nabbed two Sri Lankans accused of helping hackers steal millions from Far Eastern International Bank of Taiwan.
Focus Taiwan, the English-language news website of Taiwan’s Central News Agency, said on Saturday Far Eastern Bank had reported to Taiwan’s financial watchdog that its computer system had been infected with malware.

hits._id: Dengue Awareness Programme To Be Conducted In Schools Island Wide

The schools have been instructed in this manner after discussions held with the Education State Minister, Nuwara Eliya District Parliamentarian V. Radhakrishnan, and the Education Ministry states.
Accordingly, it is insisted that all schools should conduct a voluntary-clean-up session on weekly basis.
Is was also decided that a seminar to educate school children on Dengue menace also should be held on weekly basis.
The police and the Health Ministry are to assist on these programmes.

hits._id: EU Parliament delegation meets Defence Secretary

_source.content:
A delegation of the European Union Parliament met the Secretary to the Ministry of Defence (MoD), Eng. Karunasena Hettiarachchi and senior officials of the MoD at the ministry today (09).
The EU delegation is led by Member of European Parliament Geoffrey Van Orden, and the Chairman of the Friends of Sri Lanka Group in the EU Parliament, Morten Messerschmidt is focusing on issues related to development and reconcilliation in Sri Lanka since January 2015.
The Defense Secretary explained the EU delegation about progress  made in demining and releasing efforts of lands previously used by the military, for civilian use.
Discussions also emphasized on the development of the defense policy in a post-war context with a focus to rehabilitate ex-LTTE carders.

hits._id: Moon calls for International involvement in SL war crimes allegation

_source.content:
The United Nations Secretary‑General Ban Ki-moon has told in a Media query that he expects Sri Lankan government will abide by the commitment made to the UN Human Rights Council in October 2015.
Spokesperson for the Secretary-General Stephane Dujarric said the UN Chief "remains hopeful that the Sri Lankan Government stands by its commitments and fully implements the resolution."
The remarks were made in response to a media query on the President Maithripala Sirisena's statement that no foreign judges are welcome in the war crimes inquiry.
However, Secretary‑General states that involvement of foreign judges on the transitional justice mechanism will ensure International credibility and transparency.

hits._id: A bus strike in the South protesting against Rs. 2500 minimum fine

_source.content:
A group of private bus operators responsible for several routes in the Southern Province have launched a bus strike in protest of the Budget 2017 proposal to increase the minimum fine for traffic violations to 2500 rupees.
Convener of All Ceylon Private Bus Workers Association Kumara Rathna Renuka said that bus drivers and employees that cover the routes from Galle, Matara, Tangalle and Kataragama have joined in the strike.
A similar strike was staged by bus workers in Kalutara, Panadura and Horana yesterday.
Kumara Rathna Renuka said that they will continue the strike if the government does not find a solution to the issue today.

hits._id: Government faced with 13 issues instead of 13th amendment

_source.content:
The United National Party today questioned the government regarding its stance on the 13th amendment to the constitution.
 
General Secretary of the UNP MP Thissa Aththanayeke speaking in this regard noted that the government had until present-failed to declare its stance before parliament.
 
The Parliamentary Group of the Sri Lankan Freedom Party convened at Temple Trees last evening under the patronage of President Mahinda Rajapaksa.
 
However the group had failed to reach a consensus with regards to the 13th amendment to the constitution.
 
Speaking here President Mahinda Rajapaksa stated that party members should refrain from commenting on the 13th amendment to the constitution since the party would make its stance public during the days to follow.
 
However General Secretary of the UNP MP Thissa Aththanayke commenting further in this regard noted that government had made a myriad of statements with concern to the 13th amendment to the constitution on multiple occasions.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Moreover addressing a media briefing held in Colombo yesterday Deputy Minister of Economic Development S.M. Cndrasena noted that endowing provincial councils with police & land powers may result in creating further divisions.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Meanwhile Co-Convener of the Janatha Paura Organisation Attorney-at-law Sunil Handunneththi who was present during a media briefing which was held today stated that although the government had come forth with various topics on the devolution of power, the people of the North were faced with 13 dire concerns.
 

			   
			   		
	
			   
 
Meanwhile consent was granted today at the Uwa & North Central provincial councils with regards to 2 amendments which were introduced by the government with concern to the 13th amendment to the constitution.
 
When these amendments were presented before the Uwa provincial council 
today by leader of the house Wimal Galagama.
 
At this juncture the UNP councilors had been absent in the house while the only JVP councilor of the Uwa provincial council Sudath Balagalle had abstained from voting.
 
19 government party councilors who had been present during the vote at the Uwa provincial council had cast their votes in favor, enabling the amendments to be passed.
 
Meanwhile in the North Central provincial Council these amendments were passed with a majority of 8 votes.
 
19 votes were cast in favor while 11 were cast against.
 
The 11 UNP members over at the North Central provincial council had cast their votes against the amendment while the North Central Provincial Councils JVP member Wasantha Smarasinghe had been absent.
 
Moreover Former Chief Minister of the North Central Province Berty Premalal Dissanayeke who represents the government was also absent during today’s session at the provincial council since he had obtained 3 months leave a few days ago.
 
Under the governments recent modifications to the 13th amendment it would not be possible to amalgamate two or more provincial councils while the consensus of all provincial councils would be required to enact a single decision instead of the approval of a single local government institution.

hits._id: Prime Minister's special statement tomorrow

_source.content: Prime Minister Ranil Wickramasingha is scheduled to make a special statement tomorrow regarding the current political situation in the country.The statement will be issued at the party head quarters siri kotha tomorrow morning.A meeting between President Maithreepala Sirisena and a group of his supporters was held yesterday at former President Chandrika Kumaratunga’s resident. A SLPF senior minister told our news team that the prevailing political situation and the future of the SLFP have been discussed in the meeting.At the same time, former president Mahinda Rajapaksa has requested President Maithreepala Sirisena to give nominations to all MPs who are attached to the alliance. Former MP T.B. Ekanayake told our news team that copies of this letter by former president Rajapaksa have been sent to SLFP General Secretary and UPFA General Secretary as well.However, SLFP General Secretary Anura Priyadarshana Yapa told our news team that his party has already decided to give the nominations together with the UPFA.

hits._id: Minister Rajitha expresses views on Minister Wijedasa

_source.content:
Minister Rajitha Senaratne says he regrets the comments made by certain ministers of the present government.
He said certain ministers criticize the government while enjoying benefits as ministers and are abusing the freedom given to them.
Dr. Rajitha noted certain ministers who did not speak out during the time of the previous regime have now become heroes.
He alleged that the Minister of Justice, had influenced not to undertake court proceedings for the last two and half years.

hits._id: Main political parties hold final election rallies today

hits._id: Deposits for 93 LG bodies to be accepted

_source.content:
Additional Election Commissioner, M. M. Mohamed says that placing security deposits for 93 local government bodies will take place starting from today (27) to 13th of December.
 
The Additional Commissioner said that besides this, nominations for these 93 local government bodies will be accepted from 11th to 12 noon of 14th of December.
 
The notification of calling for nomination is scheduled to be issued today by the District Returning Officers.
 
The Court of Appeal meanwhile issued an interim injunction order against the holding of local government elections and the Election Commission announced that 203 LG bodies will be affected by the court order.
 
However although it is possible to hold the election for 133 local government bodies, there are minor problems with regard to 40 institutions.
 
The Commissioner said recently that therefore order has been issued to hold elections for 93 bodies.
 
Similarly, the Local Government and Provincial Council Ministry said that the flaws in these 40 institutions would be corrected and the relevant gazette notification would be issued today or tomorrow.

hits._id: Special debate on ousted CJ Mohan Peiris

_source.content: As per the request of Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, Speaker Chamal Rajapaksa has decided to convene a special parliament meeting on coming Monday.Secretary General of Parliament Dhammika Dasanayake told our news team that on this day a special debate concerning the ousting of Mohan Pieris, who served as the Chief Justice thus far, will be held as per the request of the opposition.A relevant gazette notification has been issued regarding the matter where the parliament is to be convened at 2pm.An debate took place in parliament yesterday when the opposition requested for a debate following Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe’s special statement regarding the ousting of Mohan Pieris from his position.The parliament was adjourned and was convened again after 30 minutes.At this moment, the prime minister agreed to hold a debate on the 5th of February.However, when the parliament recommenced, MP Dinesh Gunawardena requested to hold a debate yesterday and allow at least one opposition MP to express their views.In response, the Prime Minister said that the debate will be held on the 5th of next month.When a request was made to hold the debate on the 2nd, the ruling party denied it, stating that a rehearsal for Independence Day celebrations will be held on the particular day.Later, a heated argument occurred between the opposition and the ruling party members.

hits._id: Foreign Affairs Minister to visit India next week

_source.content:
Minister of Foreign Affairs Tilak Marapana is scheduled to visit India next week.
He will be accompanied by Foreign Secretary Prasad Kariyawasam, who was Sri Lankan High Commissioner to India before being appointed as the ambassador to the United States.
This also happens to be his first overseas visit since assuming office on the 15th of August.
Marapana is scheduled to call on Prime Minister Narendra Modi, hold talks with his Indian counterpart Sushma Swaraj, and a few other ministers and officials.
Sushma Swaraj was in Colombo last week to attend the second Indian Ocean Conference.
She met President Maithripala Sirisena, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and Tilak Marapana and discussed key aspects of bilateral cooperation.
Sri Lanka released 76 Indian fishermen to coincide with Swaraj’s visit to the country.

hits._id: No pre-agenda for the new constitution- PM

_source.content:
The country now has a president who is ready to hand over power to the constitution, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe said at the National Legislative Summit.
At the summit organized by the Sri Lanka Bar Association, the premier added that a pre-agenda is not required for the preparation of a new constitution.
Meanwhile, President Maithripala Sirisena said he would not agree to involve foreign judges concerning the investigations of the alleged human rights violations or tribunals to hear such cases. He added the UN Human Rights Commissioner has not made a request from him with regard to appointing foreign judges.
 More than 400 persons involved in the field of law participated in this year’s National Legislative Summit which was held under the theme ‘The future path of Sri Lanka’.

hits._id: Warning from former President

_source.content:
The term of office of newly elected Local Government councillors begins from today (Mar. 20).
 
The chairmen and mayors of councils where over 50% of votes obtained have already been named.
 
The chairmen and mayors of at LG authorities where no party has obtained over 50% of votes will be chosen at the inaugural session.
 
8356 councillors were elected to 340 LG authorities from the February 10th Local Government poll.
 
Meanwhile, a group of councillors elected from the Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna took oaths before former President Mahinda Rajapaksa today (Mar. 20).
 
Later, the former President warned the newly elected councillors to act with care as the government is watchful over the SLPP councillors.
